Nel or Clare becomes very unstable and begins to change drastically
1152121211212112221111212111.content:
Kathrin brushed back from her face a strand of silvery hair as she watched the Empress’ cortege walk away, trailed by a reduced Nel and Clare, now clad in the cream and blue uniforms of the palatial maidservants, to embark into their ornate and, to her, delicate coaches. These, she thought, were novel little contraptions, borne aloft not by magic but by harnessed and reigned birds: in case of the coaches of the Empress herself, this was drawn by a pair of haughty eagles, while the coaches of the footmen, towards which Nel and Clare were being directed, were altogether smaller and drawn by several ravens. In the evening light the young witch watched the small figures of Clare and Nel walk, seemingly a bit downcast, towards the line of coaches. Clare was the first to embark, the ball-like orb of the coach tilting slightly with her weight. Nel lingered just a second, her eyes focusing on nothing in particular; Kathrin thought, as she looked on at the bluehaired pixie, she saw Nel’s frame tremble or flicker, thought she saw her form expand and contract in a moment less than a heartbeat. But Nel shook her head and stepped up into the coach, drawing the door closed behind her with a click. As the coaches flew away into the sky, Kathrin waved after them. Once she could no longer see them skimming across the tops of the trees, Kathrin furrowed her brow; for a while, she contemplated the huge rocks that were pulverised remains of the clouded heights of the valley mountains, biting her lip.

Some days later, Nel and Clare were allocated their roles within the castle walls for the coming months. Clare had found herself in the scullery and kitchens, where she was resigned to cooking and often sweated so profusely that her uniform was reduced almost to transparency in places and clung to her skin. At other times she was required was required to serve and wait on the table and upon the Empress and her guests, but, although she escaped the sweating and cloying heat of the kitchens below, she found the uniform for this very constraining, especially in the bust and backside, and oftentimes found herself the toast of the Barons and Dukes for the indiscreet and not ungenerous gaps her bosom made between the buttons of her taught maid’s blouses.

By contrast, Nel found herself cleaning and dusting the rooms of the palace, sometimes in rooms so remote from the rest of the castle that she could not see or hear others in the adjoining rooms. The dust, and there seemed to be an awful lot of it gathered on the ornate mantelpieces and postered beds, aggravated her allergies and as she stretched, crouched, and crawled to dust to the steward’s exacting standards the uniform rode up the crack of her backside awfully. Nel, having been reduced from the size of a mountain, had to confess she found adapting to indoors a little difficult, especially seeing as she was returned, not to her former size, but a size fractionally larger than Clare had been before her similar immense inflation. This made negotiated the tighter corners of the room uncomfortable to say the least and she was especially embarrassed when, having squeezed her hefty bosom and plump hips under a bed to sweep dust-bunnies, she found herself stuck and the butler had to lift the frame to let his meaty underling wriggle free. Nel, for all the world, swore her hips shouldn’t have got stuck. She often found herself perched precariously atop stools, one leg stretched out behind her for balance, and wobbling as she attempted to dust a particularly overlooked cranny of a room. Though she was sometimes called upon to provide fresh linens and blankets to the Palace guests, Nel did not have as much to do with the Palace servants or guests, for which she was glad, but she was expected to report to the Empress’ butler in all matters. This cold individual, with a large aquiline nose, made little secret of his contempt for Nel and was in the business of making her scour and dust rooms she considered clean.

In the evenings Clare and Nel, exhausted from working, would take the opportunity to meet each other in one of their respective rooms. One of these nights Clare, fresh from a day in the kitchens, perched on the foot of Nel’s bed. Clare flopped backwards onto the sheets, her taught bosom wobbling, a detail Nel caught with a sideways glance from her place by the armoire. Clare rolled onto her side, propping her head up, and ran her eyes over Nel. “You’re filthy” she eventually opined. Nel turned her to regard Clare outstretched on the sheet in the soft, amber light of the candles. “Well you stink” Clare scowled and curled her head to sniff tentatively at a sodden armpit before pulling a face and plucking at the clinging fabric of her blouse.

In the pause that followed Nel brushed her hair, craning down in the candlelit gloom to look into the dresser mirror; she could not quite suppress the slight curl of a smile at the way her swaying chest hung and filled her nightgown. As Nel adjusted the strap of her nightgown Clare sighed; the bedsprings clinked: “Say, Nel.”.
“Hmmm?”, Nel, still faintly involved in the arch formed by her hanging breasts, absentmindedly returned.
“Have you noticed anything weird happening?”
Nel put down her brush, “How do you mean?” Clare, still lying on her side, continued: “You know about yourself? Anything weird?”
Nel, her curiosity piqued, turned and leaned against the armoire, her hands behind her, “Like what exactly?”
Clare scratched her thigh, “Like, well, okay. Today I was in the kitchen—”
“I can smell” added Nel.
“Shut up” snapped Clare impatiently. “I was in the kitchen today and the cook, after making me peel a complete mountain of potatoes and vegetables. I hate vegetables now mountain after mountain of god damn vegetables. Anyway, sorry, she says I have to take over at the stove while she goes into the village, for whatever reason.” There was a slight noise from the hallway and Clare paused before lowering her voice a fraction.
“Anyway, as I was stirring the pot, I,uh, hit my head on the shelf above the stove.”
Nel snorted, “That was a great story Clare; you should turn it into a book someday”
“Shut up, Miss Sarcastaboobs.”
Nel, still quite amused with herself, added “Well?”
Clare, still conscious of the hallway, continued “Well? Have you ever seen this shelf?”
“You know I haven’t”
“Well, it’s at least several head-heights above the stove! You have to get a stool to get down the pots and pans”
“So”, Nel shrugged, “you’re a tall girl”
“Not THAT tall though! I dropped the spoon into the soup and rubbed my head, looking up at the shelf. I can’t understand how I could have hit it. And here’s another thing: when I was waiting the table for that big function the other day, I was taking round a dish of berries and nuts, when I got this strange feeling that came over me like a shiver. suddenly, and without any warning, the front of my maid’s blouse blew open! It sprayed a few buttons onto the table; one bounced off the aspic and hit some Baron on the forehead; It was mortifying”
Nel, intrigued again, asked “Did anyone say anything?”
Clare rolled her eyes, “That particular baron quipped something like “That one has more wobble than the jelly” and everyone burst into laughter as the steward swept me out of the room”.
Nel snorted again, “Well, Clare, you’re a big girl too; these uniforms are too small for the pair of us; I didn't mind it at first that the Empress left us on the large side for a pixie, but that was before she stuffed us into these uniforms...I can scarcely go ten minutes without a butt-cheek saying hello…”
Clare sat up and continued emphatically, “But don’t you think that’s weird?”
“Not as weird as using a hillside as a pillow”
“Exactly,” as she said this the bedsprings clinked, “I don’t just mean haunted feather-duster weird, I mean weird given our 'condition'.”
“Hmmm”, Nel cocked an eyebrow, “you think you had a few growth spurts, since we arrived?”
“I don’t know”, said Clare, rubbing her arm, “I’m not much bigger if I am Have you noticed anything?”
Nel thought for a moment, “Can’t say I've noticed anything as drastic as that there was the day I was balancing on a stool and a vase fell off the cabinet behind me, I figured I clipped it with my outstretched foot though…” Nel looked about, “I can’t tell though… I’m not used to quite this perspective as it stands.”
Clare closed her eyes and thought back, “It was like a quick expansion and contraction, of suddenly swelling up and suddenly deflating back, like a balloon stretching.”
“Hmmm”, repeated Nel as she thought for a moment, “maybe the potion, or whatever they used to shrink us, wasn't potent enough?” the footsteps of someone passing the door made Nel stop for a moment. When they passed she continued “and maybe it couldn't quite contain us? What with all the volatile magics in us at the time...”
Clare blinked, “So you’re saying our bodies might be unstable?”
Nel tilted her head and stuck out her bottom lip, “Just a tad…”
The candle sputtered a moment before Clare asked “What will we do about it?”
“It doesn’t seem to have lingering effects…” Nel cupped her bosom briefly, “I’m not even sure I’m having them.”
Clare was quick to add “Maybe you’ve just had them when you’re asleep? Or just haven’t noticed?”
“There’s an easy way to tell about all this Clare...Stand up” Nel said, motioning Clare towards her.
Clare hopped from the bed, bouncing ripely in the room’s candlelit penumbra, and came forwards to stand toe-to-toe with Nel. The light from the dresser candles had all but gone out and the smell from the smoke mixed with the smell of Clare’s body, outlined darkly before her. Nel came forward from the armoire, straightened up so her chest pressed against Clare’s...except it was clear that...
“Well….”, Nel quipped, “somebody’s been eating all her vegetables…”
1152121211212112221111212111.title: Unstable Intermissions

choices: He finds Nel is now as tall as the roof!
He finds Nel transformed into a monster!
He finds Nel has disappeared...
11521212112121122211112121112.content:
In the following weeks Clare found that her fluctuations in size were an inconvenience, but one which she managed, more or less, successfully to conceal from those about her. Since Clare was, with the way her body was beginning to bulge out of her clothing through every hole and gap, ever more resembling a rising loaf of overproofed dough, with great bulging egg of her chest straining her blouses to breaking point, her feet curling up inside plimsolls, and her thighs pressing together inside her skirt even as her hips threatened to rip it asunder at the seams, neither of the girls expected that the most radical effect would eventually come from Nel, who, hitherto, had had comparatively few problems with random fluctuations in her height, weight or her “bodaciousness”. True, Clare was beginning to provoke questions, like: why was the new girl always hitting her head? why wasn’t the new girl given a properly fitting uniform? did the new girl seem different? why was the new girl always nipping out of the kitchen? why were they alway finding buttons in places? why, suddenly, was the new girl able to lift whole crates of potatoes like throw-pillows? was the new girl stealing pumpkins? And it was true that both Nel and Clare took to fretting about keeping Clare’s episodes a secret, coming up with all manner of weird excuses, like: she was wearing a sprite-sized uniform; she was clumsy; that was supposed to be exposed; she had good genes; it was their imagination; boys always think they’re bigger than they are; she had an upset stomach; the weather was changing and it affected her badly. Nel deflected attention from the occasionally bulging Clare with expertise and precision, for lying came quite naturally to her.

In fact, so concerted were Nel’s efforts to cover up Clare’s various “little” accidents and mishaps that she scarcely noticed her own. It was strange, given Nel’s intimate and, for that matter, first hand knowledge of their unstable affliction that she should fail to think much of becoming suddenly stuck under a bed or catching a vase upon a mantlepiece as she passed by and breaking it when carrying out the duties she had been assigned about the castle. Perhaps it was that she, being, for the most part, and unlike Clare, was left very much to her own devices and would seldom see another soul in the vast wings of the Palace until her senior servants would come in to inspect her handiwork, fastidiously combing over every inch and jot of the room until something unsatisfactory was discovered. For her job was never satisfactory, despite her efforts, and when it was discovered, as it inevitably was, be it a speck of dust on the windowsill or a feather slightly protruding from the quilt, it was rained down upon Nel in the calm and reserved triumph only imperial butlers and stewards could command. A tone which, more often than not, was intended to make its recipient, usually Nel, of whom, it had been decided, they would make an example, feel worthless, make them feel far smaller than they were. Nel was often treated to such scathing critiques of her cleaning and housekeeping, perhaps because they did not like her attitude or the circumstances under which they had been landed with her, and would be left to redo the room, from top to bottom, with her anger and resentment fulminating in her head and belly. The Steward remarked once to the Butler, vis-a-vis the attitude of his blue-haired pixie, that he had had to make her redo the windowpanes of the Rose room, which she had basically missed altogether; the young pixie had not said a word, but her eye had twitched, which the Steward took as a sign of her rebellious soul. Having completed the task as she should have done in the first place the Steward had sent her about the rest of her day, but, watching her go down the corridor, to see that she did not slip off, this young, blue-haired pixie had, presumably because she thought the Steward still inside the Rose room, clutched and pulled at the backside of her garments! As if they were uncomfortably tight or hitched up! Such coarseness and how indiscreet!

Sometimes Nel would lie awake at night, her hands and knees sore, and glare at the ceiling, her teeth gritted, and think that the steward might not be so quick to censure her if he knew that she was forced to dust and scrub the rooms and chambers of the palace only because she had, just over a week ago, towered over these ramparts and turrets and that even the largest of the Palace vaults, cloisters or halls could not have contained her! Oh how he’d change his tune, thought Nel with a quiet smile to herself, if I were just a fraction of that size again! For Nel had, although she had only sought to reach such proportions as a means to contending with the then enormous and size-delirious Clare, become quickly accustomed to having that new perspective on the world and, although she had for a long time wanted to be taller, never had she imagined that she would be THAT large or that it would feel SO right! Nel had been reminded of this feeling when she was folding a quilt in one of the royal chambers, upon which was embroidered a landscape, a map of the realm, with the castle, the blue mountains and the vast forests stretching across it. Nel had examined this stitched landscape for a moment as she smoothed it flat across the bed and thought again of the view from such great heights that she had enjoyed, so it seemed, only for a moment. She thought of looking down from the summit of her stature at the matchbox houses and the forest which seemed only like the bristles of a deep green carpet, and Nel contemplated throwing herself down upon the bed and the quilt and stretching her body across that fabric landscape as if she were a part of it. Think of this now, lying in bed, Nel gave an involuntary wriggle. It was perhaps these memories of her former size, and her fondness for her larger stature, that worked somewhat to embitter Nel as she dusted and cleaned, made her difficult, intransigent and, no doubt, stoked the fires of her resentment. Quite apart from being almost constantly irritable and on edge, there were times during the last week when Nel, who had never been an exceptionally angry person, felt she could scarcely contain herself, like her anger was overpowering her. During these episodes, usually face to face with one of her superiors in the Palace staff, Nel felt her cheeks flushing and a sensation as if her belly were full of molten lead, churning and burning. Apart from this her vision would swim as she felt light-headed, dizzy and often sick, in fact often having to fight down the impulse to wretch, which, doubtless, would not have been well received. But Nel managed to keep herself bottled up, focusing on keeping herself upright when her knees inevitably began to wobble and tremble as if they were made of jelly.

It was, therefore, on one of these occasions that Nel finally snapped. Nel had, on this occasion, neglected to sweep from the mouth of the fireplace a several cinders and a few flecks of soot. The fire had not been lit that year and Nel had overlooked this. The Steward drew himself up, sighing as if he did not like being so pedantic, and flicking his swallowtails out behind him, while managing to look down his nose at Nel, through the little circular lenses of his glasses, despite being a head shorter than her. During his lecture on the value of detail, the Steward noticed the twitch in the girl’s eye again and resolved to set her right! Meanwhile Nel was becoming more and more aggravated. The room was long, more of hall really, how could she had done it all herself? Nel gritted her teeth and felt her blood boiling, hearing it in her ears. Her cheeks flushed red, as the Steward crooked a finger at her and said “Come” as he turned his back and began to walk the length of the hall. Nel rolled her eyes and followed, fighting the urge to be sick with rage. Again!?

“The windows look a touch dusty” said the Steward, not turning but indicating them with a wave of his hand as they walked. Nel focused on putting one foot in front of another; her knees were wobbling and, looking down at her feet, she saw perspiration forming on her chest.

Passing by a table, the Steward paused a moment to hold up a chess-piece to his eye for closer inspection, making a show out of it for Nel, who all the time felt herself becoming angrier, but took the chance to clutch at her backside and dislodge her undergarments. Replacing the piece, he moved on down the room.

As he walked on the Steward indicated the chairs and the chaise longue on his right, which he said were in a sorry state and should be shine and plumped. Nel, following in town, felt something plummet in her stomach; her eyes wide, she said nothing as her vision swam.

They were drawing towards the other end of the hall as he the Steward remarked that the rug would need adjusted. By this point Nel was drifting behind clutching her stomach, but as he continued on she felt something bubbling up from the pit of her stomach. Anyone looking in would have seen quite the scene.

The Steward walked on casually, oblivious to the fact Nel was neither listening nor following him now. As he approached the end of the room where the fireplace lay he seemed unaware of the shadow beginning to stretch across the hall. He fastidiously ran a finger along the mantelpiece and rubbed it as it loomed behind him taller and taller “Yes…” he said, pausing for effect, as the chandelier jingled. “I’m afraid you’ll just have to do it again” he said wearily, “am I understood Miss?” No reply, the shadow now spreading over the end of the hall. The Steward asked again “Miss?”, conscious of a kind of rubbery sound from time to time. There was a crunch from behind him and the scraping of furniture and a rumbling. Incensed by the girl, he rounded on the blue-haired pixie in fury, his finger brandished: “ Do I make myself...perfectly...clear”
11521212112121122211112121112.title: Nel's Anger Management

choices: Nel outgrows the wing of the Palace
Nel spots Clare in the hall
There is a rumbling from outside
115212121121211222111121211121.content:
Nel had, only moments before, been trailing the steward’s coat-tails disconsolately; however, now, she found her shoulders pressing hard against the ridged ceiling and her head, crooked at the neck, slowly scraping along the curve of the roof. To the steward, who all the while had remained practically oblivious, the change must have practically instantaneous; yet it was hardly that for Nel and, behind his turned back and clasped hands, it went something like this. Nel had, her pent up anger now mounting to bursting point, found herself overcome by feelings of dizziness and nausea and she faltered as she walked behind the steward. Her hands resting on her belly, Nel’s anger thawed into a mixture of confusion and discomfort. It felt as if the rage and frustration welling up inside her over the passing weeks had suddenly burst, sending it running down into the pit of her stomach in a cold stream, like meltwater flowing down from a glacier to the valley below in the midst of Summer. Nel felt her gut groan as she stopped walking altogether. Nel struggled to focus on the slim, tall figure of the steward as he walked onwards as her vision seemed to swim. She was suddenly aware of her legs feeling weak and Nel looked down to see them trembling like strands of kelp caught in a current—they felt as if they were made of jelly and might give way under her at any second. Nel’s eyes grew wide as, after a momentary pause, her legs suddenly wobbled, so much so that her knees knocked together a few times; more surprising still was that her legs appeared to be growing longer before her eyes! Releasing her aching stomach, Nel clapped her hands onto her thighs, even as she did so feeling them thickening beneath her fingers. She managed to stifle a cry of surprise as she found herself climbing higher, on what seemed like ever-growing stilts. Nel released her legs and held her arms out to her sides in a bid to balance on her elongated legs, wobbling and teetering like some huge, gangly fly or wading bird. Nel looked again at her legs to see the tights of her uniform split open like banana peels as her legs spurted up again, revealing the white flesh beneath. It crossed Nel’s mind to attract the steward’s attention and he strolled on, oblivious, muttering something or other. Nel wobbled back on forth on legs now fully three times her body-length, before feeling the plummeting sensation in her guts again and she had just enough time to stabilise herself before hips flared outwards and her buttocks suddenly bulged, quite as if she were a rubber balloon being abruptly pumped full of a quantity of water. Nel’s hips and butt-cheeks swelled from this particular spurt until her skirt sat about her waist like a thin, delicate band of sapphire on a lady’s finger. Nel was struggling more than ever to keep her balance at this point, feeling not unlike a spinning-top, when she noticed her arms stretching too! Growing longer and branching out from her body, atop her trunklike legs, towards the sides of the room. Her arms now long and unwieldy, there was nothing Nel could do when, after only a few moments wherein she seems to have stopped growing, her chest swelled up with the same violence as her hips had done, the great orbs bursting the buttons from her powder blue blouse within seconds, seeming, after their surge, to eclipse her torso altogether. Nel thanked heaven that the steward was, in his old age, becoming hard of hearing, so as not to her the rending and tearing of her maid’s garments, and she could only pray that he did not notice the buttons sent forth from her burgeoning bosom like sparks from a fire. Nel’s chest was now so heavy that it was becoming a strain to remain upright, despite the size and sturdiness of her legs, and began to slowly bear her down towards the floor! It was in that instant, just as her nipples threatened to graze the carpet, and Nel herself was sweating from the exertion of holding herself, moreover her monstrous chest, up, with her now huge arms braces against the walls, that Nel’s torso caught up to the rest of her. Nel suddenly was conscious of the weight easing and lifting as her trunk lengthened and thickened, casting her shadow across the hall as her shoulders lengthened and cracked. Nel was able, at this point, to straighten herself up somewhat. She had only a moment to cast a confused glance about her at the size of her head before, with a suddenness that shook Nel’s vision, it inflated to fit her body with a pop, tousling her blue hair. All this happened in the time it took the steward to cross the hall and Nel stood and watched him as he stood there, hands clasped behind his back, bracing herself for the reveal. Nel bit her lip as she saw the steward draw a deep breath. But Nel caught her own breath as she felt the plummeting sensation again and the trembling of her limbs. She soon found her wobbling knees bending and her arms crooked at the elbows, with her hands, pressed flat against the walls. Nel winced as her head bumped against the ceiling and she bend her neck—she was getting too tall for the room! Even now the steward, ever the primadonna, had not turn, instead seeming to casually inspect his fingernails with an air, Nel guessed, of regret. Nel could only dimly hear the steward muttering something, but whatever it was it detracted from by another growth spurt, wedging Nel, even with her back bent, in the ceiling space, her head brushing aside the chandelier, her legs crooked and knees turned inwards, and her arms braced against the walls. Nel attempted to blow her hair from her face when the steward, standing before the now much taller Nel like a cricket turned on her, fury on his face, brandishing a tiny finger at the space where Nel should have been. But, of course, she was not. The steward’s eyes were met not by those of a young girl, blushing from embarrassment at being hauled up for her shoddiness, but instead met only a tattered pile of clothes where the girl had been and, instead, his eyes followed the trunk of a massive and shapely leg upwards, towards a pair of hips like an onion dome at the foot of the towering column of a torso, which, as it extended upwards, and as the steward’s eyes lifted along its height, widened not only into broad, rampartlike shoulders, but branched out into long, powerful arms reaching across the width of the hall and billowed outwards in a bosom like an avalanche, which hung there, half eclipsing the view of the midriff, like an enormous soft pillow, before his eyes reached the heart-shaped face, framed by blue hair, hanging above him like the moon in a morning-sky and, finally, his gaze met the huge green eyes of the girl, which were full of embarrassment, shock and boldness. Perhaps it was natural, then, that some of the steward’s ire disappeared suddenly and he found himself lost for words.

Nel looked down at the cricket of a steward below her and attempted to shift a bit inside the hall. She could see his little eyes glinting, and wondered if it was fear or surprise she saw on his minute features. Nel was still somewhat shocked herself at this sudden growth spurt and had barely had time to adjust, yet she still took the opportunity to be defiant: “I’m sorry” she spoke, feeling her voice rumbling out from her mouth, “my head must have been elsewhere, would you like to repeat that last part?” Nel smirked a touch when the steward said nothing and instead remained stock still before the fireplace: “Thought so”, she boomed, attempting to draw herself up as much as possible, “not quite so critical of me now are you?” Nel tried to reposition her legs in the hall, bringing them together. “Because, if you were”, she went on, smiling down at the floor, “that little growth spurt made me big enough to kick your butt! Ha, made me big enough to squash you flat!” Nel, though she was annoyed, was far too elated to find herself tall again to follow through on her threats, but had forgotten, or seemed oblivious to, the tendency people had, when one was now a giant, many times their size, to treat what you said with a certain seriousness. Nel had not noticed the maid who, attracted by Nel’s booming voice, had slipped in at a sidedoor, who, at Nel’s taunt, screamed so loud it hurt Nel’s ears. Nel was startled and bumped her head against the ceiling with a crash, which sent spiderweb cracks spreading across the hall. Nel swore and looked down as best she could: “settle down, lady!” The maid had fainted and had been joined by another and then another. Nel looked back to the steward to see he had been joined by a worried-looking young lad and that the door at the back of the room held the forms of several similarly distressed maids. Nel tried to smile sheepishly: “It’s my first day?” Without warning the young boy shot off too fast for Nel, whose maneuverability was limited as it was, to grab him. She helplessly watched him dart through a doorway, knowing he was off to alert the Empress. “Aww, no, don’t do that” she moaned as he disappeared. Another maid who had just entered screamed and ran back out crying “monster!” followed by another few shrieks from other staff. Nel’s head clattered with the chandelier again; she was getting worked up again: “Can you just… not?” Nel moved her foot and crushed a chaise longue, the broken timber stabbing into her sole. Nel howled in pain and stumbled backwards, Nel arm brushing a large gargoyle from the wall. Nel fell onto her giant rump, crushing more furniture, and slammed her head against the rear wall. “OW!” cried Nel clutching her head, “see what you made me do!?” The steward and the others were quickly retreating through the doorways: “Oi!!”, Nel boomed, “where do you think you’re going!?” Nel, becoming annoyed by now, was about to move when another large gargoyle fell onto her head. “RRRRRRRR!” Nel, her head dusty with granite and her butt-cheeks pricked by furniture, was about to scream when she abruptly froze, her eyes wide…
115212121121211222111121211121.title: Rule 42: All Persons more than a mile high...

choices: Her curiousity piqued, Nel goes for a stroll over to the Mages' Tower
Nel pays a visit to the Empress and those gathered in the Cathedral
Nel heads to the woods around the Palace; no sense in waiting around
1152121211212112221111212111211.content:
Moments later in the Palace grounds there came a rumbling, a rumbling which shook the boughs of the trees and juddered the stones in the rockery. Those in the garden cast about them, got to their feet and looked in confusion at the stream of servants and waiting staff fleeing from one of the Palace’s various service entrances. Meanwhile, those with a better view of the hall where barons, counts, dukes, their wives and others would retire after dinner to mingle, smoke and drink brandy, speculate on the affairs of the kingdom, be entertained by the recitals or performances the Empress would arrange and make witty remarks, situated on the far left wing of the Palace, where the rumbling was worst, could see, through the high and latticed windows of that hall, something swelling up from inside, as if someone were inflating a hot-air balloon inside, a balloon fashioned of white silk and bedsheets. Only several moments passed before the roof of the hall began to heave, the ridge starting to curve, the slates dislodging and sliding off to crack on the ground and the roof itself was soon straining at the eaves. Scarcely had the roof begun to bow when there burst forth from the lateral facade of the hall the long, white trunk of an arm in a shower of dust, glass and masonry. This arm was propelled, obviously, by its owner’s increasing size, which had sent it through the side of the building, from its place braced against the wall of the hall, when space began to become an issue. And now, as this huge limb lay tensed on the lawn, its palm planted down, still lengthening and thickening, there came from the other side of the building a similar crashing and shattering that suggested that another arm had burst from the side of the hall. Soon though, the roof was shuddering and bulging further, accompanied by a horrible splintering of wood and cracking of masonry. The roof ridge split like the shell of a duck’s egg and there rose from this fissure, in a cloud of slate dust and broken masonry, a giant blue head. And as the onlookers looked up in shock, this blue head climbed higher, shards of slate falling from those long tresses and clattering on the roofing and guttering. In sporadic leaps and spurts the blue-haired head rose from the hall. The edges of the roof crumbled as a pair of huge shoulders forced their way through with the long neck and head. People were fleeing across the lawns, through the hedgerows, and out of the gates as the roof of the hall started to crumble further still as a giant bosom, a huge mound of marble flesh, rose upwards from below. A growing shadow was now spreading across the grounds, swallowing up the flowers, the trees and statuettes. Those attracted from the other reaches of the grounds by the commotion stood on the grass rapt with shock as a giant figure stood up from the hall, bits of masonry and roofing clinging to its massive form. Brushing its body down, the giant figure, still climbing, drew back its blue tresses to examine the scene before letting a surprised and brash laugh.

Nel, now suddenly finding herself restored, despite the Empress’ counter-measures, to huge and still-increasing proportions, could not help but laugh. She had been concerned all this while that it would be Clare who caused a scene like this, her already confined bosom suddenly erupting one morning in the kitchen and her legs and buttocks shooting through a rear wall as her golden head ploughed through room after room. But instead it had been her! She had been so concerned with covering up Clare’s little spurts that she had been oblivious to her own not-so-little spurts! Nel curiously hefted and weighed her own bosom in her huge hand, feeling her nipples and, also, feeling her skin stretching beneath her palms. Her bosom gradually threatening to obscure her view of the ground below, Nel glanced down, through the chasm between her breasts at the length of her torso, along her expanding midriff, fixing for a moment on the gorse of blue hair atop her lower regions, and settled on the rooftops and Palace lawn gradually receding from her as she continued to grow. Seeing her perspective on the world still changing, Nel soon realised that her long calves, as the grew longer and thickened, would soon begin to eat up the hole made in the roof of the hall by her head, shoulder and chest, and from which the still climbing figure of Nel protruded like a giant sunflower. To avoid the eventuality where her feet would become stuck in what was, to her, no more than a large shoebox, Nel unclasped her chest, for she needed her arms for balance, and tentatively brought up her left leg and stepped free of the remains of the hall, the black shadow of her leg passing over the lawns as he foot planted down on the grass by a copse of tree with a resounding boom. Straddling the grounds and the hall awkwardly for a moment, as he outstretched arms helped her adjust to the ungainliness of her still increasing size, Nel hauled up her right leg, bringing it up and around over the rooftops, lodging and shattering a slender steeple in the process. Nel now stood on the lawns of the Palace gardens; about her saw the flowerbeds and rockeries which seemed to her like little jewelry boxes or assorted sweets, the meticulously kept hedgerows winding across the grounds like a dark green snake and she looked down about her at the trees which looked less like the tall and ancient trees they were, looked after by generations up generations of gardeners, but more like shrubs or bushes growing in array on the grounds. Looking at these trees, and at the figures of people flitting across the lawn, Nel could not help but wonder how big she must be and if there would soon be a point when these trees resembled toadstools compared to her.

But, even as she thought this, Nel felt the swelling rumble of her body beginning to sputter and wane, and it was with a mixture of elation and disappointment that she saw the ground slowly cease to recede before her, the feeling of the grass rumpling beneath her feet diminishing, and felt herself grinding to a halt. A slight “Awww” escaped from Nel’s lips; she could not help but wish she was just a bit bigger; she had been many times this size before! But, Nel thought as she cast about, this would do still nicely! Nel, the initial mood of surprised contemplation of herself, and herself in comparison to her surroundings, beginning to disperse and the almost petulant and impish feeling of glee at finding herself, once again, much bigger beginning to creep in, Nel heaved a huge breath and placed her hand on her giant hips, elbows turned out, and grinned, her vast bosom stuck out before her like the battlements of some castle. Moments later the trees in the gardens shook with a peal of laughter. Looking down at the servants, gardeners and domestic staff flitting across the lawns or into domiciles encircling the Palace, Nel could not help but laugh; she leaned forward, the better to see the ground, casting her shadow more darkly across the grounds: “Yeah”, she boomed in jest, “you better run.” Despite her efforts she could not see the Steward, who had no doubt scarpered before ever she outgrew the hall; Nel could not help but be slightly galled that she could not seize this opportunity to teach him a lesson in manners, now that she had tipped the scales in her favour. Nel cast about her again, looking out over the rooftops and steeples of the Palace, towards the grand hall, the pinnacle of the mage’s tower, the bell tower atop the cathedral, which was just beginning to strike tea-time, and the gardens sprawling away into a thick wood which encompassed the Palace; Nel’s carmine lips curled as smile creased her face again: “Yup, this is JUST what I needed!”
1152121211212112221111212111211.title: Raising the roof

choices: Nel lays siege to the Archmage's tower! The Archmage fights back!
Nel plunders the potions vaults! That ought to give her a "little" boost!
Nel breaks into the aedificium! Just for something to give her a "tiny" edge!
11521212112121122211112121112111.content:
A quarter past the stroke of six found Nel, now standing taller than the trees and better built than the Gothic masonry about her, skirting the Mages' Quarter of the Palace, a sort of labyrinth of vaulted buildings and spires, containing library upon library, vast lecture halls, vaults of arcana, artifacts, potions and useless junk. Even at her new size, the room at the top of the Mages’ tower, which was central to the quarter and rose above it like a spearhead of turquoise and brass, and was where the Imperial Archmage resided, was still higher than Nel. Nel craned her neck and stood on her huge tiptoes to try and peek in through the many latticed windows that lines the upper tower, but to no avail. Nel had always wanted to attend the University here, but it was, to say the least, rather exclusive and was not easy for someone like her to gain entry— students were typically backed by wealthy financiers, be they parents or benevolent, philanthropic lords or ladies. Now Nel relished the opportunity to see the University, which was adjunct to the Palace, and to gain access to the University by the ever-so-slightly unorthodox route of straddling one of the buildings as it were a garden gate.

Hooking her leg over the rooftops of the Mage’s sleeping quarters, Nel stepped into the courtyard, taking with her a chimney stack from the dormitory. A tall tree in the courtyard gardens, wafting gently in the breeze, brush softly against Nel’s thigh. Nel craned over out of curiosity to peer inside the dormitory windows, which seemed like a doll’s house to her, and presenting to the upper floors of the University corridors, at the south wing of the courtyard, a marvelous eyeful of tremendous rump, the huge, white expanse of her rear seeming to swallow up the view from the high windows and, as Nel inspected more closely, threatened to bust the very facade of the building. In the dormitory, the pupils who had retired to their dormitories after dinner, were shocked when the windowpanes were suddenly filled by a great, green iris and pupil, peering in at them with apparent curiosity. From somewhere the young mages, some of whom had hidden in wardrobes or under their beds, heard a booming chirrup of laughter: “Ha! Boo!”. Nel titled her head, the better to peer at the little figures inside the dormitories, who were skittering about like mice, panicked by something. Nel laughed again: “My teachers said I’d never fit in at the Mage’s school; Wow were they right! There’s no way I’d fit in THERE now!” boomed Nel as she poked a windowpane gently with an outstretched finger. Her curiosity overcoming her, Nel prised up the roof to peek inside, coming away surprisingly easily, to a chorus of shrieks and yells, while Nel, instead marveled at her own strength. Inspecting the contents of the dormitory, Nel looked down upon the neat little rooms of the upper stories, arranged before her eyes like the compartments of a jewellry box: before her were little four-poster beds, some made and unmade, decked with blue curtains, and scarcely more substantial than a matchbox, and dark, wooden bookcases that reached to the ceiling, stuffed with books the names of which Nel could not distinguish at her size, and round, high-backed little armchairs, of blue leather, with bright dots of golden buttons, which looked very comfortable, except that Nel’s rear would never have been accommodated by one of them, and delicate torch-brackets with flickering flames, and glossy armoires, and cute little, claw-footed bathtubs, in which a small bearded mage was frozen amidst a pile of bubbles, scrubbing brush poised under an arm, and long indigo curtains which billowed as Nel drew breath, and the large footlockers, or trunks, at the foot of each bed, which, when Nel picked one up to inspect it, rattled like a box of pins. Nel dropped the trunk back into the room as delicately as she could and let the roof down again, letting it go with a crash. Nel straightened back up to her full height, hands placed on the small of her back do that her huge chest thrust even further outwards as she stretched, her eyes scanning the rooftops of the University.
*
The Imperial Archmage, a Professor and Magister for come fifty years now, a certain Algernon Charles Loyola, had retired to his quarters, in the high, glass-windowed chamber at the top of the Mages’ tower, after a hearty dinner in the refectory, where he had indulged himself in a nap before the evening’s course of work: a night of poring over tomes, translating antique texts, examining the skies, copying out passages, watching alembics, writing letters, feeding the owl, napping at his desk, finishing his yet unfinished book on volatile magics and his memoirs, napping some more, combing his white beard (which long ago more or less eclipsed any view of his torso), shouting at young mages who had been partying in the courtyard form one of the windows, staring at the ceiling in rapt concentration, napping in his chair, reading letters from his associates in the guild of Mages in other provinces, pretending to read letters from his associates in the guild of Mages, poking at the fire, browsing the many cabinets of books that lined the room, napping, walking up and down the floorboards in the twilight, and occasionally just looking out over the spires of the University in calm contemplation. It was to this last activity that the Archmage now sought to apply himself, waking from his nap, for his old age had made him increasingly thoughtful as the years passed, he had always been somewhat zany and this had not been lessened by the advancing of time. On this evening the Archmage crossed the dark, hard wooden boards of the floor to the window. Drawing open the rich, blue curtains by the golden cord, the Archmage looked out into the crepuscular light. Today though, instead of being drawn to the fading light, turning the hills beyond violet and the trees of the forests black, his eyes were inextricably drawn to the University rooftops and the courtyard.

Quite apart from the tall tree by the cloisters, a tree he remembered as a young student, whose leaves were now touched with the orange light of the evening and blowing gently in the breeze, the Archmage was shocked to find himself looking down at an enormous pair of buttocks upended in the courtyard, jutting up many feet into the air, like a great, white peach! Taking off his glasses and rubbing the sleep from his eyes with a finger and the heel of his thumb, inspecting the lenses of his glasses, blowing on them to fog said lenses, polishing them on the sleeves of his robe while glancing calmly about the room, and finally returning them to balance atop his nose, the Archmage looked again. But, yes, it was unmistakable, that was a colossal rump, even down to the freckle on the left cheek. Indeed the huge buttocks, seeming like the moon as they caught the evening light coming across the rooftops, waggled back and forth as if to emphasise their, admittedly quite significant, impression. Of all the things to happen around the University during his incumbency as Archmage this was arguable one of the stranger ones, certainly ranking alongside the time the bins came to life and tried to swallow the janitor or the time the aedificium had been upturned to balance precariously on its spire. The evening sun was setting as Nel, a strange sight at several stories tall, rubbed her cheek, where a red mark and a smarting had been left by a bolt of magic, flung by the Archmage atop his tower. Before Nel could react further, another bolt whistled down from the heights, striking her on the chin. Nel yelped and flailed a little before composing herself, only to clench her fists, grit her teeth and snort through her nose like a vituperative dragon. “That HURTS! Stop that you little—”, boomed Nel, only to be interrupted by another flying spark, “OWCH!” Nel took a booming step backwards, almost unbalancing for a moment, for she was still not entirely adjusted to her new size, neither to the weight of her immense, wibbling bust nor to teetering atop her cumbersome and treetrunk tall legs. Regaining her balance, Nel glared up at the tower and the figure at its top. Nel stamped her foot, blocking another bolt flung down from the tower with her hand, and stormed towards the tower with large, thunderous footfalls. Reaching the tower, the next volley of bolts landing on her hair, and therefore of little concern to her, Nel stood on tiptoes and attempted to reach the ringed balcony on which the Archmage was standing. But, must to her dismay, it was out of her reach, even at this size! Nel’s outstretched finger was pricked by a shard from the Archmage and she hastily withdrew it with a yelp, sucking her finger and thumping the tower with her other hand. With climbing out of the question, next Nel tried planting her hands against the tower and attempted to push the tower over! But, much to Nel’s frustration, the tower had been standing for centuries for good reason and she could not budge it, at least not by pushing. As Nel fumed and thought of a new course of action, a fireball came sizzling down from above and caught her upper arm. Nel clapped her hand over the singed area and glared up at the balcony: if only she could have a nice, juicy growth spurt about now. But, despite Nel’s rage, no sudden surge came. She looked down about her for something to use, arm still wound around her body, tucked under her bosom. Nel, seeing no other option, slammed the girth of her hip into the tower, shaking it as if a battering ram had collided with it. Satisfied with the results, Nel could not help but laugh triumphantly and swing her hips into the tower again, sending a ripple through her buttocks and sending a few slates from the spiretop sliding down. Nel slid a huge hand down the curve of her bulwark hips and eyed the tower thoughtfully for a moment. Biting her lip, she gave her ass cheek a slap with a sound like a peal of lightning before gleefully swinging her hips into the tower again.


The archmage, standing atop the tower, nearly lost his footing as the giant pixie thumped herself into the foundations, having to steady himself on the balustrade to prevent from falling. Scarcely had he had time to stabilise himself than another huge thud shook the tower. Clutching the dark wooden balustrade, the archmage looked over the parapet. He could only distinguish, for all the shaking, the girl’s mass of blue hair, her pointed ears, expansive shoulders and, he glimpsed with a feeling that made him feel a profound sense of vertigo, the black chasm as cleavage. Swinging back from the parapet, the Archmage thought frantically. Thinking for only a moment longer, as the tower was convulsed by another shudder from the pixie’s monstrous rear, the Archmage threw back his long sleeves and threw forth from his fingertips a plume of blue smoke, which travelled up over the parapet and resolved itself into a cloud, floating above Nel’s big, blue head.


Nel was stopped in her battering of the tower’s foundations for a moment, feeling a light sprinkling on her head. Nel looked up at the cloud and it’s fine veil of drizzle falling. As droplets pooled on her cheeks, Nel let out a laugh: “It’ll take a bit more than a little rain to stop me little guy!” Nel wiped her cheeks and ran her hands through her hair: “But thanks all the same! I was getting a bit sweaty from all this effort!” Nel dusted her left buttock for an instant, before bunching up her hands and resuming her demolition, rain still lightly falling on her head. Such was Nel’s absorption in the task of levelling the Archmage’s tower with her wrecking-ball hips that she failed to clock the cloud above her suddenly start to flush purple and to swell. As Nel drew back for another thunderous hip-bump she was suddenly convulsed by the most horrific jolt, which shot through her body in a wave of agonising pain.


Nel lurched backwards, her huge arms flailing and her huge feet shaking the courtyard and turning up paving stones in a series of staccato, thunderous booms. Just what gave Nel such an advantage over everyone, her by now prodigious size, was fast beginning to hamper Nel, no longer used to the bulk of her bosom, hips and limbs. Just as Nel had almost managed to compose herself, her huge breasts seeming to lag just a little bit behind the rest of her as they bounced back into place, she looked up in time to catch another bolt from the tower’s top, this time catching her on her cheek. Nel yelped and stumbled backwards again, almost tripping over the oak tree that grew in the courtyard. “Hey!” Nell thundered, clutching her cheek and stamping a foot, “No fair!” But suddenly, even as she said this, Nel felt a gurgling in her stomach; clutching her stomach, Nel briefly looked down and then back up at the tower. “Oh you’re for it now beardy!” Nel felt the rumblings in her gut intensify, fuel by her rage. Nel felt the familiar swell of her stomach, bulging out as if a weather balloon were being inflated, and grinned as she felt the sensation subside and seem to travel up and up through her monolithic frame. Nel fixed her gaze at the tower’s spire, as if she intended not just to attain its height but soon thereafter to pick her teeth with it! Nel braced herself, the feeling swelling inside her, still rising upwards and upwards.


A moment later, Nel’s body seemed to shake with the force of a belch; nothing more. In the pause that followed all that could be heard was the wind soughing in the tree and sound of crows cawing and taking wing in some far-off field. Nel only had time to frown down at her huge but ungrowing trunk before the Archmage, recovering faster from the thunderous eruption faster than Nel herself, sent flying from the tower’s top a gusting flurry of snow and sleet, which drove into Nel’s face, cramming her nostrils and blinding her eyes. Nel flailed backwards once more, trying to shield her face and claw the snow from her eyes, thundering across the cobbles and flagstones of the courtyard. So bewildered was she, so unused to the ponderous bulk of her own body, so unused to the potential obstacles architecture might cause her, that Nel blundered into the cloisters partitioning the west courtyard of the mage’s university from the east. Nel’s foot caught on the machicolated masonry and, with a yelp, the giant pixie was sent flying across the courtyard, her shadow passing over the students fleeing her like that of an aeroplane; stumbling off the grass in the eastern courtyard, Nel almost regained her composure, but her huge, ungainly body bore her on as she flailed her arms, only to plunge headfirst into the vast and imposing walls of the aedificium.

From the top of the spire, the Archmage sighed with relief. Crossing the circular walkway of the tower, he looked down over the wooden railing at the eastern courtyard. The huge, blue-haired pixie had crashed through the facade of the aedificium, housing the mage’s labyrinthine magical library; there now protruded from the hole in that facade, amidst the still settling clouds of grey mortar and dust, the trunks of two long legs and a pair of huge buttocks powdered with broken masonry, while the rest of the giant pixie, it was to be assumed, had crashed into the atrium of the library, where she was either unconscious, stunned or stuck. The Archmage leaned on the railing, as if contemplating the huge legs and rump of the girl, which stuck out from the aedificium like a branch of coral, or as if a smooth, white meteor has struck earth and lay there smoking. He was lost in thought, twisting her beard around a finger, as the apprentices began to emerge tentatively from the sheltered cloisters. What an awful mess... Oh well, all in a day's work as Archmage!...Still not the strangest thing to have happened at the university... He was just about to return to bed and let the Empress and others deal with the giant young lady when he was distracted by something....

11521212112121122211112121112111111.content:
From the top of the Mage’s spire, the Archmage could not help but gawk down at the scene unfolding in the courtyard outside the library. Having toppled the giant, blue-haired pixie that had suddenly intruded upon the cloisters, sending her tumbling backwards with a flurry of spells, things had taken on a new, more perplexing aspect. One would not have thought that things could become much worse, but shortly after tumbling headlong through the edifice of the Mage library, something the Archmage had felt some regret about but chiefly owing to the work that would be involved in repairing the masonry and reorganising the strewn books, the giant pixie’s legs, which had hung limply out of the library like wilted petals, had begun to suddenly snake their way across the cobbles on the courtyard! As they did this, the flesh of these already impressively long limbs grew thicker and rounder as if watching the trunks of oak trees across many, many years. The Archmage had been about to repair to his chambers, where he intended to arrange for the restraint and containment of the giant young pixie while the Empress passed her verdict, when he noticed this unexpected development. Indeed, noticing this, the Archmage could see that as these legs thickened they seeming to flow away from the base of the giant pixie’s huge arse, which was lodged uncomfortably in the hole her body had made in the library, flowing down into and across the courtyard like streams of white milk. And as his gaze followed the legs up to the those fleshy cheeks stuck in the masonry, like some great cloven cheese, he could easily discern them seeming to undulate and bulge, protruding more and more from the architecture! Looking down from the spire, the Archmage could only watch those cheeks swell and fatten, seeming, as they definitely grew larger, to pitch towards him like a moon crashing to earth or, he reflected, like puffball mushroom growing so rampantly in meadow that its bulk had split.

http://i.ebayimg.com/images/i/3016085960...

There was something mesmeric to the experience, terrible though it was, for what man of letters could not appreciate orbs of such smooth beauty? Or appreciate the appropriateness that a little knowledge was a dangerous thing? For it had become clear that the magic housed in that labyrinthine library, in the form of its many magical books, tomes, grimoires and octavos, was having some terrible effect on the young, albeit tall, lady he had sent collapsing upon the library. She must, the Archmage reasoned, have received some terrific dose of magic, available to her only because of her great size, for ordinary pixies would never have been able to swallow whole one book, let alone many. What was worse, and though deducible from the Archmage's vantage, though not necessarily appreciable, was that, as Nel’s legs lengthened and her arse swelled, the rest of her, inside the vault of the library, amongst the veritable vortex of bookcases, was also growing! The result of this was not only that she gradually ate up more and more space, causing more and more damage but that her body lengthened, plunging further into the library. Because of the angle at which she had “entered” the library, by the unconventional new entrance, Nel lay cushioned by her huge chest, her face upon the cold floor; now, as she grew, her lengthening spire pushed Nel deeper into the library, pushing her huge face along the floor, knocking over bookshelves and driving drifts of papers and books before her. And, as she gritted her teeth in pain, occasionally snatching deep breaths or sharp gasps and yelps, Nel in turn occasionally swallowed more books, spluttering as she did so. It was not long before Nel had grow so much that her shoulders were straining against the inner walls and her head was piling up uncomfortably against the rear wall, her neck bent at an awkward angle, as she continued to grow, her body bent, twisting and crumpling up inside the library like a carpet gathered into bundles by careless feet. By this time, of course, the discomfort and pain had taken on a slightly different tenor and the muffled gasps and yelps that echoes out onto the courtyard were now mixed with those of pleasure, a rare, self-centred pleasure that one derives from find oneself improving, becoming larger, more beautiful still.

While this was not quite appreciable from the Mage’s spire, what was not immediately obvious to Nel, so squashed was she in the confines of the library, was the other changes being wrought on her body during all this. The Archmage, however, was able to see these particular changes. As those long legs stretched and the meaty buttocks swelled, the Archmage saw the bales of white flesh begin to change in colour, as if a cloud were passing over the face of the moon, or oil were darkening the waters of a lake. This began in patches across the giant pixie’s skin, patches here and there on her calves and thighs, a large patch on her left buttock, but some these quickly grew as if the soft, fragrant flesh were being eaten away, leaving her skin mottled with a dusky turquoise, such as you might see in the clouds in the night sky. These grew until the pixie’s body was adorned with large patches of this colouring, collaged with those of her pale white flesh, which seemed to have grown more pearly by contrast, so much so that her left leg and buttocks were all but covered by this colouration, as if it were slicked with a clinging, tarry film or she had grown a second skin, while the great trunk of the right leg and a slice of the right ass-cheek were for the most part the ivory white flesh of before, save for some dark mottling. These patches of dark colouration even seemed, the Archmage could see, to fulminate and ripple like stormclouds on the giant pixie’s very skin. Another change came soon thereafter, aside from the eruption of the mysterious patches of dark turquoise, hither and thither, heedless of new skin or old, there broke out lines and traceries of vibrant sea-green runes, which would intermittently flare up and recede, only to refulge again, seeming to incise themselves in fiery, green-blue lines and filigrees upon her powerful legs or upon her huge ass. These runes, thin and delicate to the eye, at first glance looked like the giant pixie’s veins expanding in a pulsing network beneath the surface of the skin, and indeed seemed to slip and shift beneath her almost translucent, white skin like jellyfish floating and drifting just below the surface of the sea. As she continued to grow, some of these lines seemed to knit together and encircle the huge fleshy limbs in rings of sea-green, where the now glowed strongly, while others continued to pulse, float and fade across the giant pixie.

https://ak6.picdn.net/shutterstock/video...


By the time most of these changes had taken place, and really it had only taken several minutes for all this to elapse, so violent and sudden a reaction was taking place, Nel had already grown substantially larger and it was with a look of horror that the Archmage had to watch the library wall, increasingly overburdened by the swelling cheeks and hips, which now bulged out absurdly from the hole through which the pixie’s upper half had entered, as if a hot air balloon were being prepared for flight inside, as it began to buckle and sag. Even as he watched, the great bulk of the young lady’s hips and buttocks drooped more and more from the library, like a huge pear ripening and fattening, drawing closer to the ground as the giant, tree-trunk legs bent at the knee, spanning the courtyard, and the hole in the library’s edifice was made wider still of flaring hips and a growing waist-line! Not long had to then elapse before the giant girl’s haunches met the stones as the wall gave way beneath her, leaving her torso, head and arms for the most part still inside, as if stuck in a rabbit’s burrow. At this same time, the terrible growth spurt and transformation she had undergone tapered off and abated. The dust had not had the chance to settle when the Archmage saw the huge haunches he had just watched grow more huge brace themselves as the giant pixie prepared to extricate herself from the library. Gradually, and in clouds of crumbling masonry and dust, the giant blue-haired pixie withdrew herself from the library, revealing by degrees the great column of her spine, which had also become covered with that murky colouration and traced over by the runes, her great, wide shoulders as they took with them a greater portion of the library’s facade, in no small part because the tremendous bulk and volume of her breasts would simply not have allowed her otherwise as they too emerged from the library, half-cleaved like double moons by dark-turquoise and creamy white, and finally the great monument of blue hair crowning it all.

Except, no, not blue. It was at this point, in case it was ever doubted, that the Archmage realised the extent of the young lady’s transformation, beyond gaining more prodigious size, for her hair, beforehand a royal blue, had grown like molten rock, flowing like lava around her huge face! The Archmage was dumbfounded at the effect the mage had taken on the young girl as she drew herself up and up and UP, rising on her immense legs to now tower over the spire, which now, where previously it had risen above her head, now could only graze her hipline or maybe her navel. From the balcony the Archmage could see the giant pixie dusting off her transformed body and inspecting her limbs and curves with a mixture of shock and curiosity. It was not long before a wide smile broke out across her face and her gaze shifted from her arm down the Mage’s spire. “OH!” Nel boomed, with an air of delight and amusement, “You’re in trouble NOW!”

1152121211212112221111212112.content:
They returned for the palace after a long journey. Kassandra had appointed Nel and Clare to positions as personal servants at the court - as much a protective measure as a gesture of reconciliation. After all Clare and Nel had wreaked havoc as giantesses and Kassandra was pretty sure, there were quite a lot of pixies filled by spirit of vindictiveness, who wouldn't accept their readmission into the citizenship of the pixie kingdom and demand a gruesome punishment. They might felt betrayed by Kassandra's benevolence and feel prompted to take 'justice' into their own hands. Nel and Clare had been awfully quite during the journey, both didn't speak about it, but the loss of their towering size was actually more bothering them than they liked to admit. Despite the damage they had caused, the loss of the feeling of pure unadulterated growth combined with indescribable pleasure and the fulfilment of all their sexual urges weighted heavy on their hearts. They were unarguably still tall for pixies, their bodies drop-dead gorgeous, but they were pixies again, no longer titans, who dwarfed even mountain ridges. Kassandra heard their soft moans, when they comforted each other in the nights, their libido still increased far beyond normal measure. Not willing to waste time, Kassandra sent out her most elite guards under the command of the legendary heroine Athenia, to retrieve the remains of the portions from the ruins of Clare’s former homestead. Obeying without questions, they fulfilled the mission and the potions were locked in the deepest vaults of the castle.

Two months later

Clare sighed deeply and continued to clean the room. It has been a hard day so far and she longed for the end of the day, when she finally would fell asleep in Nel’s gentle embrace, the abundance of their naked, ample bosoms pressed against each other, their nakedness only covered by one of the velvet palace blankets. While the feeling of nausea and vertigo, which had plagued both of them after shrinking back to pixie size had finally abated, their libido was more active than ever. Occasionally they even met in secrecy during their shifts to make love, unable to constrain themselves any longer.

11521212112121122211112121121.content:
Silently taunting Clare cleared the personal arms displayed on the side wall of the throne room. One of the servants had considered himself witty and funny and had replaced her maiden outfit by a distinctively smaller one. Not the first time one of the other servants granted her this kind of unwanted attention. Some were very kind to Nel and her, others openly despised them and only hold back because she wouldn’t disobey one of Kassandra’s royal decrees. Unwilling to risk the major-domo’s wrath, he was obsessed with timeliness, Clare had abolished the thought of getting a new one and chosen punctuality above modesty. Her outfit revealed far more skin than it was prudent. She pretended being unaware, that her top, though still valiantly wrapped around her generous curves, left absolutely nothing to the imagination. Her skirt was so tight that it made it look as if her butt was covered not by fabric, but by a layer of black, glossy paint; barely long enough to cover up the swell of her ass, it revealed her endless long, exquisitely toned and shapely legs in all their glory. The lining was so tight, it knitted her panty to something more akin to a thong, which buried deep in her crotch and wasn’t exactly helpful for someone, who was desperately trying suppress an overly active libido. Luckily today most of her tasks had been connected to work in rather less frequented rooms and even the throne room was deserted at the moment. Clenching her teeth, Clare swore vengeance to anonymous prankster. She was quite sure she could hear an occasional giggle and aroused deep breaths in the distance and behind the walls were the servants’ passages were hidden. They shouldn’t overdo it. By now Nel and Clare had discovered that they not only were extraordinarily beautiful and tall, additionally they were a lot stronger than they looked, even as fit and toned as they were. A fact that made Kassandra thinking about transferring them to the royal guard, after the public wrath had calmed down a bit. Approaching one of the hidden entries, she listened attentively, catching one of the voyeurs and beating him up, would sent a message – but more likely only get Clare in trouble, when her tormentors would frame her wrong evidence. Instead of hushed whisper she actually heard booming steps in front of the main entrance, approaching the room. Twice as motivated as usual, after all Clare sincerely wanted to repay Kassandra for her generosity by fulfilling her duties accurate and diligently, Clare backed into the passage. Servants had to be invisible in the official rooms, especially when their wardrobe was rather inappropriate. The massive, heavily ornamented, wooden door of the throne room flung open, split-seconds after she had closed the door. Almost holding her breath, she peered through a hidden spyhole.
Three pixies entered the room, among them the only two pixies taller than Clare and Nel throughout the kingdom: Kassandra and step-sister Brenna, nicknamed the raven, because of her straight black hair, cascading down her back, its hair-ends even covering most of the generous swell of her perfect butt. Only surpassed by her step-sister Kassandra in height, Brenna measured two-foot-seven, with a body to shame any but the most beautiful and sculpted of pixies. The princess was so attractive that it made ones knees rubbery just to glance at her, her beauty further emphasized by her impressive size. Her angular, delicate and almost best described as angelic face, usually displayed a dismissive smirk, while the colour of her large eyes matched her hair. It was such a dark brown, her iris almost seemed to be black like her pupils. Brenna radiated a certain unique exoticness, through the combination of almost impenetrable darkness and brilliant brightness. emphasised her rather dark appearance, the pixie princess’ appearance was defined by the combination of this contrast. While her hair and eyes were dark, Brenna’s skin was pale, its colour was something reminiscent of finest marble. Typically, she wore elegant long black dresses, that emphasised this contrast even more and showed of her breath-taking body, with perfect hour-glass curves. Clare couldn’t help but staring at the creamy white abundance of Brenna’s colossal tear-drop breasts, straining the corsage of the princess’ dress, swaying gently with each of her gracious steps. Brenna’s beauty was flawless, suitors for her hand arrived from all pixie kingdoms around the world, just to be rejected. But actually some of them were relived, when they left the court. While there was no flaw in her looks, the princess had a rather ‘special’ character. Brenna was charismatic, stunningly intelligent and smart witted. But all her good qualities gave her one hell of an inflated ego. Short tempered, dominant and sometimes distinctively cold-hearted she made sure only few people at court searched for her company. Most pixies in the kingdom were quite relieved that Kassandra was the legal heiress of the throne. A point of view, Brenna definitely didn’t share. Glad that most underlings and nobles avoided her presence, she caused some rumours by building an own palace guard, some members with a shady reputation. Like the brutish pixie walking next to her.
Rulana was extremely musclebound for a pixie, the proportions of her bulging body almost passed beyond 'ideal' and into the realm of 'impossible.', making her the most massive muscled pixie in history. Lack of discipline and respect and several charges concerning corruption and pub-brawls had earned her the dismissal from the palace guard. She had disobeyed superiors and skipped every drill, stating she was the strongest pixie around in no need for orders from wimps and useless exercises. To her own shame Athenia had beaten her in a following duel, easily compensating Rulana’s greater strength wit speed, skill and determination. Bruised and shamed, Rulana had yielded. Only days later Brenna had appointed her to the position of her first bodyguard, much to the dismay of the court advisors and the queen herself. Rumours spread the princess and her hulking guard were sharing the bed at night, but no one dared to accuse them openly.

“You know I’m right, sister! Why don’t you stop denying it!”, Brenna said coldly.

There was no trace of the usual warmth in Kassandra’s voice, when she answered. “I’m sick and tired of discussing it – over and over and over again! The remains of potions are too dangerous to be researched by our alchemist! They shall be kept under lock!”

Brenna stepped forward, her face only inches from her sisters’: “Your ignorance will cost us dearly! You see danger, I see opportunity!
