Another bolt of livid magic soared towards the giant pixie’s bulging bosom where it seemed only to fizzle out and burst. In frustration the captain, a towering amazon of a pixie, aimed and leveled a bolt up at the growing pixie’s darkened face and let fly. Clare, seeing the bluish streak of magic making towards her, eased her laughter enough to let her open her mouth and, with remarkable deftness, catch the bolt in her mouth with a gulp. Clare’s laughing stopped, licking her lips, before a momentary pause that was soon broken by an unladylike belch, which rumbled both her frame and the foundations of the vault, that was plainly, thought the young alchemist, the result of the violent magical reactions taking place inside the growing pixie, a theory only supported by the little storm cloud that blew out from the giant pixie’s mouth as her belly rumbled and which rained down onto the vault floor, with little sparks of lightning. Worse still, far from the intended outcome, the burp seemed to buoy the giant pixie that little bit larger so that by the time her disgorge had ended the Vault had begun to crack and chips of masonry had begun to fall.

The young alchemist looked at the scene with a mixture of horror and, much as she would hate to admit it, interest, and, stirring strangely in her mind, the odd twinges of titillation. What was taking place in the Vault and inside the growing pixie was actually quite remarkable and from a purely alchemical point of view. What she found most astonishing was how the growing pixie metabolised the various unpredictable reactions taking place inside her, which realistically could, at any moment, overwhelm her with their fissuring energies and threaten to burst her colossal body apart. In the dark of the vault the tracery of veins in her colossal bosom seemed to glow occasionally sea-green, lending her monstrous chest the fleeting impression of translucence.

The consumption of those gallons of distilled magic had caused her body to soak up magic like a sponge or, at the same time, to simply repel or negate it as it metabolised the unstable concoction in her belly; at this point the was forced to duck slightly as another spell bounced off the colossal pixie and scorched the wall behind her. It seemed that, at least for the moment, the growing pixie was next to invincible, that spells and magic at best did not graze her and at worst made her bigger. Her comparative immunity to magic was extraordinary, the way she nonchalantly, with pursed lips or an amused smile, brushed off whatever the guards could throw at her. The young alchemist felt a cold prickle on her skin and she realised that the giant pixie was, the bigger and stronger she became, and by now she had crouched down altogether in the Vault, the more she communicated to the air of the Vault an atmosphere of unstable magic that was sticky and static and easily confused with the heat of her huge body. The tawny-haired giant’s wanton guzzling had now transformed her into a towering, unstable caryatid that, because of the brewing alchemical reactions in her stomach, engendered the very air around her with their instability and unpredictability. Although the growing pixie was at the mercy of these volatile energies inside her, of which she was likely fully aware and yet slightly maddened by them at the same time, it was possible, thought the young alchemist, that this was only the beginning of the transformation that would be brought to bear on her by the caprices of her well of ingested magic. Whatever the magics she had consumed, after most of the swamp of reactants had dispersed themselves into her bloodstream and body, would likely coalesce and crystallise, concentrating in the huge pool of her stomach, at some later time and wreak further changes on the giant pixie’s body. Right now, the young alchemist thought, the tawny girl was metamorphing not unlike a silkworm, which, between emergence from the egg and entrance to the cocoon, the last, and most radical, metamorphosis, will gorge itself on mulberry leaves and grow and grow, eating and growing until it has increased its weight by over ten thousand times. Somewhere in the mire of confused and unstable magic inside the giant pixie’s body, beneath the outward appearances of extreme growth, something inside her was beginning to grow and well up and change: so that, as the tawny-haired pixie was becoming bigger and stronger and her magics were becoming stronger and more unpredictable, one got the sense she was becoming something more. Judging the the still crumbling ceiling and the rumbles of the tawny giant’s body as she picked up and crunched on a wooden cabinet of potions and elixirs, her process of gorging and growing was far from done.

The alchemist’s apprentice clutched at a torch bracket as the expanding girl sat, bringing her huge buttocks down on the cold stone flags with a boom; her knees now scraping the lower gloom of the ceiling and her head still ploughing its way into the vaulted ceiling. It was as if she wanted to prolong the experience of filling up the Vault as long as she could, the sensation of consuming, greedily, more and more space with her body; eking out the fear of her mounting flesh in the inhabitants; letting her excitement at her imminent eclosion from the Vault well up in her heart and stomach and brim over. Slowing, while regarding her billowing self, she began her deep, sonorous laughing again, but amplified again by her having swelled. Just as she began to contemplate what might become of the giant pixie, or rather what she might become, or what she was becoming, the alchemist girl saw a guard, who was bravely contending with the ballooning, squashed roundness of the tawny pixie’s left buttock, suddenly burst in a shower of sea-green sparks. Craning to see, she could at first make out nothing, but soon saw, scuttling about under a helmet, a fat, little chicken. She realised with a quiver of horror that the giant pixie had begun to affect the air and background magic around her to such an extent that those her proximity in could be affected by them, whatever she happened to be giving off. As she finished this thought another guard was rendered into a cloud of bubbles. As the other guards back away and began to filter out of the room, the alchemist’s apprentice saw this as an opportune time to make her exit. She slipped through the service door, rather than the main door, which the growing colossus had all but occluded by now with her monster buttocks, or the back door, which was the only option remaining for the royal guards. As she pulled the heavy, black wooden door shut, acutely aware of the tremors being sent through all the vault by that voluptuous behemoth and her continuing swelling, her last glimpse of the fast-being-swallowed scene was of a monstrous, wobbling crag of breast-flesh, like a bulbous and inverted loveheart, and of huge, brilliant sea-green eyes.

Clare, still kind of rapturous and euphoric, realised that it would not be long before she filled up the Vault. She had enjoyed the little pangs of magic and the jags from the guards’ magic and weapons; still sort of fogged up with the sensation of growing, and the lust for more, she had not really properly registered the ‘attack’. She did not really mind; she found it rather cute. Even she did not know how powerful she had become until then; the fact she now felt increasingly, as she grew bigger and stronger, like a goddess was something she had hitherto only suspected. But now, as her shoulders broadened and her neck and head cricked against the spider-webbed ceiling; her ever-swelling bosom made in still more difficult to breath and her still growing limbs made it harder to move, she saw the little mages and guards retreating. She smiled wickedly and boomed out - OH DEAR, YOU WOULDN’T LEAVE LITTLE ME HERE BY MYSELF WOULD YOU? With this she reached out through the now crumbling and falling masonry and caught up two guards in one hand, like toy-soldiers. She brought them up to her sea-green eyes and was amazed how the could be seen by the glow from her eyes. To her astonishment, even as she held him, one mage was reduced, in a puff of sparks, to a cloud of butterflies; Clare blinked and giggled even as her head started to crack through above. DON’T WORRY, Clare squeezed the toy-mage and parted her wettened lips suggestively, I JUST NEED A LITTLE BIT OF ‘HELP’ TO GET THROUGH THIS. She put him to her lips with two fingers, kissed his toylike form and, with all the grace and joy of eating an over ripe strawberry, sucked him into her mouth.

Only moments later, Clare grew through the roof of the Vault; her still-swelling body, coiled up inside tight as a djinn inside, shook the plates and specks of masonry from her as she emerged upwards into the frosty morning light. Her great tawny head rose and swayed through the mists as she rose to stand silhouetted in the pale sky; her immense high bosom, with clay-piped nipples, was soon wet from the mist.

11521212112121122211112122212111111.content:
The castle’s groundskeeper was strolling in the balmy air, under the humid flowers of the trees overhanging the path. There seemed, at least to him, to be something oppressive in the air of the garden, something strange and sticky about it, rather than simply the cloying smell of the pollen. As evening bells came from the palace cathedral, he was regarding the dark castle when he became conscious of a trembling in the ground. The stones of the path seemed to jitter faintly by his boots. Frowning, he squinted in the gloom of the garden, up through the branches of the trees, at the roof of the palace vaults, which seemed to heave. His jaw dropped as masonry of the roof crumbled and, from the plumes of dust, there rose something huge. At first it seemed like a great quantity of boiled milk billowing up in a colossal balloon or egg before bursting upwards, but, as he ran closer, down the garden path, until his view was no longer obscured by the veil of the trees, for an instant the form seemed more like a huge tower or lighthouse, the smooth and off-white as ivory, whose coiled spiral staircases and floors were rising up from the Vault. But no sooner had this impression lodged than the tower twisted, now seeming less like a violent and grand chemical reaction or architectural structure, but instead, in the way it seemed to twist and unfurl, more organic, at one moment like a colossal, for the thing was still rising, beanstalk, the next like a pillar of cloud, perhaps the most enduring of his impressions was, rather, like an immense column of candlewax plied by a flame, twisting and expanding.

As he made his way beyond the fringe of the trees, he beheld the form risen from the vault, and now towering over the palatial gardens, casting a huge shadow that stretched beyond the walls, as the shadowy body, though it seemed hard to believe,of a colossal pixie. Looking up, he could not see, in the evening haze, the pixie’s face which was curtained by shadows and immense coils of tawny hair. He could, however, see her eyes glowing sea-green. Her wings, beforehand cramped and pinioned by the confines of the vault, now unfolded and stretched out and up behind the colossal pixie. The gardener watched, dumbstruck, as the colossal pixie stretched her up long arms into the sky like the pinnacles of the castle out of which she had grown and tilted the tawny magnificence of her head, bits of masonry still falling from her body. The air seemed to tingle about him. A bird, crossing the sky after being disturbed by the pixie’s eruption, collided with the tangle of hair and fell to earth as a potted plant.

As the colossal pixie brought up a giant leg to step out from the vault, the gardener saw the great thickness of her thighs, but ran. As he ran across the lawn, he glanced back, seeing the trunks of the colossal pixie’s legs rising and planting as she strode towards the walls of the grounds, towering over all before her. He was thrown forward by the shock of her foot coming down on the lawn. Scrambling to his feet, he ran for the trees, his hands aching from the fall, and, as he ran, he caught, out of the corner of his eye, a glance at an tree crumpling and splintering beneath another such foot. Reaching the trees, the gardener looked up and saw above him the huge gusset of the giant pixie as she straddled forwards, her foot landing some way off in the copse of trees. He stood panting in horror as he heard the colossal pixie made her way from the palatial gardens, casting her shadow on the world.

*

Later the same evening, in the pixie town that lay in the valley down from the Palace grounds, the townspeople were conscious of a thundering coming from the forest. Nina Skyborn, a flowergirl, skirted around a puddle when a tremor sent ripples through the water lying on the cobbles. She looked up from the cobbled streets and saw a cloud of bats, roused from among the trees, cross above the rooftops of the town. Nina and her basket of flowers were sent sprawling on the wet cobblestones by another quake, much closer than before. As she lay in the street, she was conscious of the orange light of the evening darkening as the shadow of something passed over her. Twisting to look up, Nina saw the form of something huge, almost too large and close to properly distinguish, bearing down on the town’s library. Within moments the monster had torn the slated roof from the library. Nina scooped up her basket and as many bruised flowers as she could before fleeing. Looking back, she saw the colossus seeming to cram handfuls of splintered bookcases and spellbooks into its mouth. As Nina fled she was conscious of a strange rumbling that seemed to bubble and spread from the monster, through the ground beneath Nina’s feet.

*

Some miles off, John Husker, a farmer whose livelihood was the cultivation of root vegetables, turnips or carrots, in magically rich soil, causing said vegetables to swell to enormous size, and his wife were shaken awake in the night by the booms of what they thought was thunder. The thunderous sound was so strong it shook the foundations of their farmhouse. Edith sat up after a particularly violent boom. From outside they heard a tremendous crunching, which culminated in what sounded like a belch. When John ventured outside to investigate he was surprised, to say the least, that there was neither wind, nor rain, and, looking up, he saw a clear blanket of stars. However, he was shock to see that his crops had been uprooted, a job which ordinarily too a team of men, and had disappeared altogether. As John approached the smashed fence he looked about him and realised that he had entered into the bowl of a oblong crater, so freshly made that water from the soil was only now beginning to pool therein. John, still horrified by the loss of his crop, but not quite able to process it, thought, in the darkness, the shallow, long crater resembled a footprint. From behind the barn there came another thunder-like eruption, followed soon after by the gurgling, bubbling sound. He turned to see the shadow of something ballooning up behind his barn, rising higher into the night sky. The moonlight threw the monster’s shadow further and further across the ground. John flung himself flat in the soft mud of the creature’s footprint as the green-eyed colossus straddled his barn and strode forward, one enormous foot dragging and crashing through the barn itself.

*

For miles around you could see the lights from the Nightglow mines high up on the mountain, as the toiled through the night, when the magic-rich ore inside would glow blue. The workers were traumatised, when, around midnight, the mouth of the mine was suddenly blocked and illuminated by something eerie green. No sooner had this disappeared than what appeared to be a huge, white wyrm thrust itself down the passage: first grabbing a laden orecart and dragging it into the night, where the miners could hear grinding and crunching noises, before plunging back in again, thick and round, and snatching a miner, then another, then a clump of ore, another mine cart, a chunk of the wall - all of the dragged back into the mountain air. As the huge serpent thrust in again and seized sizeable chunk of ore, it paused. Old Hans then realised that the white dragon raiding the mine was, unbelievably, an arm, the arm of, presumably, some even larger creature! Suddenly a rumbling began that shook the mine and the snowy flesh of this huge arm began to swell, to grow longer, down the tunnel, after the fleeing miners and to expanding, filling up the space in the mine, shaking the struts and buttresses. Old Hans pressed against the wall and prayed for the nightmare to end.

*

In the early hours of the morning, Dan Fothergill rose early and rowed out in his little shallop onto the glassy surface of the Mala lake, home to rare catfish, unique for having swum in those magic-soaked waters and sifted its magical mud and had therefore attained not only unusual size compared to that of the lake, but, it was, said that eating these catfish granted wishes.These fish fetched a fairly generous price at market. Mist hung over the lake and the woods and all Dan could see was the amber lantern dangling from the end of his boat. He had thought he heard thunder before setting off, but assumed now that it had come from somewhere in the valley over the mountain. Dan was more tired than usual for having had several unsuccessful trips this week. He lazily watched his float bob in the milky waters for some time, he did not know how long, until he became conscious of something rather strange. As he sat angling his little boat had been born gentle backwards, drawn along as if by a current. He did not understand why; no wind stirred the lake or the mist swirling about him. What trees he could see seemed to be climbing upwards. A warm, and oddly strong, breeze dispersed some of the mist and Dan was appalled to realise that, in fact, the water level was sinking! He could actually see several to the lake’s catfish breaching from suddenly shallower waters! Dan turned to see, as he was drawn along, the shadow of the head of some colossal beast looming from the mist, its head inclined to the lake’s waters to slake its gargantuan thirst. Dan grabbed his oars and rowed furiously against the draw of the leviathan’s mouth. For some minutes he struggled against it before, its thirst apparently slaked, and the lake reduced to a meer puddle with great bloated catfish leaping in the dregs, the leviathan raised its head. Dan sat in his immobilised boat and watched as the creature rose up on two giant legs, brushing trees aside as it did so. Its breath no longer blew the mists away and, as it towered up, there came from amidst the mists swallowing up the form of the colossus, a crackling, gurgling, rumbling, and throbbing sound, like thunder brewing and growing in the clouds.

The sun seeped over the crags of the mountains and gushed down into the valley, lighting up the morning mists. The Imperial Guards looked down onto the valley where, only the night before, a young pixie, who had burst from the Palace vaults, had unleashed herself on the unsuspecting, sleepy residents of the valley. The guards had just come from inspecting one of the magic-ore mines across these mountains where this oversized pixie was supposed to have ransacked and plundered the place. They had interviewed one old miner, a dwarf, who shook so violently he could scarcely form coherent sentences, as if his jittering shook apart his sentences. His account, broken though it was, and even though he could only see an eye, an arm, or a huge pair of lips, put her at anywhere between a fifty and a hundred feet tall. This was weird, thought the Captain, as she breathed the cold mountain air. An account from the town at the foot of the Palace can’t have had this girl at much between ten and twenty foot tall. But another account, this time from a farm some way out of the village, said the pixie had been large enough to have straddled his barn and strewn it across the farmyard when its foot went through it. The barn, according to the captain, must have been maybe 8 feet in height. And, as a guardsman had pointed out, you could see where this girl had climbed the mountainside from the dislodged boulders and scree, and whatever she had raked from the mine shaft that had, so they were led to believe, not made it into her gaping mouth. He was correct in observing this and in the opinion that she must have been some size to scale that rockface. For some hours they traversed the jagged spine of the mountains searching for the girl, but to no avail. On the ridges of the one Valley the took a rest, for the mist seemed to have become more widespread and thicker, seeming to curl its way up the mountainside.The Captain bit into a grape as she ran her fingers over the unfurled map of the Valleys. She judged, from the escarpment, just visible over the sea of fog, projecting upwards like a claw, that they must have crossed over towards the Frir Valley, a region of vast, misty, wetlands and swamps, below the slopes of the mountains. It was inhabited mostly by strange elemental waterlife, such as bog nymphs, mandrakes, or frog-people. The only really civilised race to establish footholds there were Goblins, living in little Potemkin industrial villages out on the marshes. The Captain was less than keen to venture down into the mires to look for her fugitive.

Some time passed, during which the Captain leaned against a stone, and watched the way the distant cascade fell from the sunlit uplands down into the mists of the valley. Suddenly, there came a rumbling through the ground, like a quake, and a sound like thunder. The guards were shaken from their feet and one had to beat his wings furiously to recover from falling off the precipice. The Captain threw out her hand and pulled him back with a jerk. Scarcely had this quake faded then another came and another. It felt as if the earth itself were breathing, in long and deep drones, the Captain half expected to see the twin pinnacles of the of mountainsides heaving up and down like great, craggy breasts. Instead, the mountains only shook with the quaking, which seemed to emanate from somewhere in the divide of the Valley. The Captain teetered towards the brink, pebbles being shaken off about her, and looked intently. Through perhaps a slight thinning of the veil of mist she could make out the faintest, shadowy forms. Take an eyeglass from her satchel, she steadied herself and looked towards a spot in the mist, then another, then another, trying to locate as best she could where the quaking was coming from. Fixing on a spot, she adjusted the focus, Here, through the round lens, she saw that with the rumble of every quake the mist seemed to stir, to fold in on itself and then, after the rumbling had faded, to bluster and billow.

The Captain watched the spot of mist, near where the waterfall plummeted down, intently for some time. Then, as if emerging from a dream, the mists thinned and she could distinguish, though only faintly, an immense pair of red lips. The Captain lowered her eyeglass and stood for a moment. With a finger she faintly traced what she thought to be the contours of the girl down the huge tract of obscured valley, along the romantic chasm. “Boys”, she said, “I think we found our girl”.

As the giant pixie snored, whether from the wind, from their gradual dispersing along the valley, or from her swallowing up the mists as she slept, she emerged gradually from the shifting mists like some enormous ocean steamer or castle by the sea. Her breath blew across the valley, drawing in the sea of fog, and then chasing them down towards the mouth of the valley. It soon became apparent, as the fugitive girl's shadowy form emerged from the fog, that the Captain’s tracing of her outline, softly sleeping propped out but the fringe of the mountains, like some enormous porcelain doll, had been a conservative one. The girl's body was so large that the Captain and her fellow guardsman could not distinguish all of her at once, she had become so large that as she lay draped over the landscape her body was abbreviated by clouds of mist. Instead, they could see the dark forms of her outline and limbs occasionally emerging from gaps in the mist. For it transpired that the girl lay recumbent, her body rolling up the mountainside, the waterfall breaking upon her shoulder, her arm lying embedded in the thick forests that covered the mountainsides. Her monstrous hipline and buttocks swallowed up the wide wedge of the valley, where it funneled into the mountains, and was visibly bulging from pressing up against the mountainside. The Captain could not distinguish one leg as it stretch away into the mouth of the valley, but one of her splayed legs travelled up and lay hooked over the mountainside. They must have, thought the Captain, wandered past her leg in the mist, which was frankly astonishing for now, following the giant pixie's leg up over the outcrop, she could see its dark form towering up above them like a cliffside. Most astounding of all, as became clear was how tremendous the girl’s bust had become. Though the girl’s body was engorged, from her tree-studded arms to her mountain-crushing buttocks, her chest had grown monstrously huge. As the sleeping form giant pixie slowly became clear they could see them, for they maybe would have merited a valley of their own, swollen up into huge domes, swelling out from her sleeping body. Though she could not properly take stock of the sheer scale of the girl stretched out across the crease of the valley, the Captain wondered how the girl would be able to stand up. They heaved and fell as she breathed, trembling and wobbling in the fog, like vast iceflows or lakes of milk. Crowning each huge breasts was colossal nipple, starting erect from the mists, like twin pinnacles of jasper amongst the roiling fog. Contrary to what the Captain had traced in the air, the shadowy form of the girl, their fugitive, filled the valley. In contrast to the accounts provided from the pixie kingdoms, which put the girl at an undoubtedly formidable size, the the murky outline of her body suggested that since entering the swampy landscape and descending into the sea of fog in the basin of the Frir Valley the fugitive had only grown and grown and grown, becoming larger and more voluptuous, until she had reached a size utterly unthinkable for a pixie.

As the sun filtered down into the valley, through the mists, the giant pixie’s body crackled with lights from the fields of dew covering her body...

Clare looked down at the valley below her, where the morning sun illuminated the surface of great lakes of milk, still lying in pools amongst the trees and the rocks, like puddles lay in the street after a rain shower had passed. Clare, from her enormous height, watched as the gleaming pools, which seemed, in the soft light cast upon them, to spark and crackle with sea-green, gradually dispersed themselves, spreading out in rivulets, like veins or some liquid nervous system, or simply seeping into the ground, drunk up by the thirsty roots and vegetation. Clare shaded her eyes; she could see, beyond the mouth of the valley itself, the rivers of milk snaking through the swamps and the forests; she must have, she thought, expressed such a torrent that she had all but flooded the whole basin.

http://www.zastavki.com/pictures/origina...

Clare glanced from the miniature world at her feet to her vastly diminished chest and found no surprise, ultimately, in having flooded the valley; her chest had managed to grow to almost the same size as the rest of her body before the pressure had been relieved. Clare turned her attentions back to the drenched landscape before her. She smiled to see the glitter of the trees in the rays of light passing through the clouds, dusted with milk like morning dew. Clare slowly passed her hand through one of the columns of sunlight that came down from a breaks in the clouds; in a way she was thrilled by this and felt a flutter in her chest at the possibility of absentmindedly brushing through towers of sunlight and, furthermore, given additional cause for elation by the fact that she was now almost on the same scale as these rays of sun. Clare cast her gaze up and down the length of the beam of sunlight and her own body and could not help but smile at their comparable sizes; that she, whom only hours ago had been scarcely larger than a small shrub, could now be measured only using the weather and landscapes. Clare could not help but let for a irruptive giggle of laughter at her own size compared to the column of sunlight.

https://aprilemillo.files.wordpress.com/...

For a moment Clare looked up at the parting of the grey clouds and tentatively reached up towards them, imagining that she could feel the tips of her fingers brush the soft canopy. It gave her chills to think that she could be considered as a form of natural disaster, like a tornado or an earthquake. Clare lowered her immense arm and looked at the curtain of golden light falling from the clouds and wondered how long it would be before her head was breaking upwards through the clouds, until she towered over the rays of light falling on the landscape, until landforms and weather systems could only be relied upon to describe her body parts, her calves, thighs, or chest. Clare found that, having become so glutted with magic and milk that she felt bloated and tender; her explosive release had served to even out the pressure pent up inside her and now she found herself rejuvenated and almost energetic by comparison. Now that the violent storm of magic in her belly had subsided, and its effects passed, at least for now, Clare found herself finally able to enjoy her newfound stature and the power it brought with it. Even now though, as he stretched and bent the great pillar of her body skywards, she felt, somewhere in the pit of her stomach, a twinge, as if she had dislodged something inside her belly. She suspected she knew this feeling though, the familiar quivering of the insatiable lust for magic that had brought her to this point. Though it was not so powerful right now, Clare knew that this feeling would only intensify as time wore on and that her massive body would begin to demand more and more strongly that she satisfy its need and hunger.

Clare looked about her, at the sodden landscape, and patted her stomach. It did not worry her as much as it would another, lesser, person that her thirst for magic might be unquenchable, that her body needed magic and was now dependent on it. She wondered what would happen if she didn’t consume magic. Would she shrink? Would she become more unstable? Would her hunger drive her mad? Clare’s growing awareness of her dependence on magic, therefore, worried her only a little for this was compounded by an inward thrill and curiosity to simply see what the fate held in store for her and her body. A shiver ran through Clare’s body when she thought of the ethereal fire in her gut, constantly burning, like some huge blast furnace in the heart of a volcanic mountain, endlessly requiring stoking and fueling, greedily consuming materials and smouldering eternally, to keep it burning and sending molten slag rushing through the flumes.

Clare was roused from her musings by a faint rumbling beneath her toes. Clare, perplexed and somewhat bemused, patted her body; she did not feel the usually tremors shaking through her body that betrayed one of her immense growth spurts. But, no, as she paused, her immense hands laid across her stomach, she was sure that the rumblings were not coming from her body and that she was not due another explosion of growth. But still the rumbling continued and, if anything, intensified and grew. Clare could see the mountains beginning to judder from the quaking. Clare thought for an instant that her activities, such as stomping around the landscape, the seismic force her growth spurts exerted or the various other acts of passion she had just engaged in, had triggered and actual earthquake. But again, Clare was not sure that was right. Clare looked at the ripples being sent through the pools of milk still left on the landscape, and watched as they drained away, and soaked into the ground. Clare looked for a while at the spot where the milk had soaked away, as if into a cake, for some time before, as the quaking intensified, it hit her. Clare bit her lip, her eyes wide, and thought: “Uh oh…”

Clare was suddenly conscious of the sea of trees at her feet sprouting up about her, growing taller and taller, their trunks thickening and their branches lengthening, made a louder and louder creaking and cracking as the grew taller, as if they were bending in high winds. Clare lurched backwards in colossal, booming footsteps, her arms flailing like the sails of some gigantic windmill, as a cluster of trees sprouted beneath her foot. Clare looked, with wild eyes, as another tree began to grow, and another. Some trees were almost half Clare’s height by now. Clare received a fright and started when she felt something, like a cold brush, grazing and tickling the cheeks of her buttocks and realise, when she turned around, that the top of one conifer was growing up behind her. As Clare moved as best she could to avoid all the sprouting trees, she examined the ground between them and saw the great roots thickening and churning up the ground, bursting out, in some cases, with their sheer girth and coiling up or winding their way up the mountainsides. She saw also the grasses and flowers between the roots proliferating and exploding into veritable jungles, grow, like the trees, taller and taller, swelling up like a great green, geyser. Clare wrapped her hand around a nearby tree and her eyes widened as it thickened and swelled in her hand until her fingers no longer met each other and, before long, could no long wrap around the trunk. She laughed at feeling the creaking and cracking as the tree grew and thickened.

http://www.150.parks.ca.gov/pages/150/im...

Clare shaded her eyes and looked out over the sea of growing trees and saw the landscape seeming to ripple and undulate, like the surface of the sea, as the plants and trees sprouted ever higher. Clare gasped as she saw the landscape heaving and growing before her eyes, marvelling that her milk, infused with all her volatile magics, had caused a chain reaction of gigantic and spontaneous growth. Although she kept having to dance from spot to spot to avoid being speared by the still growing trees below, it thrilled Clare that she had the power to change the ecosystem around her. She was, Clare thought, like a goddess of life and creation, towering over all creation. But, she thought, she was not born, like the gods who dwelt somewhere in the clouds, she had been created, a manmade, or rather womanmade, goddess— move over Mother Nature! And now, Clare smiled, dodging a growing oak that was thrusting upwards and poking into the tender flesh of her inner thigh, she had given her gift to the world: the gift of giant growth. The tallest of the trees were now at Clare’s elegant and massive shoulders and still growing, still shaking the ground violently. Clare continued to dream of her new role as the Goddess of Size, the Goddess of Big and of Small. Some gods and goddesses presuded over love, the marshes or cobblers, but she, Clare, was now to preside over size, conferring on things and people her gifts and blessings. Clare strolled along, running her massive hands through the treetops, as if through a field of wheat.

Minutes later the rumbling of the trees and plants had died away and Clare found herself among a newly grown forest of giant trees, many of which were a head or two higher than her. So, she thought, I am still a giant even in my new forest. The interlocking branches of the trees in the canopy shield the Valley from the sunlight and dappled the ground with spots of warm, yellow light. The smell of the trees exhilarated her and she could still hear the faintest crackings and tremblings from the trees about her. Clare stuck her finger in a patch of sap on the trunk of one of the titanic trees and rubbed it between her thumb and forefinger, smelling it delicately. Clare smiled and wondered what she ought to do, ought to do with her gifts and her newly created Arcadia...

1152121211212112221111212221211111111111.content:
Some time had passed since the transformations that took place in and around the Frir valley, north of the pixie kingdom. Once the valley had stretched out, enclosed by a chain of jagged, dark mountain peaks, whose spindled spires and blades of rock gave the impression sometimes of a collection of giant murex shells arranged across the skyline, and filled by a sea of fog. These mists, for which the region was partly named (Frir being a linguistic corruption of the name given it by its inhabitants, which, if the early pixie explorers are to believed, means “The fog-sea”), veiled the valley for its length and breadth, obscuring its environs from those standing in the mountains above.


https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/c...


It was for this reason that relatively little was known about the valley or its inhabitants, save for the accounts of a select few explorers. The gnomish mountain explorer and historian Cecil Fizzbottom wrote, in the diary he kept travelling in these regions, of the Frir valley that:


This valley lies far north of the Lowland kingdoms of the Pixies, to the east of the Dwarven Highland kingdoms, and is enclosed by mountains as jagged as they are tall, whose pinnacles resemble the mouth of some great creature. Scarcely anything is visible from the mountains above for their lingers in the valley a perennial fog, which obscures the innermost environs. By all accounts, the valley is densely wooded with sprawling quagmire across almost its entirety. The valley is only feasibly accessible at it’s northern border, where it tapers to a scar of marshland and willow trees and where the fog thins slightly. Even then, the descent is sheer and, as far as I can tell, all but unscalable on a return....



A later account of the valley, by the eminent, dwarven natural historian and cartographer Lord Gimsteinn was made following an expedition into the Valley lasting eleven months, descending the northern mountains described by Fizzbottom and exploring the Valley for another way out, eventually discovering a narrow gorge, all but invisible in the mist, on the south-eastern limits, which led, eventually to the dales and foothills to the southern dwarven kingdoms. Amongst his descriptions of the valley interior Gimsteinn’s journals contain several accounts of the flora and fauna of the valley. A general passage, early into the expedition, reads:


This valley is just fascinating. The wood goes on for miles and miles! The trees are all of a sort and are tall and dark, so tall in fact that they form a canopy. Between this blasted fog and the trees it’s real dark down here on the ground…. We have seen only some wildlife apart from insects, the usual swampy bugs like dragonflies, moths, beetles and spiders and such, but of kinds I have never seen. Large cats had had to be seen off with axes and shields and we tried to catch a large, flocculent and iridescent rabbit, but it vanished. I caught sight of a dryad yesterday, but she quickly disappeared, and what I thought were water nymphs by a rotting pool, but they were bedraggled and sour green, and quickly gone into the stinking mud. Buri claims he heard a fire drake or salamander somewhere in the swamp, but I haven’t seen anything of it. A few nights ago we camped by a clearing, which, come night, turned out to play home to a number of mandrakes! I have never seen these kinds though, or so many different kinds near each other! Needless to say, we had to scarper once they woke up! In the morning we will make our way further south.


In spite of these accounts, very little was known about the Frir valley except what has been related, a complete map of the valley does not exist, and likely, if the native inhabitants of large, blood-sucking and biting insects, bad-tempered nymphs and dryads, savage mandragoras and bloodthirsty animals have anything to do with it, never will.


*


Now, however, since Clare, newly transformed into a veritable goddess on earth, had made her way over those jagged heights, the any travellers to the valley would be met, suddenly, with gigantic trees, which towered high up into the sky, up above the cloudy range of the mountains, their canopy casting the landscape into greenish gloom. Looking down from the peaks, one now saw a vast and tangled expanse of roots, thick as the boulevards of a city, knotted and contorted in a dense labyrinth of passages and walkways. The valley’s constant fog now wound itself in and around the roots of these trees and sank well down into the valley. From on high, one felt they could discern, far down in the dark below, a greenish twilight, throbbing and glowing. Standing on the edge of this colossal forest, one was struck by the silence of it all, save for the creaking of the trees like minor quakes.


No-one could really have anticipated the events as they transpired: that Clare would become quite so hungry for size, that she would grow quite so much, that the magic would have quite such a radical effect on her metabolism and body, and that she could have such an extreme effect of her environment! In fact, Clare had not been seen since the transformation of the valley, her huge, bosomy figure being blocked out by the climbing trunks around her. It was thought, or so the scouts reported, that, as the trunks continued to grow to their now gigantic height, that Clare had headed deeper into the valley. They were sure, however, that she was still in there, a creature of her stature was not to be missed elsewhere in the land. But nobody had ventured into the labyrinth of roots, trunks and fog since and no-one had heard a whisper from the titanic pixie deep within...


That is, until months later…

A few moments passed by, during which Clare, standing enormous amongst a forest of newly-grown, towering trees, reflected on the whirlwind of thoughts and sensations associated with her situation now passing through her mind. To think that perhaps only a day ago (she had tended to lose track of time since) Clare had been confined to a dank and dreary cell by that little Empress, but was now enjoying the most incredible sense of freedom and expansiveness conferred on her by her newfound stature! What a lark it all was! Who would have thought that growing several-hundred feet would be so liberating! Clare smiled and breathed deeply, taking in the sweet, cool scent of the trees about her. Clare laid a long-fingered hand on the trunk of one of the trees, looking up to the branches fanning out above even her head, marvelling at their height. It was amazing to think, also, that her body had done this to the landscape, that all this potential had been stocked up inside her, like a mountain reservoir, and had been unleashed all of a sudden! Thinking on it, Clare’s heart almost skipped a beat to wonder about what, if she could so transform an entire landscape, her body was capable of? Perhaps, Clare reasoned, a more accurate question was: what WASN’T she capable of?

For a few moments more, thoughts crossed Clare’s mind, imagining herself striding across landscapes, straddling mountain ranges like meadow stiles, and reforming them as she saw fit. Clare imagined herself, lying on her side, one long arm resting upon her brow, the other propping up her huge body by her elbow and cradling one gigantic breast in her palm, and, with graceful ease, expressing a fine rain of turquoise milk down upon the parched and stony fields of some small town, like some colossal watering-can, and watching on as the ground rumbled and trembled before huge stalks of corn burst up from the ground, spindling taller and taller; vines of tomatoes erupted larger and larger, like boulders and turnips and carrots heaved the ground as they swelled up below the soil. Clare thought also, in a benevolent mood, of giving her “gift” to livestock, of making a herd of cows the size of elephants, of making a goat into more of a giraffe or even of a chicken the size of a barn! She wildly pictured an enormous goose as big as a church nesting in a town square. Imagine the eggs! World hunger eat your heart out! But why stop there?

Indeed, Clare mused, she could even confer her “blessing” on people if she so wished. If, say, a little gnome was having trouble with a big, bad ogre, Clare reasoned, it would be remiss of her not to give her a little “boost”; maybe an ogre would think twice about tangling with a gnome the size of a cliff-side. Clare amused herself as she thought: Girls, big bust a must? Have a couple of storeys too! Schlong not long enough boys? How about I add a few yards! Perhaps, Clare thought, upon reflection, she should only bestow “this” (here she hefted her huge bosom) on only her fellow pixies? Seemed like the best idea; make every pixie an amazon! Hmm, but where to stop? Bigger than a human for sure. No more wire cages or glass tanks for those pixies! Of course, the girls would be the biggest, Clare thought matter of factly, it wouldn’t make sense otherwise. Come to think of it, she’d probably make a few, her favourites, just a tad bigger, just a smidge. Maybe she ought to reward them? A little pang hit Clare’s heart as she imagined a busty and broad-hipped pixie, standing at almost twenty feet tall, but scarcely a thimble to Clare, standing on tiptoes to sup from her gigantic nipple; Clare felt herself becoming a little flushed as she imagined that little pixie greedily gulping down mouthful after sweet mouthful of her milk, and watching that little amazon start to swell up and grow right there in her hands, growing until Clare had to cradle her in her arms and practically prise the girl from her breast with gasp, for fear she might grow too large.

Clare breathed deeply, steadying herself against the trees. Of course, she continued to think, she’d have to make sure that this “little blessing” didn’t find its way to the wrong people. It worried Clare a little, as much as anything could worry someone her size, that she hadn’t been altogether in control of the little “outpouring” that had transformed the valley. It worried Clare to think that another such accident could have some less than ideal results. Clare’s skin crawled a bit as she imagined beetles the size of tanks rampaging down city streets, wasps like small aircraft hovering over rooftops, spiders like threshing machines scaling glass buildings. Clare reflected that she wouldn’t overly like to gush all over a forest only to accidentally turn a harmless little woodland newt into a dragon-sized menace. Furthermore, come to think of it, mountain giants, trolls and dragons, didn’t really need to be much bigger. Might be nice to get pounded on a mountain range though. No that’s idiotic. It concerned Clare even further that she might accidentally erupt all over some people who might be less than pleased with her at the moment. Massive and powerful though she was, probably bottom of Clare’s list of desires was to have Nel or the Empress, or one of their friends, grow big enough to challenge her; Clare could not help but picture herself standing before the Empress who was now a whole torso taller than her and, much to her chagrin, upon turning to escape, finding before her, rising upwards for miles, the creamy, warm edifice of the most enormous and gigantic bosom Clare could imagine, rising before Clare, filling the landscape in all directions, as a truly gargantuan Nel lay outstretched like a cat across the surface of the planet. No. Not ideal. Will have to find a bra to cover these monsters soon.

Clare began to stroll slowly through the trees, still thinking, her huge hips grazing the bark as she went. Yes. The only thing she could do to stop that happening would be to grow only some followers. Maybe grow herself a little army. Just to make sure neither Nel or anyone else pulled any strokes on their new Queen- no, Goddess! Because, really, Clare mused, that’s what she’d become, really there was no other way of describing it; it was just a statement of bald fact. Yes, grow some servants just a bit bigger than the rest, just to make sure. The Empress has her honour guards; no reason a Goddess shouldn’t have some too. Of course, she’d do all the rest too, all the lovely stuff she hoped for, maybe just to see if she could. Maybe she’d even “adjust” all the pixies’ sizes, but not Nel and the Empress, better that they remained “ungrown.” But that’s a thought, isn’t it, Clare mused, her own army of amazons, even giants! She could evangelise the world with a resource like that at her disposal!

*

Clare’s musings were interrupted as she worked her way through the maze of trees and undergrowth with some difficulty by the most terrible gurgling and growling from her stomach. Ughh, starving; must be all that growing! It occurred to Clare that hadn’t eaten all that much since she’d started her growing. Sure she’d gulped down a bunch of ore and a magic lake or two, and had probably swallowed a few bystanders in the process, but that was only so much fuel for a growing girl! It hadn’t really occurred to her until now how she might best sustain a body like this and her stomach involuntarily churned at the thought of sweet sugar rolls and butter, fresh from the oven, now only a granule of dust to her. But whar had reminded her of this. All the while she’d been in the forest she’d been catching hints of a smell, sweet and cool, from somewhere. Sniffing about her Clare realised that all along it had been the trees that she’d been smelling. Approach the nearest one she hunted about for the source. Upon inspection she found the smell on her fingers too; it had been the sap. Ah, that’s it. Being well-disposed to drinking dew-drops and cups of flower nectar, like all pixies, Clare dabbed a sticky patch on a nearby tree and gave her finger a suck, mulling over the taste. Her countenance brightened for the sticky, greenish sap was simply delicious! Should bottle this! Licking her finger again, Clare dabbed at the patch again and stuck her fingers in her mouth. Her stomach gurgled again as Clare abandoned all pretenses and licked the patch. Smacking her lips Clare sought a more practical solution and, seeing no other, decided to see what this new body could do and, gritting her teeth, she struck the trunk a thunderous blow.

Clare howled in pain, quite a sound at her size. Apparently these trees were harder than they looked, even for her. Sucking her fist, huge, green eyes watering, Clare looked about her. Her stomach was rumbling awfully as she hunter between the trees. At last her efforts turned up, from amidst the massive toadstools on the ground, a rock, easily the size of a house, but which Clare held comfortable as a tool. Clare briefly flirted with the idea of nibbling on a mushroom, for, according to a human story she’d once heard, they could, apart from making great houses for pixies, confer on the eater the ability to change size, shrinking down or growing up and up! Clare decided against this, figuring all she’d get was poisoned. Such was her hunger that moments later Clare had opened up the side of a nearby tree and, discarding her rock, dipped her hand into the sap welling up and dripping from the wound. Minutes passed as Clare ate the sap, like a bear sticking its paw into a beehive, extracting honey. As Clare ate greedily though she became conscious that she wasn’t feeling her best, feeling sickly and dizzy. Did she eat too much too quickly or was it just too sugary. Fingers still in her mouth, Clare stepped back from the tree trunk, the world starting to spin slightly about her giant head. Almost overcome by dizziness and stomach cramps, Clare nearly collapsed back against another tree, where she leaned, her eyes cast upwards to the woozy canopy above. Indeed, as the moments passed by, and Clare’s began to flush, it seemed like the wavering canopy was drawing closer, pressing down on Clare from above. Fighting the urge not to vomit from dizziness Clare tried to fix her gaze on the trees before her, but found her vision swimming up and down as she were afloat at sea. Clare shut her eyes for a moment, trying to be sick from the sap, but was perturbed by the most awful abrasive, chafing feeling between her shoulderblades and, as time wore on, between her buttocks. Opening her eyes, Clare unstuck her rear from the trunk of the tree. Still dizzy, Clare rubbed the red skin about her cheeks. So big back there I’m wrapping round the bloody thing. Clare shut her eyes again, trying to gather herself; this was perhaps not how she’d envisaged life as a goddess, at best tripping her but in a giant forest with a sore butt or at worst poisoned and slowly expiring. Clare opened her eyes and looked at her hands and down at her giant chest; the seemed to be throbbing and undulating. Yup, hallucinating…brilliant. What probably went some way to clearing Clare’s head, though, was, as she inspected her long, tapering hands, her huge, that her blonde head was suddenly struck from above with a thud. At first Clare, as she clamped her hand to her head and let out a yelp, thought something had fallen on her. Looking up, she had to swipe a tangle of twigs from her eyes. Clare stepped back as much as she dared for her dizziness and so the branch that had hit her continue to slowly fall past her head and shoulders. In her addled state of mind it took Clare a little longer than was proper to realise that yes, she was feeling sick and that, yes, it wasn’t impossible that she was hallucinating, but it was also certainly true as well, without a shadow of a doubt, that she was growing! No sooner had Clare noticed her slowly expanding body than her growing eased off, although her stomach pain and wooziness only abated slightly. Clare, still groggy, could feel the offending branch from earlier lightly grazing the underside of her right breast. Steadying herself against a tree, which creaked a touch ominously with her increased size, Clare closed her eyes again for a moment, still not quite over her nausea. Obviously the sap had made her grow again. But why? Clare reasoned that the sap must be suffused with raw magic after she’d gushed a fair torrent of her magic-laden milk over the valley; they’d just sponged it all up. And now it’d made her grow again! Resting her head against the trunk of a tree, Clare was a little conflicted; she felt terrible after that growth spurt, but her hunger was a little satiated and, well, she was bigger and bustier than ever! There was a pause during which Clare, head pressed against the trunk, could only hear the forest murmurs and the creaking of the trunks and branches. The sweet smell caught her attention again, wafting up from the trees like a vapor or a mist. And while she leaned there she found herself thinking of her new role in this world, as she had done shortly before, as remaking things as she saw proper, as, for want of a better word, a real goddess. And she found herself thinking of her vision of herself lying contentedly upon her side before her subjects, some mere humans grateful for her bounty and others tall, womanly pixies, all dwelling in the shadow of her mountainous breast in complete happiness. But, another vision clouded her addled mind and happy thoughts, that vision of a gargantuan Nel, looming over Clare and stretching further than the horizon, her prone body curved catlike around the planet; what was a mountain compared to a moon!? What if Nel should grow and grow and GROW!? No, Clare thought, head still swimming from the sap, she was indeed becoming a goddess, that was certain, but for what she wanted to achieve, to realise the potential welling up inside her, she’d have to get much, much bigger...

1152121211212112221111212221211111111112.content:
Clare was still swooning among the trees from the heady effects of the magic-laden sap, which seemed to linger in her veins and her brain. Holding her stomach, which continued to burble like muted thunder, Clare brooded following her sap-induced growth spurts. It niggled at Clare that, gigantic though she was, both Nel and the Empress could cause her any worry! That they could make her feel insecure about her size and her power. It was ridiculous, thought Clare, for she had grown so much that Nel and the Empress were no more than motes to her, like flecks of pollen before her huge, green eyes. And yet, just as a tiny speck of pollen can be enough to bring on a fit of hay fever or a single spore is enough to bring about infection, the tiny bodies of Nel and the Empress made Clare begin to worry, for none knew as well as she how tiny things can suddenly blow up. For Clare knew that her escape from the dungeon and her subsequent expansions, from tall pixie to giantess and, from there, to voluptuous goddess, could not have escaped the notice of the Empress and her friend and that they must have been, while Clare had made her way across the landscape, growing bigger along the way, industriously seeking a way to foil her, whether this involved, as it were, deflating her or, maybe worse, inflating themselves Clare could not know. Indeed, as she stood amongst those towering trees, it occurred to Clare that at her immense size Nel and the Empress could carry out plans to stop her right under her nose and she’d be too big to notice until it was too late! It was very inconvenient being so large, thought Clare, although it was only natural that some might resent the rise of a new goddess.

Clare foresaw herself sprawled out across a mountain range, a huge hand resting in the cool waters of a nearby lake, and dreaming contentedly. But, all of sudden, Clare noticed a cloud of birds rising from the treetops of a nearby woodland and soon glimpsed the towering form of the Empress making her way towards Clare through the woods! Clare roused herself, lifting her head from her hand; she cocked an eyebrow to behold the Empress, thousands of feet of toned, honey-coloured muscle and scarlet hair, with huge, brassy breasts bouncing with each footstep, and a thicket of red hair crowning the Empress’s mighty, powerful hips and haunches! Rising, Clare sat upright atop the mountains like a throne, her huge hands resting on far-distant peaks, and smiled at the Empress who seemed to Clare, as she drew closer, like a child wading through the grass, quiety confident. But, all of a sudden, Clare’s smirk dimmed as the Empress, as she strode towards Clare with her jaw clenched, suddenly ballooned in size, again and again, doubling and redoubling her height, until she loomed over Clare and the mountain range, casting her shadow before her. So startled was Clare that she stumbled backwards over the blue mountains as she rose to her feet. Clare craned to neck upwards as the darkening form of the Empress loomed over her, coming closer all the while. Even as Clare backed away from the Empress, though, Clare heard, from the inky clouds mounting behind her, the most terrific rumble of thunder, long, sticky and drawn out like stretching rubber. Clare turned from the giant Empress and was confronted by a gigantic, black chasm in the air before her. Clare’s eyes followed the seam of the chasm up and up and up, towering up beyond the dark clouds and, Clare could discern that on either side there rose great crags of faintly blue rock, smooth as the inside of an oyster shell. Clare reeled backwards as the chasm seemed to gape and yawn before her, as if opening to swallow her; Clare was conscious also of the thunder from above again and the smooth rock walls seeming to shift. A blast of wind came down from on high, parting the clouds above Clare. Clare lifted her eyes upwards, while the Empress stomped ever closer, and to her horror saw, through the ring of parted clouds, Nel’s gargantuan face peering down over the gigantic bulwark of her bosom. Clare broke put into a cold sweat, stuck between a rock and a soft place, or maybe between the devil and the big, blue pixie! The Empress now was upon Clare (gosh she too was enormous, by now) and reached down to snatch Clare from her feet, lifting her up through the clouds, smiling wickedly down at the huge Clare held between her fingers. Clare struggled in the Empress’s grasp, but even as she did so the Empress advanced on Nel and her endless plain of chest-flesh, while the titanic Nel laughed like a volcano and held her tremendous mammaries tight. Clare could see the vast abyss of cleavage yawn before her, as if in eagerness Nel had expanded larger again, ready to swallow her up! But, no, Clare thought to herself, in the midst of her daydream, she was the one in charge! It was her that had been transformed into a goddess, not them! She had more magic in on finger than any of them! And accordingly, as these thought flowed through Clare’s mind, the scene still there in her mind’s eye dissolved into one where Nel and the Empress had indeed grown gigantic, but they no longer held a doll-like Clare, ready to plunge her into a chasm of vast and sweaty cleavage, but instead both lay pressed to the landscape, as if under a fallen tree-trunk, under the immense weight of Clare’s buttocks, which rose up from the earth like pale moon pressed into the soft mantle of the planet, smooth, warm and huge! A hand larger than some countries grasped appreciatively the flesh of one monumental cheek, while Clare, sitting on a whole continent as if it were a tuffet, craned over her shoulder to appreciate her rivals pressed underneath her! Clare heaved an immense sigh of satisfaction at the thought and wondered if she might, if she were just to get a little bit bigger, if she take a bite from the moon floating above her head...

Still holding her stomach, Clare pursed her lips as she thought all this over, the smell of the sap rising from the trees. Waking from her sap-fueled day-dream, Clare set her jaw, and grasped the trunk of a nearby tree. Sweat broke out across Clare’s brow and her magic-fueled body and her face flushed as she exerted herself and muscles she did not even know she had. A tremendous groaning became a thunderous cracking which accompanied Clare’s managing to bend and break the upper portion of the tree, snapping off the treetop and letting it tumble to the forest floor. Clare stood panting from the force of her exertion, hands on her thighs, looking down at the splintered trunk, which was now gathering dewdrops and puddles of sap as green as malachite, swelling up from the wood like an underground spring. As the sap welled up Clare stooped, the glow from the sap lighting her huge cheeks while her enormous breasts brushed the branches below. Clare dipped her long fingers into the glowing pool, drawing up a long, sticky strand, as when a spoon is lifted from a pot of honey, and placed them in her mouth. Again and again Clare dipped in her hands to scoop up the magic-laden sap, her huge form hunched over the broken trunk like a bear breaking into a hive, gorging on the comb and the honey alike. As she did so Clare found her lips and chin becoming impossibly sticky with sap and her body became increasingly adorned with patches of sap as it dripped from her fingers or was off on her bulging hips. When Clare found her finger tacking across wood, she cast about, wiping her mouth as best she could, and set herself to felling another tree, for each tree was glutted with sap, far more than one might expect!

This continued for what seemed like hours; from on high, on perhaps the tallest mountain in the land, one could probably only hear the cacophonous crashing of trunks like skyscrapers falling, and maybe, through shifts and thinning of the mists, a great clearing in the otherwise unbroken throng of the trees. Perhaps, also, one could have caught sight of the dark and massive figure sending the trees crashing to the ground. At all events, after some time had passed, the groaning of the falling timber was replaced by a new, animal groaning and the heavy crashing of the trunks was replaced by another, duller thumping. After gorging herself time and time again on the magic sap, Clare could now be seen making her way through the gigantic forest she had created with some difficulty, squeezing herself between the trunks, and walking with a ponderous, waddling gait, her stomach bloated and distended, filled to bursting with sap. Rubbing her stomach as she edged between two trees, Clare could not stifle a sudden belch, which rang out through the canopy. Clare groaned and clutched at her back as she wander on. Within a few minutes, Clare had reached a glade of sorts, into which sunlight was falling, showing the vapours rising from the forest floor. Laying herself down against the gnarled root of a huge tree, Clare regarded herself and the great dome of her hugely swollen stomach, running her hands across it affectionately, as if she were carrying a child inside her. Clare groaned with pain but smiled to think of the veritable green sea of magic sap, like jellied frog-spawn now swilling around and fermenting inside of her. Clare could almost see the new life stirring inside her and swimming in that green sea, as in a snowglobe: monster-breasted nymphs, dryads with hips like town walls, and mermaids as big as whales. Clare could not help but laugh a little at the thought of the new world she might soon create for herself, of what she would soon become! Soon Clare felt a trembling in her stomach, a rippling starting to pass through her; she could feel her stomach and the sap quivering; grinding herself into the forest floor, Clare panted as she clutched at her stomach and a nearby trunk and began a resounding groan, feeling the quickening inside her, as if now ready to heave a new world from herself, ready to become what she may...

1152121211212112221111212221211111111112.content:
Meanwhile, Nel had just awoken from a fitful night’s sleep. In the days since Clare had effected her escape from the palace dungeons, outgrown the alchemical vault and proceeded to wreak havoc on the outlying areas, and, by all accounts delivered to the Empress, managing to grow more and more, the Empress had moved to a chalet owned by the crown in the hills, for her own safety should Clare return to the palace, and she had insisted that Nel be allowed to accompany her. Despite reservations from the captain of the captain of the Empress’ Honour Guard (What if Nel should suddenly grow immense also!?), Nel had accompanied the entourage. Joining them also were the court Archmage and Grand Sorceress, though in a mostly advisory capacity. The chalet was set some miles from the palace grounds, far back on the sloping green hills that bordered the royal lands of the pixies, amongst tall and dark coniferous woodlands, generally known to exist, but its location not commonly known.

Nel awoke in her room on the west side of the chalet; she and the Empress for matters of etiquette slept in separate rooms, though Nel partly suspected that Captain Alexandra, a mighty pixie in her own right, who might easily have overpowered Clare prior to her tremendous growth spurt, was suspicious of Nel’s motive in laying with the Empress, perhaps having terrible vision of Nel sudden erupting in size and pounding the Empress flat, who, even in spite of Nel’s recent growth, was a towering pixie in her own right. Of course, the problem was that neither Kassandra nor Alexandra or Nel were big enough to handle Clare! All the same, it did irk Nel a little to see the suspicious look Alexandra would shoot her, from under her dragonhide helmet, if she were to see Nel readjusting her overtight dress, as if Nel’s chest might suddenly explode and engulf them all like and avalanche. Nel stretched, the covers slipping from her breasts, bundling up around her hips. Still groggy, Nel scratched a breast and could not help but smirk a little at her newfound bustiness and rose to begin her morning, nearly knocking her head on the posters of the bed as she did so.

The Empress had spent the morning in council with the Alexandra, the archmage and the grand sorceress and Nel was left to her own devices. Wandering among the meadows, Nel enjoyed greatly the fresh breeze coming from down the valley, rippling across the grasses and bobbing the heads of the mountain roses. Nel walked from the chalet, though she had been warned, sternly, not wander too far, and, enjoying the early sunshine so much, she sat down in a sunny spot, upon a mossy rock, doing her best to tuck her dress under her. Nel sat there in silence, lost in thought. She had been sick with anxiety since Clare’s escape, preying on her dreams at night and her thoughts during the day. For even though the others felt gravely about the situation, Nel knew Clare better, from before her hunger for magic had started to drive her, and knew that Clare had a mean streak when she was crossed and was wont, in such a situation, to go to wild extremes in her attempts to get even. Nel recalled a time when they were at school, that Clare had been made out to be a fool by their potion instructor for some reason. Clare’s response had been to obsessively study for months, until she knew outside and in the topic on which she had been mocked and more! So much so that she had got the better of the instructor in class, exposing him, so she thought, as the fool he was. It was around that time, Nel recalled that Clare’s puberty had really kicked in and during this time she rocketed upwards, eventually becoming tallest in the year by head and shoulders, so that she positively towered over the instructor when he attempted to upbraid her for her insolence. It was probably around this time, reflected Nel, that Clare had learned to associate superior size with superiority. Nel played with stalk of grass and shuffled her bum on the rock; she had a funny feeling that she too had grown since arriving at the chalet, maybe all that fatty milk from the upland cows. That was perhaps the source of Nel’s constant worry, the knowledge that Clare might go to silly lengths to square the circle with the Empress.

Nel was looking back towards the chalet when a large flock of birds flew overhead and Nel was conscious of an almost imperceptible rumbling, perhaps it was only in her ears. Nel could see the guards exchanging glances though and she definitely felt a kind of trembling in the air. The wind had picked up and was soughing in the trees. Soon Nel could feel a rumbling in the ground. Looking down, Nel could see the little pebbles jittering, ever so slightly, by her feet. There had, Nel recalled been reports from outlying territories of increased seismic activity, but not, so far as she knew, in these vales. But as time went by, the rumbling soon intensified. Nel could see that it had attracted the attentions of those indoors for she could see the gleam of Alexandra striding from the doorway of the chalet. Nel steadied herself against the trunk of a tall conifer as the rumbling began to grow into a shaking. Nel could see Alexandra dispatching a guard to quickly ascend the slopes of the mountain, to the small; ornate watchtower concealed there. Nel watching the small figure nimbly glide up the slope, weaving in and out of the rocks, when the shaking grew again. It comforted Nel little to reason that the rumbling, whatever it was, was near unbroken and, therefore, could not be the thunderous footfalls of an approaching Clare. But this did not solve the mystery of the quake, for even as Nel thought this the shaking seemed to redouble and Nel had to cling to the tree to keep from falling. As the quaking continued, Nel followed as best she could, the guardsman’s ascent. She watched him reach the top and disappear into the thicket of gorse at the top. For several agonising moments Nel waited, seeing that Alexandra and the guards did so also. Nel realised soon that she had been holding her breath and gasped abruptly. Momentarily, Nel saw the guardsman bolt from the thicket, descending the slopes like lightning, making towards the chalet. Nel continued to look about her, seeing a few rocks now tumbling down the slope before, before she could see Alexandra wildly and frantically gesticulating towards her, seeming to beckon her back to the chalet; Nel had not seen the captain so discomposed as this. Nel started across the meadow as the thundering of the ground became greater still, so much so that as she crossed again through the long grasses Nel was bowled from her feet as the thundering and quaking grew still more severe. Only mildly bruised, Nel wondered, her vision juddering with the landscape, if the world were not splitting asunder and half expected to see the ground opening up before her. She rose unsteadily to a half-stooped position and made her way towards the chalet, where, she could see, Alexandra was making ready the carriages for the Empress and her guests, who were confusedly standing in the doorway.

But Nel’s eyes were drawn the range of the hills, where Alexandra was suddenly pointing and yelling with renewed fury. From above the rim of the hills Nel could see a shadowy outline rising above the morning mists clinging to the thicket of gorse, vast and black, as if a volcano were thrusting up from the valley beyond. Nel could see the arc of this shadow spanning, as it rose, the entire chain of the hills, turning honey-white as the morning sun fell upon it in patches, like some enormous white sunrise, or the moon rising over the horizon. The moon-like dome continued to rise over the hill-line, rumbling like thunder, become pearly and glittering as the mists settled up its vast rondure. Nel could see, along the distant chain of the mountains, another such form looming. It slowly dawned on Nel as it had already on the others what she was seeing, for it seemed so impossibly large that it was an impediment to her realisation, that is until she saw, looming through the fine, golden mists rising from the wet earth, a vast crag or excrescence of ruby affixed to the vast rondure of that swelling honey-globe, projecting outwards, proudly like the spire of a cathedral or the summit of a mountain. But as the great dome rose thunderingly, so too did the reddish crag, taking on definition through the mist, seeming now more like a pyramid, but again, as its contours softened, more like a levelled hilltop or a slag-heap. Like the light of day, realisation immediately forced its way into Nel’s brain: a nipple… And as Nel realised this the scene rising before her coalesced; she realised the huge, honey-coloured domes could only be a monstrous pair of breasts, ploughing across the landscape! And, indeed, these could belong to only one person, confirmed maybe unnecessarily by the dimly visible mole on the vast expanse of expanding flesh, like a small crater on the face of the moon, and that person, though perhaps she needed a more appropriate term now, was Clare… Nel realised that Alexandra’s fear was that this expansion was far from over and that those monstrous mammaries, slipping over dales and valleys as they grew would swell over the rim over the mountains, as the sea breaks through a seawall, and engulf them all! Nel scrabbled to her feet as the titanic breast looming over the valley surged above her. Appearing now, over the rim of that gargantuan breasts, half-concealed by white cloud, was the terrible and radiant blonde head. Nel reached the waiting carriage and cast a look back again as she made to enter at the goddess-like visage of her friend, her immense green eyes lighting up the clouds veiling her face. Whatever Clare had done this time, however far she’d gone, she was now truly gigantic and, as she continued to grow, her body sprawling across the landscape, there was no telling what else she was in the midst of becoming...
