1152121211212112221111212221211111111112.content:
Nel hurried to the carriage, doing her best to stuff her breasts back into her slight dress, for in the rumbling commotion they seemed to have sprung free. The Empress, the Archmage and the Grand Sorceress had already bundled into the carriage, making for quite a squeeze, and, as she reached it, Nel glanced back, as she clasped the doorframe and had put her foot on the step to hoist herself in, looking up at the gigantic dome of creamy flesh towering up above the mountains, growing ever rounder and more full as the moments passed, while the vast reddish discs of Clare’s aereola widened and stretched across its surface like the spot on Jupiter or the sanguine iris of some colossal eye, and in its midst Clare’s nipple grew and lengthened as if it were a volcano tumescing up from the earth’s mantle, positively engorged with magma.

https://solarsystem.nasa.gov/images/cont...

Nel mounted the carriage and urgently attempted to squeeze uncomfortably into the already packed seating. Nel cursed under her breath; she was certain she had grown since last she had been in this carriage. She was internally quite proud of herself for managing to fit with so little hassle and un such a rush, but, then again, was basically oblivious to the Archmage and Grand Sorceress’ panicked shuffling to the corners of the bench to avoid being swallowed by Nel imposing rear, where they now sat uncomfortably cramped. The carriage rocked as Alexandra mounted the front alongside another the chalet’s retainer. Nel heard him gasp to the Captain, “Ye Gods, Ma’am, she’s gigantic!” Alexandra angrily muttered something in response that was drowned out by the now incessant rumbling, a deafening rubbery sound like elastic thunder. Nel felt the carriage beginning to move off, towed by the eagles down the path to the chalet. Nel attempted to crane her neck back to see the scene unfolding, but could only manage a tessellated glimpse through the latticed window at the mountainsides and the swelling monument of snowy breast-flesh rising above. Nel returned her attentions to the carriage. She saw the Empress looking grave as the carriage trundled on and Nel wondered what was running through Kassandra’s mind at this moment. Nel more than expected that the others, much like herself, were anxious that they were in very real danger of being crushed to death in this valley, swallowed up like motes of pollen in a field beneath Clare’s body. But preying on the Empress’ mind must have been the worrying thought that, even supposing they were not crushed, that they did escape, how could they ever stop a creature like Clare? To whom huge dragons were like bothersome flies about her person? Vast lakes dwindled into puddles before her now and great chains of jagged mountains seemed like little more than filigree on the hem of a green quilt or like a string of blue-grey stones laying across her colossal bosom. Indeed, this thought weighed heavily on Nel at this moment, as the carriage gathered speed, preparing to take to the skies. And, moreover, as the carriage struggled into the air with a succession of clattering bumps, the one fear, that is, the fear that they might be crushed, started to be allayed, the other fear continued grow and grow in Nel’s mind, while above the mountains so too did Clare’s monstrous breasts and, beyond her view, the rest of Clare’s titanic body.

http://blog.oxforddictionaries.com/wp-co...

As the carriage gained height, the occupants clung on as it was rocked by bouts of turbulence, always the case with the wind funneling down from the mountains, but perhaps exacerbated by Clare’s breathing in the distance. As the climbed higher and higher, Nel could now see more comfortably from the window. They were just drawing level with the tops of the hills when there came a tremendous booming and the most apocalyptic crunching. All eyes were drawn to the windows of the carriage with this. Nel quickly supposed, as was soon confirmed, that Clare’s gargantuan bustline had at last reached the mountains, colliding with a massive shock, such as the force of growth pumping through her body, and was now pushing up against the mountainside as she continued to grow bigger! As Nel leant forward, the better to see, displaying her own chasm of cleavage to the seats opposite, she could see, as they were now level with the mountaintops, Clare’s immense chest pressing up against the peaks, which were, for the moment, seeming to hold back the bosomy tide so that, as Clare continued to expand, the seemed to bulge up behind the natural barrier larger and larger, piling up like huge mounting clouds. But as time passed, so Clare grew ever larger and her breasts ever more voluminous and Nel could see huge, rubbery bulk of Clare’s breasts, as the cracking seemed to worsen, start to bulge over of the mountain ridge, swelling through passes between the peaks. Nel could see the jagged teeth of the highest peaks stabbing into the heedless bulwark of growing flesh much as a knitting-needle rests on the surface of a balloon and could not help but hope that Clare might suddenly deflate herself or burst and send herself scudding into the distance. But no such luck, and Nel could tell, as anyone could, that Clare’s breasts were growing ever larger, ploughing to the landscape as their owner lengthed across it. They have to use Clare's milk to get as big as her!
1152121211212112221111212221211111111112.content:
Rather than return to the Imperial castle, where Clare would undoubtedly seek them should she wish to find them, if she was not by now so large that the castle seemed to her only like a miniscule, blue-grey mushroom in a hummock of plushy moss, the Imperial entourage had proceeded further up into the mountains, travelling for almost half a day before reaching a small mountain village through a pass to the north.

http://www.caryinstitute.org/sites/defau...

An hour or more later they were accommodated in the inn, where by now sat in one of the more private anterior rooms, reserved for local festivities or a guest of the Empress’ standing. The entire royal party sat gloomily, scarcely able to touch the food and drink provided for them, thinking only of the ever-growing threat that was Clare. By now the harsh reality had dawned on each of them, and, indeed, also on many denizens of the lands around, and had time to fester that Clare was now, quite literally, the biggest threat to the world that could be imagined. And, moreover, without some kind of plan to stop her, and her relentless growth, their fate would be sealed. Not one of them, not even Nel, was absolutely sure what Clare would or could do with her newfound power, but all of them could be certain that it would be disastrous.

Hours later, the fire was dying down to embers and the party was no further towards a concrete plan to stop Clare. Instead they would quickly devolve into bickering, such as when the Archmage’s apprentice, a shy young lad whose main duty seemed to be to carry scroll, offered the suggestion that perhaps they might try some kind of decoction to shrink the gargantuan pixie and the Captain of the Imperial Guard had flown into a frustrated rage, yelling that it was precisely Clare’s having slugged a vault-worth of potions that had lead them to this point. The young lad received a cuff of admonishment about his ears from the Archmage, to remind him to think before he spoke. Several plans were mooted, discussed and inevitably dismissed. Alexandra and the Grand Sorceress favoured tackling the problem in as aggressive a manner as possible. But raising a vast army to defeat Clare was ruled a fool’s errand because it would likely, even if they were able to call for help from the mountain giants and sleeping dragons, end in failure and would constitute only a nuisance, or, worse, an amusing game of toy soldier for Clare. No-one needed to go through that.

https://www.google.co.uk/search?rlz=1C1C...

All the while, though, Nel sat in quiet reflection, staring into the glowing cinders of the fire. Gradually it began to dawn on Nel that the reason all their plans seemed impossible to stop Clare was precisely because she was so powerful by now. So...it stood to reason that the only thing that could stop Clare was...Clare. With this, Nel’s eye’s brightened with an idea and she lifted her head to speak...
1152121211212112221111212221211111111112.title: Nel hatches a big plan

choices: Weeks later, the trap is set...
Someone betrays the plan to Clare...
Something goes wrong during preparation...
1152121211212112221111212221211111111112.content:
Rising to speak, Nel took care not to clatter her head on the low beams that criss-crossed the room in which they had convened. Inclining her neck a little, Nel could not help but feel that she’d grown again. Looking into the glowing coals of the fireplace for a moment, Nel cleared her throat.
― What if, she began, hesitating at first, ― what if we give Clare exactly what she wants?
The gathered listeners were decidedly nonplussed by this suggestion, even the Empress looked at Nel with a concerned face. The Grand Sorceress was the first to speak.
―Are you suggesting that we surrender then!? Just accept our new lives in whatever world your friend might choose to make for herself!? ―No, not at all...what I am suggesting is this…
Nel paused for a moment to run through her plan to herself, while the assembly waited on tenterhooks.
―Yes, how about we try to give Clare too much of a good thing, until she can’t handle it any more?
Seeing their faces still confused, Nel elaborated.
― Look, by now we know that, whatever Clare did to herself, magic in whatever form has catalysed Clare’s growth and we also know that Clare seems intent on finding more sources of magic to make herself even more powerful, yes?
Nods of understanding.
― But we also know that this has made Clare’s body hugely unstable, right? Well, how about we trick Clare into consuming so much magic that her body becomes unstable? If I am right, if we can pump her full of enough magic and saturate her, it might just expel all the magic from Clare’s body.
Nel looked to the Empress, whose red hair seemed to smolder by the light of the fire.
There was a brief pause before the Empress spoke.
―But Nel, even if this could work, where would we find enough magic to do such a thing?
―Your Highness, if we could call upon our kingdom and the neighbouring kingdoms to scour for any source of magic…
Grand Sorceress again was quick to speak.
―But surely your friend Clare is, by now, much too large to notice any such measly little sources of magic as we can offer up?
―My thought was that we could cluster them together so that they would attract her attention, Grand Sorceress.
The Empress spoke again, kind yet sceptical.
―Even so Nel, I just cannot foresee such a quantity of magic as could do anything other than exaggerate our problems.
Nel struggled to think, somewhat crestfallen.
―Then, then…
At this the Archmage, who all the while had been gazing into the fire, smoking a long pipe and stroke his beard in what they had assumed was an attempt to look thoughtful, spoke up.
―You know, your Highness...were there not, in more wasteful times, dwarven mines in the northern mountains that were digging deep into the planet for raw magic?
Nel’s eyes lit up as she looked to the Empress who appeared to think for a moment.
―Well, yes, yes, I believe there were...but they were abandoned years ago.
―Is it not conceivable then, Empress, that we might, uhmm, open them up again? Access to the a geyser of the planet’s raw magic would surely, in theory, provide us with enough magic to carry out this young lady’s plan, no?
Nel was quick to accommodate these new facts and hastily added:
―Yes! And, we could use the sources we amassed to lure Clare north towards the mines!

The Empress sat with her brows knitted for some time, pondering what to do. Nel stood, anxiously awaiting the Empress’ decision. To Nel, the plan would work as she planned, she had only to rely on Clare’s greed to drive it. Nel did not envy Kassandra her position; Empresses (pixie rulers were invariably women) of the past had had to contend with the threat of monsters before, dragons, ogres and the like, but never before had the threat been on such a scale as Clare, who was no longer solely a threat to the pixies but a threat to the entire land! Perhaps even the world. Nel could not help but feel pangs of guilt when she thought that it was her own desire to be bigger and her fooling around with potions that had lead them to this point; it was she that had originally blown up Clare and she had to put this all right.

After a moment the Empress spoke.
―Alexandra…
―Yes, your Highness.
―start sending word to the kingdoms to gather all the sources of magic that they can possibly find...
Rising, the Empress strode from the room
―...we have much work to do.

Clare restrains herself for now...
1152121211212112221111212221211111111112.content:
The soaring Gothic towers and spires of the city seemed to quiver and creak, as if caught in a storm passing over the mountains to the north, with each of Clare’s breaths. Clare lay alongside the city in all her immensity, lazily engaged in toying with one of these spires with the tip of her index finger, encircling the entire ornate mass of buildings with her body, curled up thick and voluptuous as though she were some gigantic cat. The citizens could only quake and cower to behold Clare, whose breasts alone dwarfed the city, steeply rising up from city limits in an graceful bulge into mighty edifices of flesh, seeming to groan and shift as if the city had been built in the lee of two colossal glaciers. All the while Clare’s immense face hovered above the city, her huge red lips and seagreen eyes hovered above them, hazy like the moon seen during daylight hours, but ever so close!

In the days since her last growth spurt, Clare had subjugated all the cities, townships and kingdoms she could, toying with each in turn for her own amusement. Indeed, the process had proved relatively easy for Clare, for she was, as both she and the citizens of these domains had eventually come to grasp, virtually invulnerable to all attempts to repulse her: volleys of magic seeming to evaporate on the surface of her skin like tiny sparks, projectiles hurled at her from catapults and ballistas mounted on the ramparts simply rebounded or crumpled and armies advancing on her were brushed aside like layers of dust, or, in unfortunate cases, obliterated by the alternating impacts of either Clare’s gigantic arse or colossal bosom. And though it seemed like Clare’s growth spurts were at long last at an end (though it was apparent that she had continued to thicken for some time afterwards), it certainly seemed as though her last explosion of growth had been more than enough to push Clare towards being something very near to a terrestrial goddess. What Clare had been unprepared for, though, was the comparative boredom that would accompany this; although Clare’s powers were by now utterly immense, once she had subjugated any kingdom or city, she was faced with a strangely restricted range of options for her amusement that did not consisted of completely wiping districts from the face of the earth. Clare found herself, as she peered with difficulty at the thronging citizens who looked no more substantial than mites to her, missing the times when she was merely fifty foot tall and could appreciate the widespread panic she engendered as people fleed from her and the satisfying squash of those trodden underfoot as though she were treading on toadstools, or even of being five hundred foot tall ( a size that now seemed diminutive to her) when she could feel every building popping like gooseberries under her fleshy posterior as it was mashed into the ground. Clare heaved a gigantic sigh that sent vaporous gusts travelling through the city streets.

Weeks had also passed since the night when Nel and the others had devised their plan, during which they had gone about setting it in motion, preparing their trap for Clare, and now it was ready to spring. Nel and the Empress were stood atop a stone watchtower, perched on the mountainsides overlooking the valley in which lay the city alongside which Clare was currently nestled. Their nerves were wracked by anticipation as they looked on Clare and the city. Presently, there arrived a messenger from the Grand Sorceress, who was currently stationed at another of these waypoints further to the north. They were ready. The Empress shot Nel a glance; her face was pale and her lips thin as she nodded to her honour guards. In response her guards lowered the small drawbridge of the tower, flung wide its barricaded windows and opened up the hatch in its rooftop, to reveal the trove of magic objects amassed within: urns, books, candles, amulets, bracelets, shoes, wands, hats, rings, goblets, staffs and anything they could lay their hands on that contained any trace of magic. Individually, none of these could attract Clare’s notice, but together... Nel stood on the crenelated battlements, the wind at her back, and looked out on the valley and the gargantuan form of Clare and waited. It took almost an hour, but eventually she could see, through the spyglass, Clare’s gaze change from one of drowsy boredom to the countenance of a child who, having spent hours playing amongst the flowerbeds of her family’s garden smells, floating between the branches, the spicy and warm smell of her mother’s baking. Nel saw Clare stir and sit up and could hear the rumbling as she did so; as Nel watched Clare seem to sniff at the air, the Empress laid her hand on Nel’s shoulder: “We should retreat to the next waypoint Nel.” As they descended the tower and the carriage climbed once more into the air, they heard something like far-distant thunder and Nel could see her gigantic friend sat up her heels in the valley, a flash of greed beginning to be rekindled in her green eyes.

Clare slowly canted forwards across the valley, her gigantic breasts swinging beneath her, sniffing all the while; even at her colossal size she had detected, wafting on the breeze, that peculiar tang that she had come to associate with sources of raw magic. Crawling, Clare followed that faint trace across the valley (an irrelevantly small distance for her now); she could already feel the anticipatory burbling in her stomach. It was an unfortunate consequence of her enormous size that Clare could no longer smell smaller sources of magic and as she had grown larger and larger so too had it become harder for her to discern the fuel for her growth; Clare had reconciled herself to this size as long as she thought that she had scoured the lands clean of substantial sources of raw magic, but now, with the barest hint of another source reaching her, there awoke in her the desire to devour and grow. Reaching the mountains, Clare brought her huge eye up to the lone tower, which appeared to her like little more than a thimble. Clare sniffed at the tower with something like care, before, as her eyes brightened, reached up and plucking the entire masonry from the mountaintop, between her index and medial fingers. Without much ceremony, Clare popped the tower into her cavernous mouth, chewing the insubstantial morsel with much relish as if it were a small raspberry candy.

Clare was still absentmindedly chewing and sucking the tower between her teeth and cheek, when she caught a whiff of something on the wind blowing down from the north, further into the mountains. With an almost mechanical motion, Clare heaved herself up again and moved northwards, her giant nipples grazing the frosted peaks as she passed over the crags and valleys in the way one moves tentatively over the coastal rocks and rockpools of the seashore. It took Clare much more searching to find this source of raw magic: a small horde of things that she could not tell apart and were, to her, a single mass secreted in the attic spaces of a burned out mansion on the outskirts of a mountain village thickly bordered by conifers. As soon as she’d located the mansion, Clare dispatched it with a lick of her tongue. But not sooner had Clare crunched down her tongueful of woodwork, magic and trees, then there was that weird tang in the air once more. What was this? Clare mused to herself as she followed the smells that made even her gigantic nose prickle. Was it now the case that she was so large that her nose was like some enormous radar for raw magic, capable of picking up even small traces, or was it that her body was so starved for magic that she was becoming super receptive to it? It did, nevertheless, strike her as strange that these little troves should have escaped her notice before now. Moreover, it was odd the way these troves were always in locations remote from any populace yet more or less easily discernible even to someone who was thousands of feet tall: on a precipice near the mouth of a mountain cave; in a sort of cairn atop a burial mound; on lining the ramparts of a ruined castle; packing the courtyard of a recessed monastery; in a forest clearing. ‘Upon reaching another one of these troves glinting and lumped together on the ice of a mountain lake that Clare’s suspicions were truly sparked and, after grabbing the magical objects and yards of lake ice, she scoured the landscape in vain for any evidence of the hoarders. But it was no use; she was simply too huge. Whomsoever had amassed these piles, they had done so long beforehand, and without her notice, but seemingly specifically to bring her northwards. Clare could not help but blast her stupidity in following this trail of crumbs, for crumbs they were and would certainly make no difference to her size.

It was then that Clare spotted the glimmer something on an escarpment nearby the mountain lake. Clare leaned in to examine the green object: from what she could see it was a crude statue, little more than a figurine to her, of a woman, a pixie, standing with arms and wings outflung, its massive chest jutting outwards from the torso...her? Close inspection made clear that the statue had been hastily carved from a lump of raw magic ore, but from where? Clare picked up the statue and was scrutinising it when she saw, chalked into the edifice behind it, in letters so tall that even she could read them: FEED. GROW. GODDESS. So she was really a goddess now? She had become some kind of deity to some, devoted followers who would have her become even more powerful? Clare could not help but grin with glee as she popped the statue into her cheek. The mountains rang with her throaty laughter. Clare smilingly rose to her feet, towering up over the mountain peaks and valleys, but as she did so her mouth dropped open and she near spat out the statuette when saw what lay in a basin to the north and to which her followers had lead her, throbbing with seagreen light.
1152121211212112221111212221211111111112.title: Oooh, a piece of candy!...

1152121211212112221111212221211111111112.content:
Before Clare’s eyes, at a distance of some miles northwards, she beheld a familiar greenish glow emanating from a crater or deep basin, that seemed almost to bleed upwards into the darkened sky in streams and tapers of turquoise light. Clare’s mouth could not help but water as the smell stimulated her nostrils, blown down from the north on chill winds: raw magic, a great, open well of it. Such a well, thought Clare as she rose to her feet, must run miles deep into the planet! Clare strode across the northern plains as her stomach once again seemed to lurch into activity in anticipation of finally being satiated. She marvelled that such a well of raw magic had escaped her notice until now. It had been quite an oversight on her part.

As Clare began to make her way across the featureless steppe between them and the crater, and as her calamitous footfalls grew steadily more distant, a small band of creatures emerged from a cave in the peak that Clare had observed as scarcely more than a hairline crack. This band, among whom was the cloaked and hooded Alexandra, rapidly moved towards a pyre concealed from Clare in the northern lee of the mountain peak. As a moments activity, the bonfire was lit, sending the signal to the north. Alexandra looked out from the snowy mountaintop as those colossal buttocks swayed their way northwards to the muted groaning and resonating thunderclaps of Clare’s feet, seeming in unison to be the clanging of some gigantic bell. She prayed that Nel and the Empress knew what they were doing.

Clare could see, as she neared the crater, that lustrous pool of light, evidence of mining communities on the steppe, small flimsy houses bunched together, now windswept and seemingly empty, for Clare was used to seeing whole cities swarming to escape her while these towns stayed motionless. Deciding that to spend time inspecting these would be a waste, Clare strode over them like pebbles in her path. Lining the edge of the crater, Clare fancied she could see the tiny lines of scaffolding cross-crossing the crater’s rim, illuminated by the lurid green glow from within. Clare supposed, as she began to loom over the scene, that she could see shadows flitting about in the glow, no more substantial to her than the black sparks and motes that float through the humours of one's eyeball. Indeed, as she approached and the crater began to be swallowed up by the shadow she cast, and she could not help but feel her great size to be an impediment to discerning any signs of life in and around the crater. Who in the world had done this? Done this, for her? If this had, as she suspected, been the work of a group devoted to her, to worshipping her, The Cult of Clare, then it felt disappointing to not be able to see those responsible for delivering her this offering. Not able to thank them properly. Clare stood above the crater in all her voluptuous glory, she thought a while, as though pondering what lay before her.

Upon receiving the signal from the mountains that Clare was approaching the crater, the parties under command of the Empress and the Grand Sorceress had immediately begun preparations to decamp from the crater’s rim, where the workforce of hired miners had spent the last few weeks sedulously excavating and blasting open the mine, till the raw magic had began to gush up and well from the planet’s interior. Once retreated to a distance judged safe, they crouched, concealed by outcrops and by the giant’s spreading shadow, and waited. In the gathering gloom, they could, when they lifted their eyes up the entire length of Clare’s colossal, almost luminous body to her face, see a gigantic red smile split across it.

The ground thundered and trembled as Clare knelt down with all her weight upon the landscape. Planting her hands heavily on either side of the crater, Clare leaned herself forward, her gargantuan breasts ploughing over the lower slopes, pulverising bare trees and ramshackle huts as they dragged across the land. The landscape rumbled and shook again as Clare, on all fours. lowered her lips to the crater, wrapping them around the crater, the rim and the pool contained therein. The ground began to quake for miles around, rattling the tiny houses and shook snows from the summits of the mountains, as Clare began to drink raw magic straight from the planet, drawing up huge mouthfuls and then gulping them down.

Some way off, Nel and her party crouched hidden in a dusty building near the crater’s slopes. Looking up at Clare’s enormous countenance, luminous like the moon, Nel watched Clare’s huge lips clamped around the crater’s rim contracting and squeezing as though some gigantic red serpent had coiled about the crater. “That’s it”, Nel muttered to herself, “drink it all up like a good girl.”

To the north of the crater, the Archmage and the excavation team were forced to seek refuge in the cellars of the mining town lest they be blown away. Such was Clare’s size and the strain of her exertion that her nostrils blasted tunnels of galeforce wind down the slopes of the crater and scouring across the immediate landscape. Descending into the cellar, his beard blown into an unruly tumbleweed, he wondered to what scene he might eventually emerge.


Those escorting the Empress sheltered precariously underneath Clare, meanwhile. The Empress studied the vast, milky canopy of Clare’s body spread out above them with stony features. The Empress could see every mouthful of magic as it passed into the gigantic pixie’s belly, dully glowing lumps that moved slowly down her gullet before disappearing into Clare’s stomach. As Clare gulped down more and more, the Empress could see Clare’s belly growing taught and bloated, distending more and more with the sheer volume of magic Clare was now ingesting. Indeed, as Clare’s stomach continued to engorge it was acquiring that same luminosity that the Empress could discern in her throat.

Minutes passed, yet they seemed like hours to the onlookers. The dramatic quaking of the landscape and the thunderous moans of gustatory pleasure continued. Clare seemed like some gargantuan blood-sucking insect, vampirically draining the planet of rich, green blood and gradually becoming swollen and distended. But, just when the gigantic pixie seemed like she could gorge herself forever, there came a new rumbling in the sky. At first it seemed like thunder brewing in the clouds and but after a few moments it acquired the cacophonous groaning of trees being felled in the woods. Clare’s eyes, closed in concentration as she suck up raw magic, snapped open in alarm as she felt a strange quivering in her guts, as though her belly were not with lakefulls of raw magic, but a mass of wriggling tadpoles. GRRRRRRRRRKKKKK. Clare lifted her lips from the crater, great gobs of seagreen magic dripping from her chin, and clutched her grotesquely swollen stomach in pain as it groaned thunderously.

All the onlookers, Nel, the Empress, The Sorceress, Alexandra and everyone for miles around, saw the cataclysm unfold. The seagreen glow coalesced in Clare’s belly was seen to slowly disperse itself through her body, lighting up her veins as it did so, turning them into rivers of livid green. Passing along Clare’s flanks, the glow spread in a web across her obelisk-like thighs, down her legs and calves to her feet, and across the vast expanse of her gigantic buttocks, while, simultaneously, it spread just as rapidly across her arms and shoulders, to her huge and flushed cheeks and to the colossal teardropped swell of her breasts, where they fanned out into a veritable delta of tributaries. GRRRRRRRK! As this progressed Clare could only groan in pain as here stomach heaved and sloshed violently, while giant droplets of green-hued sweat formed on her brow, her throat, breaking out on her massive chest and running down the small of her back between the humid chasm of her gargantuan butt-cheeks. Clare’s body felt strange, like nothing she’d felt before; her vision seemed to swim before her, zooming in and out of focus. To the startled onlookers Clare’s body seemed to be trying to expand and contract all at once, its contours, fissuring with green light, seeming to have become indistinct, fluctuating and flickering as it did so. Clare gritted her teeth, sweat gluing her hair to her jawline, as she suppressed a scream. NNNNGGGGHHH--GRRRK! As her body flickered more violently, seeming in less than a second to lurch bigger before abruptly shrinking, realisation came to Clare. She had been tricked! Tricked, and now she felt like she was on the point of exploding. This was impossible! How could this have happened!? With THIS body!? A Goddess like HER!? A feeling began to wash over Clare that felt as though her veins were rupturing, as though she were gradually being pulled asunder from inside. And as this feeling mounted, Clare lifted her huge head, cheeks streaked with sweat and tears, and screamed: WHAT HAVE YOU DONE TO MEEEEE!?

With this outburst Clare’s enormous and voluptuous body was lost from anyone’s sight as there erupted a cataclysm of seagreen light that blasted over the landscape for miles around….

choices: The time-stopping spell dissipated.

1152121211212112221111212221211111111112.content:
Clare having lurched back unto her haunches and dangerously bloated with magic was at the apex of being torn apart by the very magical essence she had glutted herself on. Tear-soaked and screaming, Clare cried up at the heavens as her body violently shuddered, growing and shrinking as her body illuminated further and further before she felt her veins burn with energy and her body reached critical mass. Growing blindingly bright, the enormous pixie vanished behind a screen of blinding seawater green light.

Just when Clare thought this was it, that it was all over. Everything came to a stop. Everything froze all around her. The snow tumbling from the mountains, the birds taking flight from the howls of her screams, even the clouds overhead.

Everything froze, except Clare.

She still hurt. Everything hurt, like inside her very veins there existed a thousand suns, all burning at once, on the cusp of a supernova each. She burned, feeling the green-hued sweat and tears sizzle upon her body as it felt like it was burning from a sunburn contained within. Clare's body still ebbed, distorting doubly under her vision as her eyes dazzled and unfocused. Her head pounded as a good portion of the energy within was creeping through her bodystream into her brain. She seethed, palm to forehead as she squatted in the ravine, on the edge of the crater.

Nothing else moved.

Clare felt like she was going to die. Felt like she should have died, right then and there. But instead she lived. She didn't want to die, but this moment was painfully hellish to endure. Still, she did exactly that. Spreading her legs as she squatted, stepping slightly and twisting away from the crater, her bloated and distended belly forcing her legs apart and making the simple act of turning around painful. She still held her head, her elbow nudging her swollen, inflamed breasts as she did so. They jostled and jiggled against her as she burned with discomforting pain.

"Not... like... this..." She seethed, hissing between clenched teeth as she forced herself to contain the explosive energy within. Feeling like a living bomb about to go off, she swallowed back her own detonation.

Slowly, the pain began to subside. She swallowed again, feeling her whole body convulse. All her exploding nerves slowly easing back the burning pain. She panted, gasping for deep breaths as her body cooled. The magical swirling coalescence within slowly being tamed by her willpower alone. She forced herself to inhale, to swallow back the explosive energy about to burst forth, to own it, to control it. The cracks in her body, inside her very veins it felt like, slowly repaired themselves, growing stronger and sturdier as she forced herself, in this dying moment to tame her wild magical energy.

It was a herculean task. It was impossible. But she cheated. This whole moment frozen in time, was cheating. Somehow, in her last breath she had tapped into the critical surplus of magic within and managed a spell, a single magical spell borne from sheer willpower and a desperation to live. She expended some of the bounty she had just consumed. For some reason, the magical statuette of herself flashed before her mind. The imagined Cult of Clare feeding her desire to live. And a burning desire to not allow those that had conspired, tricked her into this situation to win, to get the last laugh. All this has accumulated into this last ditch effort to stay alive.

And it was successful.

Clare's body, still distorting uncontrollably, slowly ceased its distorting contortions. The magic within her slowly rebuilt her body, better, more durable than her original frailty. It would not allow this vulnerability to be exploited again. But this spell, like Clare, wasn't perfect. There were consequences.

Clare's body grew. She grew taller. And then her ass fattened. Feeling it as it happened, Clare cast an eye over her shoulder and watched as her bum, already perfectly proportioned in her eyes already, suddenly fatten with surplus. She gasped with pleasure as her butt grew against the ground, filling the ravine and spreading over the crater. She twerked involuntarily, like she was attempting to seduce a lover, her enormous bum teasing the crater of raw magic. She felt her exposed nethers loom over the crater's rim, feeling terribly indecent in this frozen moment.

Her thighs felt heavier, thicker, as she maintained her squat and feeling the magic lava in her veins slowly cool. Her arms felt sturdier, stronger too as she flexed them. Not muscular at all, but thick with a pleasant womanly way. Clare, hissed next, involuntarily as she felt her already massive mams swell even moreso. She gaped in surprise as her overblown tits blew up even bigger. Terribly rotund and swollen already, they bulged outwards excessively. She cooed and bit her lip as she bundled them up with her arms, feeling their enormous heft and heavenly swell puff and wobble sensually.

She especially liked this, she wasn't even sure why. She'd never dreamed of being this proportionately busty, but somehow reaching this size filled her with pride. It felt right.

She pivoted slightly, dipping low to show off to nobody in particular only to feel her distended tummy brush against her thighs. She reeled back at the sensation. Where had that come from?

Blissfully unaware of how much she had gorged her tummy until now, she felt it's hefty size weigh upon her middle as her body tamed the unruly, violently unstable molecules of her body and restore her to a sense of normalcy. That tummy shouldn't be here, that belly had to go. She couldn't see it, but she could feel it and it simply couldn't stay. It was ruining her "perfect" figure.

1152121211212112221111212221211111111112.content:
For minutes after the world rang. The landscape surrounding the crater quaked and was engulfed by a blinding green light that obliterated one’s sight entirely. Nel found herself fumbling sightlessly to steady herself, but finally crouching by what felt like a large, broad stone to save herself being shaken from her feet entirely. About her, though she could not see anything, Nel could just about hear above the rumbling the cries and shouts of the others as they sought stability on the quaking ground. Nel’s panic rose in her throat as wondered if the ground beneath them might split asunder, so violent was the quaking about them. Gradually, after what seemed like an eternity to endure, the rumbling began to subside, the quaking dying down and leaving behind a sound like muted thunder. It was still some time, though, before the green light cleared though. Nel, leaning against the rock, squinted about her as the scene slowly distilled itself: shadowy forms of figures and buildings looming out of air as green as deep water.

What struck Nel as she stood there, casting about in the dispersing mists, was the silence. Where previously the landscape had been full of the sounds of Clare’s gigantic body, her rumblings and thunderous groanings, there was only the sound of the wind and the cries of some marsh-bird in the distance. The mists were receding now, lifting from the crater and retreating to the edges of the plains, where they bundled into greenish reefs out there in the morning gloom. Nel saw her companions emerging from the places where they had sought cover and could see the Empresses’ carriage already on the wing from the mountains and fast-approaching. What Nel, could be certain of though, now that the light had faded and the quaking stopped, was that Clare had seemed to have disappeared from the scene altogether…

It did not take long for the parties to reconvene at the crater’s foot, the Archmage’s group being the last to arrive. Nor did it take long for them to reconnoitre the edges of the crater for any trace of Clare; scouting over the gigantic impressions Clare left on the landscape, they could discover no sign of her. Nel and the others, on learning this, took the time to reflect. Their plan had been a success it seemed, although they could not tell what had happened to Clare after they had overloaded her body. Had she been shrunk by the violent expulsion magic? If she had been shrunk, it must have been to some miniscule size, so small in fact that the pixies could not easily find her as they scoured the grasses and rocks. It was perhaps the case, as the Grand Sorceress ventured, that Clare really had been evaporated altogether, blasted into nothingness but the power of the raw magic she had so greedily gulped down. It was quickly ruled out that Clare had turned invisible because of the complete absence of the thunderous sounds of her body. It seemed plausible that Clare had been transformed into something completely different. It was not so long ago really that the amount of volatile magic Clare gave off from her in a kind of static discharge was such that her mere presence would see things spontaneously change form: trees popping into candycanes, birds turned into falling pots of flowers, lilyponds changed into gelatine or carthorses suddenly becoming a cloud of balloons! It therefore didn’t seem impossible that Clare might have been transfigured from her gargantuan size into a little dandelion on the steppe.

As they talked of how to begin preparations for departure, the Empress peeled away from the group, wandering as if lost in thought. Nel followed Kassandra along the small path, quickly catching up to her, lightly touching her on the arm. They walked some way uphill together in relative silence. After a while, the Empress paused and turned to look at the rim of the distant hills, girded with mist, over which the light of a new day was beginning to break in marmalade fingers. The Empress, without turning her rosy cheeks, sighed.
―It seems that the problems with your friend are at an end, Nel.
―Yes, it does...your majesty.
―I did not want it to end quite like this, you know? I entertained the hope that we would shrink her...but it would seem…
―I know Empress...but we had to do something...she had to be stopped; we couldn’t let her continue to…

The two stood in silence for a while, watching the first flickers of dawn; a breeze blowing gently through their hair. A few moments passed before Nel, shooting a glance at Kassandra ventured a thought.
―I suppose...this will soon mean it is goodbye....for us...your majesty.
Smilingly the Empress turned, looking up into Nel’s face. Nel blushed to look down at the auburn nest of gold-circleted curls over the heft of her considerable chest.
―You’ve grown Nel...It’s funny, we were so caught up with Clare that I didn’t notice you creeping up.
Nel flushed redder as the Empress loosely trailed a finger along the curve of Nel’s breast.
―You know, Nel, this needn’t be the end of our...acquaintance. If you were amenable...you might remain at the castle, as an advisor perhaps?
Nel smiled in response, but said nothing; the Empress leaned in, standing on her tip-toes. Nel inclined her neck, she could feel the warm puff of the Empresses’ breath and she could feel the warm morning sun falling on her shoulders as it came over the teeth of the mountains.

But in that instant before their lips met, the sunlight suddenly disappeared, casting the basin into the gloom of night once again. The Empress and Nel cast around in bewilderment at the sudden darkening of the landscape. They clung to each other as a tremendous quaking rocked the world about them.

―What on earth!?
Nel looked out towards the black mountains, seeing only the starless dark of the sky and the reefs of mist lying at the edges of the plain. As Nel looked on, while Empress called to those downhill of them, she saw a ribbon of green northern light split across the sky, a wondrous aurora wavering, crackling and broadening, a light so bright that it lit up the whole scene once more, and it seemed to Nel as if she and the others had suddenly been plunged fathoms deep in seawater and were standing on the seabed, amongst kelp and weed. Nel shielded her eyes as she looked on; the aurora was growing in brightness and size, waxing upwards across the sky, arcing across the whole of the horizon like a marine rainbow; about the ribbons and stripes of green Nel could see what looked like showers of sparks, crackling like lightning or rain. As the initial flare of the aurora died down though, bathing the landscape in an eerie green glow, Nel could distinguish something else amongst the lights: a vast black hole in the sky itself, as though someone had burned a perfectly hole in the midst of the panorama of green light. The landscape was again convulsed by the cataclysmic shaking and Nel was shaken from her feet, sliding down the embankment, landing crumpled on a tuft of shrubbery.

The world was still spinning for Nel as the whole horizon swam with the seagreen aurora, and at its centre that huge black circle. The light seem to be streaming upwards, full of green veins and shafts that resembled a colossal glacier of green ice. As she struggled to avoid losing consciousness, a pang of liquid fear coursed through Nel’s body: the hole in the sky...was a pupil; the crackling green light of the aurora...was an iris...and the thing filling the horizon, the whole of the sky, could only be Clare’s gargantuan green eye...

Would there be anything left? Would her consciousness and power be left bereft of a physical form? If not and she were to die, would Nel Nightfall grieve for her?

Solemnly through the fog of pain and pleasure, Clare recognized it was very unlikely anyone would mourn her death. While she knew not of the Captain and her guardsmen having tracked her here to try and capture her, only to realize their task was far more monumental than they had prepared for, she suspected her magical growth binge over the last day would have many wanting her dead. While the idea of consuming Nel and Kassandra, current queen of the pixies, (though Clare could probably take that title easily now) had been appealing during her imprisonment, now virtually all of her earlier anger had burnt out, and she was glad she hadn't. She was even starting to regret her growth binge and those she probably devoured in it... if just a little.

Maybe it was the intense maelstrom of sensation coursing through her and intensifying with every moment talking, but Clare... loved her friend Nel in ways she would have never dared voice when she was her original 1'7" size. She saw the way her little blue haired friend looked at Kevin, a fellow pixie from their village. She was also aware of Nel's crush on their queen, which seemed to further complicate these feelings. It was then that Clare had an epiphany of sorts. Of course, it had been several hours since, and finding their individual magical essences within her own would be like trying to find a pixie-scale needle in a human-scale haystack, but surely all this tremendous power would also compensate for her lacking the queen's talent with the spell. And maybe this would relieve some of this sensation that felt as though it would tear her apart as well... The blonde resolved to try.
