"Yes, but it also serves to return the magic I devoured. I don't really need it anymore." Clare replied to her would-be captor, smiling, "The real show is how you guys are still able to breathe up here."

"...What?"

"The milk was imbued with the magic and will reform into the stuff I ate last night. Anyway, I think I should make myself more presentable to Queen Kassandra..." Clare informed, before magically fashioning a pair of panties and a bra for herself, which felt so wonderfully soft on her skin. She topped it off with a magnificent iridescent dress that left little of her voluptuous curves to the imagination... despite her needing to aid others in seeing her in full now, not that she minded. "Much better! Well then, let's head back to the palace! It should only take me, what, ten steps at most to get there!" she beamed with a cheerful laugh as she begun her first steps, repairing the valley to its former glory shortly after.
115212121121211222111121222121111111121.title: Clarehemoth.

choices: Clare and Nel's first royal task...
The three get intimate...
Something else.
1152121211212112221111212221211111111211.content:
From around the construction site busily repairing the palace walls where Claire first emerged, workers saw what seemed to be a torrent of white liquid rushing towards them. It looked like... milk, but it sure didn't behave like any they knew of, what with it appearing to not touch the ground and dodging buildings in its path as though alive. Terrified, they darted out of the way as fast as their limbs could carry them. To their shock, as it flowed into the remains of the magical vault, it broke up into various colored fluids, which then created or reformed individual bottles and containers for the various magical potions that had once been stored within. "What... what did we just witness?" one of the workers asked in confusion.

Such occurred in other places, including the ruined library having its magical tomes restored and neatly ordered... before promptly falling to the ground without shelves to rest on, and the lake' magical waters returning. The ore from the mines, on the other hand, stopped shy of entering the mine, instead piling neatly next to its entrance, ready to be loaded and carried off to be processed into a more readily workable form. Indeed, the pixie kingdom was dumbstruck by all of this. At first, many pixies cheered or breathed a sigh of relief in the belief that the danger of Clare Cloudlight was finally over.

It was then that a tremor rumbled through the land, followed by another, and another after that. The town with the library fell into shadow. Its citizens gasped as they looked up as far as their necks would allow, some even falling to their backs, finding Clare staring down upon them and the library in particular, so vast that she blotted out the sun, her bare toes alone dwarfing nearby trees. Somehow, they could comprehend her smiling face, as well as her free hand giving a friendly wave, unaware that she was assisting them. Just as they feared for their lives, she resumed her journey with another earth-shaking step.

Meanwhile, Kassandra could see from the window the utterly massive 16 mile pixie fast approaching the palace despite the tawny haired giantess' very leisurely pace. "My queen... w-what should we do?" a guardsman asked.

"Close the gates to the palace and raise the magical barriers. See to it that Clare Cloudlight does not get through. I fear she may be after me, and her friend Nel Nightfall." Kassandra answers, maintaining her calm despite her own fears threatening to destroy the facade. Her people needed her calm and level-headed, and her panicking would not be beneficial.

The guardsman bowed, and departed to deliver his queen's command. The pixie city palace was well equipped in its fortifications to discourage even a dragon from wanting to waste its time in trying to breach through. It hardly took more than a few minutes for the massive gates to close, one by one, followed by layer after layer of shimmering barrier to be erected. "My queen..." Nel whispered next to her worriedly.

"I know not what Clare's intentions are, Nel, but I too wonder what she's up to out there. If her goal was to destroy us, surely she would be making haste for the palace rather than taking her time..."

Athenia watched helplessly as Clare examined the city before moving on. The captain of the royal guard disliked feeling helpless, and her current position atop Clare's vast fingernail felt like it mocked her. Thankfully, the tawny titan had teleported those she had revived down to the town before she left, so Athenia didn't have to worry about them any longer. "You do know that the palace and surrounding city are renowned for their defenses, right?" she asked, "And how do you intend to do anything meaningful at your scale? You're too damn big!"

"Yes, at this size, I could fit my home village on my nipple easily," Clare paused in her answer as the thought sent a shiver of pleasure down her spine, needing just a moment to keep her wings from fluttering and potentially causing disastrous effects, "but it won't really be an issue, I'm sure."

The titanic blonde took another couple of steps, stopping at the border of the pixie city that served as the capital of their kingdom. She could feel the powerful magic of the barriers near her toes, the outermost layer generously stretching almost to her ankle and giving her another pleasure-filled shiver over just how massive she was. She crouched down as low as she could, granting the city a view of the biggest breasts this world had ever known through the top of her iridescent dress in the process, and said, "Don't even try it, boys. If you attack me with your spells, I'll be forced to reflect them back."

One brave guard fired a blast anyway, which traveled towards Clare, only to turn mere inches from the skin of her big toe and fly right back at him and knock him onto his butt. She sighed, then proceeded to tap the barrier. It flickered, before it and the layers beneath it cracked and shattered, dissolving in a shower of sparkles, much to the shock and horror of everyone else. Never in the city's history had its defenses fallen, and the notion of them falling so rapidly, up to this point, had been unthinkable! Then, with a heavy sigh, Clare... vanished.

When Athenia's vision cleared, she found herself on the ground, facing a far less gigantic Clare. Automatically, the guardsmen took the opportunity to attempt to apprehend the blonde, only to be frozen in place before they could take a step. "I still have all the magic of my 16 mile size. Now, come Athenia. I've an appointment with the queen, and I'd like your company." Clare declared, calmly walking off towards the palace, flying over each gate when she came to it. Seeing little choice, Athenia followed the now 10 foot blonde as quickly as she could.

From time to time, the Royal Guard would approach the reduced giant pixie, weapons raised. Though she loathed to do so, Athenia ordered, "As your captain, I order you all to stand down!" Immediately, they lowered their weapons, unwilling to question their amazonian (by pixie standards) captain.

Clare smiled as she bent down and gave an all too familiar guard a light pat on the helmet. "I'm sorry about the other day... I'd be willing to do almost anything to make it up to you later, if you'd like..." she apologized sincerely, hoping she wouldn't have to explain why she was only showing remorse for her actions now.

Kassandra and Nel had seen how quickly the defenses crumbled, and while the latter was panicking, the former retained her calm. The throne room's door bulged for a moment, then unlocked of its own accord to allow Clare to crawl in, followed by Athenia. "Good afternoon, Miss Cloudlight. I have received reports throughout the kingdom about you since your escape from the dungeons." Kassandra addressed.

"I know we've gotten off on the wrong foot, but I'm not the monster you think I am. I've revived nearly everyone I ate last night, and returned the magic to its proper place. The previous royal alchemist wanted me as a puppet ruler, though someone talked him into it. It may have been to prepare the kingdom to fall to this stranger while the alchemist tried to replicate the results from Nel and I."

"But if you returned everything, Clare... why are you still so huge?" Nel asked, making her presence known.

"It was unstable magic, so it changed me." Clare answered, "Wait... Nel? Oh my gosh, Nel! Look at you! You've grown! I didn't know if Queen Kassandra would give you a proper taste of growth, but-"

"Er, why do you care? You can flaunt being stupidly huge all you want, and clearly even the city's defenses are no match for you..."

Clare sighed. It was now or never, even if Nel was already committed to their queen. "Nellie... I know I've done almost nothing but drive our friendship apart, but... I... I love you." she admitted, cheeks burning.

Kassandra studied Clare, and said, "Clare, if you inform me of who set you free and why, I will pardon you for your past crimes."

Clare turned her gaze to the queen and nodded, proceeding to tell everything she knew and had done. Both Kassandra and Nel were shocked to learn the royal alchemist had attempted to stage a coup, only for it to backfire when she totally absorbed him, but even more shocked to learn someone else may have pulled his strings with the prospect of creating a new goddess. "In that sense," she concluded, "he succeeded. I've ensured the kind of reactions Nel and I experienced won't happen again, but this other party is an unknown. They may try to attack our kingdom, so I'd recommend we be prepared to defend our realm."

"Very well. Clare Cloudlight, you are hereby pardoned for your past transgressions. As our new goddess, I personally look forward to working alongside you, though I must wonder for how long you're able to remain at this scale."

"As long as needed, my queen."

"Please, you both may call me Kassandra. We are all equal here."

Nel mulled things over in her mind. Her heart couldn't deny she loved Clare back, but it also refused to let go of Kassandra. They were both breathtaking in their beauty, and have shown her kindness. "I'm sorry, but... I can't choose between you..." she said finally.

Clare and Kassandra's eyes met before resting upon the blue haired pixie who meant so much to them. "Oh, Nel... I don't believe that will be a problem. I have no qualms with the three of us being mates if that is what your heart desires." Kassandra informed.

"I'm fine with that as well, Nellie. It'll be awkward, at first, but we can get used to it." Clare said with a warm smile. Today was turning out far better than she expected, and she hoped to repay both Nel and Kassandra for giving her another chance.

As for Athenia, still standing silently by the door... She wasn't quite sure what to think.
1152121211212112221111212221211111111211.title: Clare's (re)visit to the palace

choices: Marina is made big immediately, but the girls get... distracted.
Staying focused on the task at hand.
Something else.
1152121211212112221111212221211111111211.content:
A day passed since Clare "stormed" the palace, and much of the pixie world was still uneasy. The palace clearly still stood, but no word had been given yet regarding the fate of their beloved queen. Some younger, more imaginative pixies tried to sell anyone who would listen on the idea that Clare and Kassandra battled it out with terrifying displays of magic. A duel between the royal bloodline, which had always been steeped in magic, especially expressed in the females, and Claire's stolen gains. The endings varied wildly, but one thing was certain: the entire kingdom waited with bated breath to learn whether she'd been banished for good, or they were now in her gigantic, iron grip.

Meanwhile, Kassandra and Nel awoke on warm, soft, creamy beds, both of which slowly rose and fell in unison. Silky white fabric, softer than anything Kassandra had ever known before, kept them both snugly tucked in well over their heads, which rested on pink pillows attached to the creamy surroundings. Feeling a little mischievous, Nel gave the pink pillow a gentle rub, causing it to rise and harden as she played with it until their blanket was removed, grinning cheekily at what greeted her.

Of course, they weren't really beds at all, but rather Clare's enormous breasts, her bra providing her mates with a cover, and Nel had been playing with the nipple she'd used as a pillow. "Oh, alright, Nellie. Kassandra, our beloved blue haired imp of a mate wants us to get up." she said, smiling, winking a sea green eye at Nel. As much as she loved the feeling of the landscape beneath her, she was glad to have a nice, plush mattress to sleep on. And her mates snuggled upon her breasts had been an arousing suggestion she was glad Nel made. Perhaps they'd all take turns now and then, with Clare remembering to render them all invulnerable to prevent overnight misfortune.

"Does she, now? It has only been a single night, and already I fear we may be spoiling her!" Kassandra chuckled lightly, though in truth she had been considering doing the same. It was in their nature to be at least a little impish, and Kassandra was no exception when her duties as queen didn't require her to resist it. Unfortunately for all three, the fun their hearts desired would have to wait. By now, some of the more ridiculous rumors of what transpired between herself and Clare were starting to enter the palace walls, and even most of the palace officials knew not of what actually happened.

Granted, revealing everything at once may be taken the wrong way, and she hadn't revealed to anyone that she and Nel were an item yet, so perhaps it'd be best to withhold what needn't be known for now. Regardless, the redhead fluttered off of Clare's breast, landing on the ground gracefully, before swelling back to her previous size with a moan. She was sorely tempted to keep growing, just as she was to enjoy her mates for breakfast, but her duties called. She, with great effort and Nel's aid, squeezed herself into a dress, and then left the bedroom.

"Well, I suppose we both need to get ready. Life in the palace is nothing like our old life." Nel stated, looking for a suitable dress. She was welcome to Kassandra's wardrobe, seeing as how she had been granted her previous 2'8" size, but so many of them looked too regal on her body...

"Yeah, for starters, you're no longer whining about being so small. Now you're one of the biggest pixies around!" Clare nodded, "Here, I'll give you something that's a little more... you." She concentrated, and began to form a dress for Nel in a similar style to her own. When finished, its blood red fabric hugged Nel's body nicely, and was very soft on her skin. It would not do for the dress to blemish her creamy flesh in the slightest.

"Oh wow... This is definitely more my style!" Nel beamed, her wings fluttering in happiness. She also marveled at the black boots appearing on her legs, featuring red trim at the top, before settling to the ground and leaving the bedroom to join Kassandra for breakfast.

Clare left the room herself shortly after, making sure to rearrange everything back to the way it was before, if slightly messy. The blonde made herself invisible to anyone she passed in the halls, considering she didn't want to be seen until she was properly introduced, and then slipped outside. She tried to fly, but fell back down on her ass almost immediately. "Ouch! I guess a 10 foot pixie's just too heavy to fly..." she grumbled. Still, she needed release after last night, and so gave both of her mates the ability to mentally contact her when needed.

With that taken care of, and Kassandra bidding her a safe trip, Clare teleported herself to a familiar location: Frir Valley. It was here that her transformation into a goddess, for lack of a better term, had completed, so she felt something of a connection to its borders. She took a few minutes to marvel at its beauty at her 10 foot size, and then returned to her titanic 16 mile height, shielding the valley from harm while she was at it. As much as she wanted to have taken it slowly and feel it happen, she had no time for that. This was her opportunity for release...

About an hour later, Clare was resting happily with a mountain buried between her legs, the entire valley flooded with her milk, when Nel mentally contacted her, letting her know to get ready. The tawny giantess willed her mess to clean itself as she stood once more, her iridescent dress returning to cover her within moments, and then confined herself to 10 feet once again. "I needed that..." she sighed, just before teleporting back to the palace. It's fortunate that the palace was as vast as it was, since otherwise the blonde wouldn't be able to stand upright at this size, and would have to settle for something even smaller.

In the throne room, Kassandra had assembled the palace officials for a meeting. A few moments into it, a small figure burst into the room, clearly out of breath, earning her looks of disdain from the gathered officials. "I'm sorry I'm late! I-" she began, only to trip on her own too large robes, falling upon her face.

"You're interrupting an important meeting, girl. State your business, and then begone." one of the officials informed coldly.

"Peace, Edmund. I've recently appointed Marina as royal alchemist, so you will treat her with respect." Kassandra reprimanded. Once Marina had been seated, Kassandra moved on to business. "As you all can clearly see, I'm unharmed from the incident yesterday. We'll be making an announcement later today, but first, I'd like to introduce you all to my new aid."

The doors opened, and Nel walked into the room excitedly. "Pardon, my queen, but isn't that the pixie who arrived here in shackles a few days ago?" the grand sorceress asked.

"Yeah, that's me. My name's Nel Nightfall, and the queen deemed me worthy of being rewarded her old size for the rest of my days." Nel answered, coming to a halt beside her mate, "It's an honor to be in her service, considering my humble origins."

Marina could see the look Nel and Kassandra shared with one another for the brief moment it was there. She had her suspicions, but kept quiet. "Now, I know this may come as a shock to some, but we have a new goddess in our midst whom I look forward to working alongside." Kassandra continued.

Again, the doors opened. This time, Clare entered through them, straightening up to her full current size shortly after. Nearly everyone in the room gasped in shock and disbelief. "Everyone thinks I, Clare Cloudlight, came here yesterday to overthrow our queen. In truth, I returned, transformed by the very unstable magics I foolishly consumed in a fit of madness, to pledge my services to her. It's my hope that I can build your trust in me as we all strive for the hope of a bright future, and protect our realm." she informed, kneeling down to show her respect.

"So, this is what the palace is to announce later?" Marina asked, doing her best not to collapse under the stress she was in just by being at this meeting, by far the smallest and least impressive pixie here despite being the previous royal alchemist's oldest and most talented apprentice. She hated that she didn't even fit in the smallest robes they had. She had been a little taller than Nel originally, but lacked her blessed curves.

"Yes, and with that said, this meeting is adjourned." Kassandra replied, "However, I'd like for you to stay behind for a few moments."

Frightened, Marina remained seated as the others filed out, leaving her alone with Kassandra, Nel, and Clare. "I-is this because I was late?"

"No, I have my first task for all three of you, and this seemed to be a good time to give it to you rather than needlessly summon you later." Kassandra smiled warmly.

"You might have heard that Nel and I grew to tremendous heights a couple days ago, which required the queen's intervention. This was sparked by a combination of an apparent shrinking potion and a growth potion meant to serve as an antidote." Clare explained.

"But that makes no sense. The effects should have canceled each other out before either of you could consume any unrefined magic..."

"Exactly. I want to know what that potion was, and if possible, where it came from."

"Alright, I'll look into it, but I need a sample of that potion so I can try to match it with what's in our records."

"And that's where Nel and Clare come in."

"Are you sure, my queen? Perhaps one of us should stay as a precaution..." Clare asked worriedly.

"I'm certain, Clare, though I appreciate your concern."

"Er, i-if it isn't too much to ask... I really hate tripping on my robes all the time, so could I be grown at least enough to properly fit in these things?"
1152121211212112221111212221211111111211.title: Tasks and meetings

choices: Fight fire with fire!
Seek out a Monster Hunter!
115212121121211222111121222121111112.content:
The morning following Clare’s escape, Nel awoke in the Empress’ quarters. Her eyes were still blurry with sleep as lay on her back and gazed at the gold and white rococo ceiling. She stretched out under the covers before remembering the evening before. She lifted the blue sheets to look down at her swollen body stretched out before her. Nel closed her eyes and heaved a sigh, smelling Kassandra on the pillows about her, and thought back on the night. Nel, now swelled to the size of, perhaps, a small human, for once in her life felt big and satisfied. She rolled over, but the Empress had already risen and there was no sign of her.

Nel rose, only naturally bumping her head on the bedframe, and crossed the room to one of the tall windows, still foggy with the heat of the room, and looked out at the mist on the Palace lawns. Nel, absentmindedly stroked the blue curtains with her cheek and looked at the golden curtain rail at her eyelevel and smiled. Nel picked her way across the room and gingerly inspected on of the huge wardrobes, so large, in fact, that they seemed to hold up the room. Having found a dress which more or less covered by body, Nel slipped from the room.

The hallways were eerily quiet and unpopulated as Nel wandered down them barefooted, like a spectre. At the end of one such hall, Nel heard voices coming from a set of double doors that lay ajar. She recognised the voice of the Empress, and slowly nudged the doors open. The Empress was sat with several others at a large table, including: the Grand Sorceress; the Imperial Arch-mage; the Imperial General; a young Alchemist Nel did not recognise, and the seven or so Imperial judges. The Empress cast her eye over Nel, but continued talking, unphased. The Sorceress and Arch-mage raised their eyebrows at the tall, fleshy pixie inching her way into the room, her head grazing the doorframe. Nel crossed the room and sat, as best she could, beside the young Alchemist, who budged aside to accommodate Nel’s hips and thighs.

The Empress was reading aloud from a pile of letters. At first Nel found the sense of the conversation difficult to follow. The Empress read only from the pile of letters, several of which, when Nel entered, were already read. Nel furrowed her brow as she listen to the reports of some immense “creature” attacking locations in the shadow of the castle; the Palace had been inundated with letters pleading for help. This particular letter concerned an attack made by this monster on the magic ore mines on the slopes of the nearby mountain range. As the Empress read on through the letters, in her low and sonorous voice, several phrases jumped out at Nel, repeating themselves and building her impression of the creature: “…the mineshaft was lit by an eerie green glow”; “…the eye of some colossus”; “reached into the mine with an arm like a sea-serpent”; “grabbed my men, mine carts, and clumps of the mine itself”; “terrible crunching and thunderous booms of laughter”; “All of a sudden, seemed to grow”; “some huge monster that seemed to glow like phosphorous in the night”; “drank a lake”; “…towered up into the clouds”; “…sounded, at first, like thunder; “huge glowing eyes”; “the air, as it strode across the treetops, seemed to crackle about me”; “Became bigger and bigger”; “…craters left behind”; “great golden head…”; “unstoppable”; “too big…”; “continued to consume…”; “blue streams of magic across its skin”; “grotesquely swollen”; “abomination”; “…transforming”. The Empress finished the last letter, which closed with the line: “My Empress, how can we stop such a thing?” The Empress set down the letter and repeated the last lines in a low voice.

Before ever the Empress had reached the last letter, Nel had clustered the impressions into a composite and realised that the colossal monster attacking the outlying regions must, in fact, be Clare! Though she, at that moment, did not know how Clare had grown again, Nel did know that having a giant Clare on loose, again, could spell only trouble for everyone involved. But it sounded, at least to Nel, like Clare had completely lost it, as she’d been driven mad the bigger she became, or maybe that she was crazed by the desire to be bigger? It was a worrying thought that a magic-maddened Clare was trampling across the landscape; who knew what she might be capable of?

The Empress laid aside the final letter; there was brief silence. The Empress breathed before saying: “It would seem our little captive, Miss Cloudlight, has become a not-so-little fugitive” The Grand Sorceress nodded and the Archmage made an affirmative sound. The Empress, a picture of calmness, laid her hands on the table and said: “I fully admit to you that I am not certain how to deal with a…problem of this magnitude. The girl has, from what I can gather, according to our friend here,” she gestured at the young alchemist, “ingested a great number of Alchemical substances for our vault, which triggered a series of violent magical reactions, and, needless to say, resulted in her rather exaggerated change of scale.” The Empress gestured to the letters: “Worse yet, if these accounts are to be believed, Miss Cloudlight, having outgrown the Vault, has gone on to seek and consume other such magical sources, only intensifying the severity of her case. Not only has Clare Cloudlight grown colossal, she is becoming bigger. I fear that if we do not act soon Miss Cloudlight will be unstoppable.”
The Grand Sorceress was the first to speak, saying “It seems, as well, that this young pixie has disappeared altogether; she has not been sighted since the early morning; one would have thought she was difficult to miss.” She waved a hand, “I think it’s safe to assume that she has gone off in pursuit of more sources of magic?” The Empress nodded gravely. The Arch-mage spoke up now, asking “I am still unclear on her motivation in this? And how did she manage this?” The Empress shrugged, looking quickly at Nel, “Revenge…most probably…on myself” The Empress seated herself before adding, “As for how, I believe our young friend can enlighten you”, gesturing at the young Alchemist seated beside Nel.

The young Alchemist opened a great ledger before her, usually in the possession of the Grand Apothecary, and flicked through the pages until she found her place. “This”, she began, “is the Grand Apothecary’s diary; I managed to retrieve it from his quarters after the incident last night…seeing as he is now somewhat ‘indisposed’”. “A few days ago”, she went on, “the Grand Apothecary seems to have learned of an instance in the nearby woods of two female pixies becoming veritable giantesses through ingestion of unrefined magic.” She paused. “His entries become fixated on the idea of how best to research and exploit this, making reference continually to ‘the possibilities.’”

The young Alchemist continued to talk: “His entries are accompanied by sketches and vague notes in ink and with a shaky hand. The sketches seem to be preliminary and to accompany his thoughts, including one of a ‘normal’ female pixie set alongside a human being but followed by one where the sizes of these figures is equal, perhaps the pixie is a fraction taller, and this is followed by another still where the pixie is portrayed as quite radically larger than the human figure; another sketch shows a female pixie towering up from serrated lines which can only stand for the treetops, while another, overleaf, show a female pixie with the hastily drawn outlines of a town at her ankles, it cannot be said if it is a pixie town or a human town because the scale has not been given.” The young girl reflected: “It seems, at least partly, that he saw the chance to adjust the world, as he saw it, for the better – to make pixies big, bigger than humans, or, if need be, even bigger.”

The girl resumed: “The entry for yesterday seems very excited to learn of the arrival of at least one of these pixies in the castle and seems very keen to make her acquaintance, for reasons that the last entry makes clear. His intention seems to have been to illicit Miss Cloudlight’s help in staging a coup on your Highness and the Palace. He seems to have planned to use the Vault to make Miss Cloudlight just big enough to take the Palace by storm and overthrow your Highness as Empress; it would seem, however, that Miss Cloudlight had bigger plans for herself in all this. She was obviously more dangerous than he expected.”

Sighing briefly, the young pixie added: “I must say though, I do not think the growth-coup was entirely of his devising – he seemed, instead, to be driven by an alchemical curiosity to experiment with her body, to see a pixie swell and grow to those proportions, to measure her, to understand how she grew, to chart her rise, moment by moment, until she was taller than trees, to, if possible, recreate it. Writing shortly before he released Miss Cloudlight, acting, so he writes, on the advice of another, whom is not named, the Grand Apothecary wrote, with zeal and hubris: ‘Wish me luck, for I go now to create a new kind of creature, who will shake the very foundations of the world!’ The young Alchemist closed the book and looked at the Empress, who was sitting with her head over her fingers, and eyebrow raised. “It seems to me”, said the Archmage after a while “like our Grand Apothecary had rather grand designs on the Empire…to create a new Empress it seems.” “I think, rather,” added the Grand Sorceress, “that the intention, muddled and mad though it was, was to create…a new Goddess”.

“And,” broke in the Empress, somewhat rattled, “regardless of motivation, in doing so he has succeeded only in unleashing on the Empire, and the rest of the world an increasingly magic-hungry titan whose only thoughts are to destroy, to eat, to grow and to let nothing stop her!” The table was silent as Kassandra cast her eyes about: “so, I ask you, friends,” she said softly “what are we to do to stop Clare Cloudlight?”
115212121121211222111121222121111112.title: The Morning after the Night Before...

choices: Nel falls asleep and awakes as they reach their destination...
A storm blows their carriage off course, crashing in the mountains...
En route, they encounter trouble— Clare's back! (Or other...)
1152121211212112221111212221211111121.content:
Hours later, as the day was drawing to a close, Nel stood with a crowd of others, gathered at the Empress’ request, by a cortege of carriages, drawn by harnessed birds. Nel noticed that this time the carriages were drawn by elegant geese and some, such as the much larger vessel, almost a kind of boat, into which Kassandra was stepping, by snowy owls, for their journey, so she was told, would take them up into the frost-covered mountains in the reaches far to the North. Nel boarded a carriage, which tilted awfully as she put her weight on the steps, with only the Grand Sorceress and the young Alchemist, both of whom sat side by side and Nel had one cushioned side of the carriage to herself, for her huge thighs and hips swallowed up the space and she had considerable difficulty squeezing herself into the carriage in the first place. Nel, her head and neck crooked against the carriage roof, looked sheepishly and apologetically at the two passengers opposite her. Before long the carriages all moved off and soon ascended into the evening air; Nel’s carriage, pulled by two owls, pulling a little extra weight, made a laboured climb into the sky, but eventually rose to join the others in a procession across the reddening sky.

Nel twisted herself to look out of the latticed window of the carriage, out at the castle and its walls and grounds receding into the twilight. The sight of the castle at such a height, which more like a toy or a postcard of some fairytale castle, reminded Nel of the time when, only a few days before, she had actually stood at just such an immense height, towering over the landscape, and looked down, through clouds girdling her hips, at the miniature buildings at her toes, seeming more like ornate and fragile growths of mushroom and toadstools, sprung up from the forest floor, than the buildings that she, Clare and other creatures called their homes. But, she thought, she might be misremembering, maybe she was not actually so tall as she remembered, and maybe she seemed larger in retrospect than she actually was, owing to that peculiar way one amplifies features in the theatre of our memory, so that a young pixie of a modest fifty foot in height suddenly ballooned until she was a truly monstrous five hundred foot tall. For it all seemed so long ago, even though it was not very long ago at all, and now seemed almost like a dream to Nel and she would probably have doubted its occurrence altogether, so close was it to her happiest dreams, if she were not now cramped in the side of a roomy royal carriage with two other pixies who occupied nothing like the same space and in pursuit of a positively gigantic Clare. The sun was now setting behind the hills and the forests, which stippled the hillsides they were passing over, sank slowly into a deeper and deeper blue. Nel looked out at the forests, lost in thought, and, but for the wisps of cloud passing before her eyes and across the landscape, she could have sworn that the forests seemed like expanses of sphagnum moss and that she could easily walk across them, feeling her feet sink into the cushiony ground, as on a quiet night As the lights came on in the forest cottages and villages this impression dispersed and was replaced, as the carriages climbed higher, by the feeling that the hillsides, and the forests, broken up by the lattice, were a massive blue and purplish honeycomb, and, as she traced a finger absentmindedly on the pane, it was all Nel could do to prevent herself reaching out and plucking a great and dripping piece of this comb from the landscape, leaving the hillside bleeding, and, heedless of the gouts sticky honey dripping on her chest, biting into it with her lush and parted lips. Nel, lost in thought, found her mouth watering and she awkwardly shifted her hips in the closeness of her carriage seat.

Nel scratched her left hip, which had pressed into the wooden arm of the booth as she looked out of the window, and turned back to the interior of the carriage, at the two other passengers, the Grand Sorceress and the young Alchemist, both whom had also been admiring the landscape, but were, perhaps, not lost in the same sort of revelries as Nel. The Grand Sorceress was tall, but not so tall as Nel or Kassandra, and elegant as a swan, with a kind of effortless grace, with a touch of frost, in her demeanour, she was of perhaps the Empress’ age and her shoulder-length, chestnut hair was tied up in a knot, with tresses lying softly about her face. Nel found herself curiously subdued around the Grand Sorceress and looked away shyly when the Sorceress’ eye caught Nel’s admiring the the gold coronet, socketed with the large, smooth lozenges of several sapphires, the Sorceress wore, which also framed and lent greater definition to her face. The little Alchemist, whom Nel had never seen before until today, was still in her oversized robes, with her cowl still drawn up over her head, shading her eyes, but Nel could still distinguish her small features, her delicate, slightly upturned nose, and her pretty little mouth, which she pursed to a corner of her face as she looked out of the right-hand window. The day had ended without any of them saying a word until Nel, once the landscape below was basically swallowed up by the inky gloom, asked where it was they were headed. The little Alchemist, whose name, Nel soon learned, was Marina, only shrugged and said that all she had been told was Northwards, to the mountains beyond the kingdom. The Grand Sorceress, seeing that neither of her travelling companions knew, said, in a drawling and lugubrious voice, which Nel though made her seem only more impressive somehow, that they were heading Northwards because Nel’s acquaintance, by which she meant the giant Clare, was last seen heading North. “There are”, said the Sorceress, “in the icebound mountain ranges, where there are often storms raging, vast natural deposits of magic ore.” The Sorceress made a gesture with her long-fingered hand. “What goes sometimes unmentioned is that beneath these mountains and ice flows there runs a current of raw magic, for the veins and deposits mined by ourselves, dwarves, goblins and other peoples have to form out of the condensation and cystallisation of this ebb and flow.” Here the Marina mentioned that she can remember reading something about this, while Nel listened attentively. “Of course”, went on the Sorceress, “this is not normally accessible or noticeable, save in the deepest caves or mines, or where it escapes from the planet through natural vents or wells, looking like jets of flame or like huge, sea green pools or lakes— ordinarily.”

“But”, and here the Grand Sorceress permitted herself a little laugh in her throat, as she rocked a little from the movement of the carriage in the air, “I suppose none of us is an ever-growing behemoth”. The Grand Sorceress paused and eyed Nel for a moment. Nel asked the Sorceress if she thought Clare had headed North in search of this new source of raw magic. The Sorceress thought a moment before saying: “I do not think so, but must admit that it is an unhappy coincidence and, even if it is unknown to your friend, it surely will not remain so for long”, here the Sorceress straightened her back against the carriage seat, “—hence our journey.” Marina could not help expressing the fear that, should Clare happen upon one of these wells or vents, or, just as likely, break open a mountainside as she made her way, and, as she was wont to do, gorge herself, like some massive vampire bat, there was no telling how large or how powerful she might become. Nel could not help but imagine Clare gigantic body, rivers of sea green running from the corners of her mouth, slaking her thirst on the gushing mountainside, growing as she did so until her reared buttocks blotted out the sun and imagined Clare, belly distended, rolling over and collapsing back onto the landscape, gasping in abject euphoria as she grew more and more. “I believe”, said the Grand Sorceress, “that this is exactly Her Majesty’s concern in all this; for, you are right, should your friend”, here she nodded at Nel in the gloom,”do this, she would likely become more or less unstoppable— that is, assuming she is not already so.”

“Her body is dangerously unstable” added Marina, “magic just bounces off her; she even affects her environment around her; without even doing anything.” Marina added that it was truly scary to see Clare’s hunger drive her and she wondered if the potent magics Clare had ingested in the Alchemy Vaults had not in some way clouded a lot of her judgement and reasoning. “I was there”, went on Marina, suddenly a bit more animated, her eyes lighting up beneath her cowl, “when she guzzled all those mixtures; I thought, with the amount she ingested, that she was going to explode or rip asunder from the magic, but no,” Marina made a ballooning gesture accompanied by an excited laugh, “she just started to grow and grow and grow!” Calming down, Marina added meekly “I mean, with a body so bloated with magic, there’s no telling what she could do or what she’ll become.” Nel remained curious. The carriage rocked and Nel hit her head. “If you don’t mind me asking”, said Nel, rubbing her head, “how does Her Majesty plan to fight or control Clare? It will take a lot to stop Clare getting what Clare wants; she was stubborn even when she was yo—our size, always kind of wanting her own way, and gaining these ‘few’ extra feet and tonnes seems only to have made her worse!” The Sorceress smiled at Nel and appeared to think for a little while before answering, with a wave of her hand: “Oh, I wouldn't worry yourself about that; I am lead to believe that Her Majesty has some plan in place, some grand design, I am not aware of the specifics, but I am in no doubt your large friend (Clare was it?) will soon meet her match.”

Nel and Marina exchanged glances across the carriage as they travelled on through the clouded night sky...
1152121211212112221111212221211111121.title: Night Flight

choices: They seek shelter in the mountains...
They attempt to find the others in the mountains...
They encounter Clare!
11521212112121122211112122212111111212.content:
It was not long before Nel drifted off to sleep in the rocking carriage.

Nel did know how long she was asleep before she was awoken suddenly by the yells of the carriage drivers and the lurching of the carriage, which knocked her head against the upper side of the carriage. As Nel awoke with a start she saw Marina holding tight to the arm of her seat, while the Sorceress was standing up, her head and upper body through the latticed portal that separated the driver’s section from theirs, in an exchange in raised voices, which Nel could not make out because of the roar of the winds outside. Nel braced herself against the sides of the carriage, her arm span letting her place a palm in each side. She attempted to crane her neck to look outside. Nel saw, through the latticed windows, almost nothing but a sea of blue clouds, churning violently, here and there, into purple. Nel saw flashes of lightning somewhere in the clouds, and not long after this there came a blinding flash and the carriage was shaken horribly by a cataclysmic boom of thunder from somewhere above them.

After the thunder faded, paring down into muted booms from far-off, and just as Nel’s eyes were recovering from the bright flash of the lightning, the Sorceress, apparently unphased, slowly withdrew from the driver’s portal and sat back down, calmly readjusting her robes and bangles. She caught Nel and Marina’s inquisitive and expectant eyes and, looping a curl of hair behind her left ear, said that these peaks were known and named for their near-constant storms, but that they usually clustered around the utmost pinnacles, so this particular storm was unexpected. “I would speculate”, added the Sorceress nodding at Nel, “that your ‘little friend’s’ passing through these crags and peaks has whipped up the clouds and displaced them to the foothills— or I may be mistaken; it is just a thought.” Nel felt a little quiver in the pit of her stomach at the mention of Clare’s name again, perhaps because it impressed on her a sense of just how large Clare had become. For, Nel realised, Clare had, in some way, and despite the incoming reports from the vales and forests of her wake of destruction, remained in her head at almost two foot tall, bigger than Nel, bigger than the average pixie, as a matter of habit, built up over years of friendship. But now Nel, who was used to looking up at Clare, and had, in the past week, been equal heights and even taller than Clare, at times, had had to adjust that image of Clare to account for all that had happened in the past day or so. And, indeed, Nel had barely had the time to adjust to her own larger body, let alone accommodate thoughts of Clare’s hips and thighs at such an enormous size that she would have to squeeze and shimmy her way through these mountain passes or that lightning strikes might seem to her no more than cinders falling upon her colossal bosom. For a fleeting instant, out among the roiling blue clouds and illuminated by flashes of lightning, Nel thought she glimpsed, silhouetted like the sharp crags and spine of the mountains, the great globular cheeks of Clare’s buttocks passing like the shadow of the moon. But, of course, it was only her imagination. Nel supposed that to some extent she had not totally accepted Clare’s sudden change in stature, having been asleep for most of it, and, in a way, had not really viewed the monstrous creature heading North as Clare at all.

Nel’s musing were interrupted by a horrible crashing and snapping sound, followed, moments later the carriage violently lurching to one side and yells from outside. Nel’s head banged against the roof again, dazing her awfully, while Marina, who was sat opposite, was flung forward suddenly and, much to both their embarrassment, landed abruptly on Nel, her face planted between Nel’s breasts, landing with a sort of flump sound. Nel, surprised and still dazed, extricated the young Alchemist sheepishly. Words were not exchanged, however, for at that moment another crash came and next thing any of the knew the carriage was sent barrelling through the night sky and storm clouds, throwing all inside the carriage into utter confusion. Nel was dimly conscious of the driver’s cursing and another flash of lightning, before the carriage spun again and, before she could react, she was knocked unconscious…

While she was unconscious Nel found herself in the midst of some strange dreams. For a while she dreamt that she was in a castle by the sea, the masonry green with age. For a while she sat with Clare in a massive vaulted room, at a table laid for dinner, groaning with food and drink, yet the room, and the castle were deserted. Nel tried to engage Clare in conversation, but Clare shushed her and smiled blithely. As Nel dreamt Clare reached forward and plucked a large fruit from the table, like a fat peach. Still smiling Clare sank her teeth into the fruit, the juice running down her mouth. Nel remembered that after Clare chewed and swallowed her body quivered for a moment before plumping up in size a fraction. Clare only smiled at Nel, not wiping the pulp from her mouth, and offered Nel a bite. As she did so the tawny pixie plumped up in height again. Nel got up from the stone chair as it happened again and, as Clare rose from her own chair wearing a concerned look, it happened again. Nel quickled back away and turned to flee. Nel could here Clare’s voice echoing: “Where you going Nellie?”As she left the hall she looked back to see Clare, whose face seemed confused and hurt, blow up again. As Nel fled through a doorway she suddenly passed between a taller Clare’s legs. “Hey, Nellie”. As Nel fluttered up a staircase lined with large stone statues all of a sudden one crumbled as an even larger Clare shook herself off. Nel quickly reached the top of the stairs and flitted down a corridor, turning at the end to see a much larger Clare filling the hallway, like an enormous cat. Clare giggled: “Haha, Boo!” Nel turned on her heels and shot back down the corridor to the louden calls of “Nellie!” Nel reached a door and, closing it behind her, breathed deeply until Clare’s voice died away. Nel climbed the stairs before her until she was standing at the top of a turret, gazing out at the vastness of the sea, which seemed, in her dream, to have no limit and just rolled on and on. Nel remembered, after she awoke, that she could look down and see the lower spires of the castle, the long stone bridge reaching to the mainland and the sheet drop down to the foaming waves and skerries below. But before long Nel felt the castle and the ground shaking as there rose, eclipsing Nel’s view of the sea, Clare’s colossal, tawny head; it alone was bigger than the castle in which Nel stood. Nel could only stand, light blotted out, as Clare’s gigantic green eye peered into the castle, which was no more than a grape to her. Nel fled inside the castle, down a flight of spiral stairs, as Clare’s head rose higher and higher and the foundations and masonry of the castle began to tremble and then to shake, crumbling about Nel. Nel arrive in the castle courtyard and looked up at the trunk of Clare’s neck and up at the underside of her jaw, up over the battlements and ramparts, and saw the slope of her shoulders and collar bones beginning to hove into view. Nel remembered, at the end of this dream, seeing the ground, the sheet of stone bricks, beginning to bulge and warp beneath her feet. She panicked as she saw, beyond the stone gates, the masonry of the bridge crumbling as there swelled up from beneath something huge and milk-white, like an enormous boiled egg. Nel started awake as she saw the cobbles erupting beneath her, leaping up to reveal creamy flesh bulging up from below, and the courtyard splitting as there opened up a great chasm, rending the castle asunder. Nel tried to fly, but found herself transfixed by the abyss yawning below her feet. The last thing she retained, as Clare’s gigantic breasts swelled up, swallowing the castle, was Clare’s booming laughter from on high.

When Nel awoke, she came to in the carriage, which appeared to be lying on its side and had snow spilling in. There was no sign of the Sorceress, the driver or the little Alchemist. Nel lay there for a moment, before slowly getting up and promptly hit her head off the other wall, now the roof. Cursing loudly, Nel forced open the door against which she had just hit her head, deciding that to try and squeeze through the driver’s window would be an exercise in futility, for not even her chest would make it through. Nel emerged into the nighttime mountainside, blinking her long-lashed eyes as the flakes of snow drifted by. There was no sign of the driver or the birds, to Nel’s dismay. She called ought, but found her voice whipped away by the gusts. Nel sighed and shivered when she heard something bumping and scraping from beneath the carriage. Nel leaned forward and peered over the edge of the carriage. She saw, emerging from the underneath the carriage, a pointy-hatted figure dragging a huge trunk. Nel recognised it soon, through the drifting snow, as Marina the little Alchemist, shorn, apparently, of her hooded robes and now garbed in the apparel brought with them, more appropriate the the mountain climes.

Nel hauled herself from the carriage, her hips only becoming stuck for a moment, and fluttered down beside the girl below, who started, but quickly collected herself. She remained shy and withdrawn though as Nel asked her if she’d seen the others. When the answer was negative, Nel, who was quickly beginning to freeze in her thin, tightly-drawn dress, began to search the trunk for suitable clothes. Marina cast around them as Nel did this, rather than have to make eye-contact with Nel’s chest and her nipples poking out beneath the fabric like thimbles. Marina looked up at the jagged pinnacles of the mountains, and at the snow blowing past, it seemed like the storm was liable to get worse...
11521212112121122211112122212111111212.title: A storm in a teacup

choices: It is a deep magic vent...
It is an abandoned mining village...
It is a massive hoard of dragon's treasure...
115212121121211222111121222121111112121.content:
The two of them, the young alchemist Marina, coated and hatted, and Nel, still in the red dress she had worn from the Palace, stood on the snowy slopes for a while, both of them wondering what their next move should be. Presently, Nel rooted in the trunk for warmer clothes, while Marina thought. Once Nel was dressed in clothing more suitable to the mountain climes, the pair of them set off up the narrow and winding path, leaving behind them the wrecked carriage. Nel took the opportunity, despite the snow, to occasionally take in the scenery, for she had never been so far North as this and had only ever glimpses these mountains from far away, like arrowheads lining the sky. Nel was in awe at the spiralling pinnacles of the mountain peaks about them, think and jagged like spearheads or the spires of gigantic temples long ago buried. It struck Nel, as they climbed higher, that the peaks, each in themselves, resembles massive, grey conch shells in the way their conical edifices bore jagged horns and spikes of rock, jutting out at extreme angles to the rockface.
As they walked, there was no sign of the Grand Sorceress, the driver or any of the others. Marina thought that they may have been blown onto a neighbouring peak. The path Nel and Marina followed wound like a thread up one of these peaks and they were luckily sheltered from the gusts that would surely have picked either of them up and thrown them from the mountainside. Marina walked ahead carefully and Nel, who hitherto had not really had a chance to notice the young alchemist, noted her dainty feet in her high-boots and the way she almost sprung forward on her little heels with a click. Nel had to admitted she had not, in the gloom of the carriage, previously been able to see Marina clearly, swaddled in the robe as she’d been, but now, walking before Nel in her britches, long coat and large hat, which she clamped down over her brow and ears with a hand, she saw the girl’s her skinny legs, her slight hips, her small chest like a dove’s. The young Alchemist seemed to Nel so fragile in comparison to the rugged and icy slopes they were ascending. And it was not until later, when Marina turned to indicate to Nel a cave some way off and a gust caught her hat, blowing it back from her face, that Nel even caught site of the girl’s features. Through the blur of powdery snow Nel noticed the delicate heart-shaped face, the skin almost as pale as the snow whirling about them, the bow-shaped mouth underneath the arrowhead nose. Nel could not, at such a remove, make out the colour of the girl’s gloomy and melancholy eyes however, which seemed to hover undecidedly grey and violet. The girl’s hair however, a few strands of which whipped across her face, was a dark greenish colour, verging on turquoise art its lightest. The girl reminded her of herself in a way, although Nel had never been so slight or, for that matter, so small. Nel found herself wondering, as she climbed, how Marina felt about all this business involving pixies growing to many times their original height. Her composite assembled, Nel felt like she knew her companion a bit better than she had done down on the mountain slopes, although that could not really be true.

It was half an hour before they reached the mouth of the cave. Scarcely had they entered and walked some way into the cave, away from the howling snows outside, than the entirely mountainside quaked, knocking both Marina and Nel from their feet. By the time either of them gathered their wits they were in darkness; the quake had sent snow and ice down from the peaks, covering the entrance; they were stuck. Nel heard Marina’s voice from somewhere in the darkness: “Oh…still, I’d rather be stuck in here than frostbitten out there.” Nel stood up and said: “But what about the others?” She heard rummaging from nearby and though she could distinguish the young alchemist rooting in the bag she had taken with her from the carriage. “Not a lot we can do” came Marina’s voice. “What was that”, said Nel, casting around the cave, but seeing nothing but darkness, “an earthquake?” Marina’s voice was somewhat muffled, as if she was disappearing into the bag: “Hmmm….I’m not really so sure.” Nel sought the young alchemist in the blackness, but appeared to have lost her: “What do you think it was?” Marina’s voice was clear again and Nel managed to guess where she was again: “I’m not saying it wasn’t a quake…I just think that it’s far more likely to have been your friend making her way among the peaks.” “You think?...Well, Clare needs to watch where she’s going”, Nel muttered, “the giant klutz.”
Nel waited for some time while Marina rooted; at one point there was a splashing sound and a caustic, oily smell. “You’re not near me are you?” came Marina’s voice finally. “I don’t think so” said Nel. There was a brief pause before Nel heard a tinkle of glass and suddenly a plume of bluish fire erupted in the darkness. Nel jumped, startled. Marina laughed and held up the torch she’d lit. “Witchfire” she said simply and, gesturing with her head, indicated that they should proceed further into the cave. As they explored they talked quietly; Marina said that many of these tunnels were created by miners, but were based on boring done by the ancient frost dragons which had lived in these peaks, but were now thought to be extinct; they were, however, seldom entirely uninhabited. It transpired that Marina was from the North, from a small village at the foot of these ranges, and had only left in order to study Alchemy in the pixie heartlands. The Gosburgs, for that was Marina’s family, were, so Nel was told, actually quite an aristocratic family, her father was a Baron. Nel expressed some surprise at this: “So you’re an heiress?” Marina laughed a bitter laugh: “No exactly, my older brother and sister will likely inherit our estate and the house.” Marina did however express some regret at having left this life behind: “I just thought that maybe becoming a respected alchemist under the Empress might get the people of my hometown to take me seriously”, Marina appeared to scrutinise a stalactite, “no-one takes me that seriously; they all treat me like I am a child.” Nel coughed and changed the subject, asking what Marina’s thoughts were on the whole situation that had lead them here. “Well, I’m not stranger to giants...there are frost giants living in these mountains, but usually they sleep.” “But from what people say”, Nel chimed in, “Clare’s not just giant, she’s enormous!” Marina coughed this time, “But anyway, despite her recklessness, your friend is a kind of walking alchemical miracle. And that’s, in its own scary way, kind of fascinating.” “Of course”, Marina went on dreamily, “wondrous and terrifying though she is, she probably needs to be stopped.” Nel thought for a moment, imagining briefly Clare’s monstrous hips and buttocks squeezing between the mountains. “How does the Empress plan to stop Clare?” asked Nel presently. Marina shrugged in the half-light “I’m not certain really; all I know is that I was brought along because I know these mountains well enough and that there are massive pockets of magical rock and magic in these mountains, which are almost porous, and sit like a thick crust upon vast wells, vents and oceans on sea-green magic.” Marina waggled the torch, “You can see it leaking out sometimes on the slopes, it hardens into crystals quickly though. That’s why there are mines and tunnels all over these mountains, to extract the magic imbued ores and rocks. It was the only industry really for towns in the North.” They walked on for a bit, “I have to say, though,” said Marina, “I did think a lot of these mines were exhausted and what magic was reachable to be mostly depleted. I’ve only seem magic in its raw state a few times and not recently…not that it’s much use like that…only dangerous.” Nel decided not to mention that she too had grown from ingesting raw, volatile magic like Clare. “Do you think,” ventured Nel, “that Clare is after the magic in the mountains?” Marina thought for a moment, “I don’t see how she’d know to look for it here; as I say, a lot of the mines are abandoned now. I think Empress thinks Clare is looking for magic though, or at the very least wants to stop her before she discovers any more by accident…I admit it’s a bad coincidence that your friend headed North. Maybe she can smell it?” Nel shuddered a little at the mental image of Clare feasting on a mountaintop like an ice-cream cone, her tongue licking up a plume of frosty sea-green. They walked on for perhaps an hour, in comparative silence. Suddenly, Nel, even as she thought of the sea-green glow of Clare’s eyes, thought she imagined a glow from a crack in the tunnel wall. Nel halted and Marina, who had been examining the glossy rock walls, ran straight into Nel’s cushiony ass and fell backwards. Nel, oblivious, inspected it and tried to see though, but could see nothing but the dim green glow. “Hey! Watch it!” fumed Marina. Nel apologised and beckoned her closer: “Look, what’s this?” Marina got up and came over, her interest piqued. “Hmmm, looks like…” began Marina, before Nel chipped in: “I bet you can squeeze through this gap.” Marina gave Nel a look up and down. “Go on,” Nel said, “you’re smaller than me”, managing to conceal her pleasure at being able to say that sentence. Marina gave Nel the torch and slipped into the crack. It was some time before Nel heard from her on the other side of the wall. After an eternity’s wait, Nel heard Marina say: “Well I’ll be …”
115212121121211222111121222121111112121.title: We may be some time...

choices: Nel waits and soon hears a rumbling from below...
Nel waits, but in vain; Marina seems to be gone...
Nel ventures down into the ca
1152121211212112221111212221211111121211.content:
Nel could not contain her curiosity any longer and lay down on the ground, attempting to squeeze through the gap at the crack’s bottom. She wormed her way through as Marina said from the other side: “This is unbelievable…” Nel’s head, arms, shoulders and, with great strain, her chest made it through the crack and the rest of her body was coming too when her hips wedged, with a sound like someone trying to tie a balloon. Nel looked back frustration, but quickly returned her gaze to room she had only partly entered. The room was some kind of cavern, only Nel could not, at least from her prone position, see the ceiling of the cavern, the walls just stretching up into impenetrable gloom. The walls in themselves were something to behold; they were glossy, as if worn smooth, like blobs of glass in the tides, and stretched up like sheets of dark emerald from below. The cavern was, unlike the tunnel adjoining, lit by a kind of eerie green glow and Nel fancied she saw wisps of turquoise vapour floating upwards. Marina, whom Nel now saw was standing at the lip of what appeared to be a ledge, was illuminated by the sea-green glow, her pale cheeks lit up as she peered over the edge in wonderment. Nel snapped out of her reverie and tried to free herself. Grunting, she placed her hands at either side of her and tried to pull herself loose. Marina, too, dragged herself away from the edge and tried to tug Nel free. There elapsed a spell of time when both girls considered Nel to be drastically stuck and there was even talk of Marina leaving Nel wedged there and attempting either to find a way around to pull Nel back or to find someone or something else to help extricate Nel. As it happened, the girls decided to give it one more go and between them, with a herculean effort, succeeded in dislodging Nel from the crack in the wall, sending both girls tumbling to the floor, Nel landing on top of Marina as they did so. Nel whined and rubbed her butt-cheeks, before hearing the frantic and muffled cries from beneath her chest. Nel quickly scrambled to her feet, letting Marina sit up, panting. Nel, embarrassed, apologised and while the girl caught her breath Nel walked to the edge to look down.
Gazing down from the ledge Nel saw great streamers of sea-green light rising up from the deep, deep below them. At the bottom of this shaft or charm Nel fancied, for the green was almost too intense to see through, she saw a pool of something, almost like turquoise lava. The streams of green vapour and tapers of light seemed to emanate from down there, rising up, past their ledge, and drifting upwards to the invisible ceiling. Most curious of all this, Nel thought, was the way the light below seemed to pulse and flow, like a heartbeat or a breath. Nel turned to back to Marina who was approaching again: “I take it this is—“, she began, before Marina finished, “Yes…magic”. Marina laughed a little and dragged her hand through the air, leaving behind it little sparks. “Wow,” said Nel, “I’ve never seen anything like this!” Marina peered over the edge again and said: “Neither have I! I knew there were vents in these mountains, but nothing like this! It looks like it goes down to well below the mountain.” Marina pointed towards where there seemed to be a bottom and a most intense sea-green light. She was excited by what she might see of the pixie village and herself, imagining herself looming over the delicately slated rooftops, with her fat hips wedged in between the houses and her breath gently pulling in the thin plumes of smoke from the chimney stacks, like the wind across a field of rippling wheat. As she planted her hands on either side of the upper story of the house which she had outgrown, Nel dwelt on the still lingering sensation of growing, mingled, in no small part, with the orgasmic pleasure of feeling Kevin between her thighs. Nel, her eyes closed, tugged at the structure stuck on her head, but it was stuck, such was the speed with which, and extent to which, she had grown! Nel thought she could see through the fine and tiny lattice of a window in the attic, or perhaps it was a bedroom, with her left eye, welled up massive and green inside the roofspace, and she blinked a few times to try and make sense of the the blurred and splintered images she could see through this small pane like a great, bloated cyclops. Nel tugged again at the roofing while she imagined herself sitting in the rubble of the house, her legs stretching out in front of her, proceeding for some way down the street and her heart almost skipped a beat as she fancied she already felt the dimpled cobbled streets beneath her thighs and calves. Nel, becoming impatient, yanked again at the structure covering her head. Her last growth spurt, her biggest to date, had left her inwardly thrilled and she could not wait to see how big and voluptuous she had become! The memory of her body pumping up, of her chest bulging outwards cartoonishly, her legs seeming further and further away, of her head suddenly clipping the ceiling, before feeling her shoulders and back, arching ever more, running along that same ceiling, of her arms lengthening from sight as the round flesh of her arm swelled to fill a hallway, or the unforgettable feeling of her buttocks billowing beneath her, seeming to buoy her up and up! Oh, the sensation of feeling one’s cheeks bloating up like that, underneath you, positively eating up the space they had to contain them, and all the while your head climbing higher while they undulate beneath you; it was a small wonder that Nel’s hips and butt cheeks had blown out the foundations of the house, sending her legs flopping out into the street, before ever her long arms had erupted or her shoulders, torso or bosom burst forth from the house. And, as she pulled at the house, wincing at the splinters of timber pricking her neck and face, but smiling at the bits of masonry tumbling onto, and bouncing off her shoulders and, no doubt, monstrous breasts, Nel could not help but wish, though she must have known she could not be THAT large, to see herself sitting amongst a cluster of houses, each no more than a thimble to her, and nor could she help but indulge fantasies of growing again, until her chest and buttocks hung above the world like the Moon! Nel gritted her teeth and pulled again...

Nel wrenched the roof from her head in a profusion of wild blue hair. For a moment, holding the roofing between her hands in her lap, Nel blinked rapidly as her eyes adjusted to the evening light and her cheeks apple pink from exertion. As the scene about her emerged from the cataclysm of light engulfing it, Nel looked about her. “Aha!” Nel tossed the remains of the house across the rooftops in glee. She saw herself easily head and shoulders above the houses. Saw her legs filling up the cobbled street and, running a hand down her side, found her hips squashed between the neighbouring houses, which brought a smile to her lips. Nel must be fully ten times her previous size! She was huge! Nel looked at herself, up and down, and guessed she must be at least, at least, twice the size of the average human, an amazonian figure of a pixie, perhaps somewhere between ten and fifteen feet. Looking at herself now, Nel was left in no doubt in her own mind that she was in the upper limit of that estimate, and, although this was maybe only wishy thinking, she wondered if she were not, in fact, larger. Only a flicker of disappointment crossed Nel’s mind and dampened her apparent elation at her size, although, it must be said, one was left wondering if Nel would have been satisfied with any size. Nel felt something tickling her right inner thigh and, clasping and parting the bulge of her breasts, looked down to see a dripping and exhausted Kevin propped against the round wall of her thigh, having, apparently extracted himself from underneath her newly grown haunches. Kevin, glistening even in the shade cast by Nel, looked up at Nel’s face, but could not see her shrouded face for the immense balcony of sweaty flesh wobbling above. “Why hello there!”, chimed Nel, peering down a Kevin between her legs, “I’m so glad I didn’t squash you...well, didn’t squash you much!” she added with a coy wink. Kevin managed to pant a “yeah” as he put his hands on his knees and breathed deeply. Nel looked down at Kevin and grinned: “Hey there little man! Alright down there?” Kevin, still breathing heavily, did his best to nod. Nel, oblivious, for she was not the one to have a friend growing on top of her, looked at herself again with an air of a connoisseur and went on: “Wow! You really know what you’re doing down there!“ Nel hefted her plump bosom and waggled her hips. Kevin stumbled a bit and leaned back against the plushy warmth of Nel’s thigh, a grin on his face such as one might find on the face of an architect who, having spent many sleepless nights planning and overseeing construction, finally sees his design brought to fruition. Nel lowered her voice to a husky tone, raising an eyebrow, and breathed “What do you say, big boy, are you ready for round two?” Kevin’s grin waned. Nel laughed, “I’m only kidding Kev, you have no sense of humour!”

But it was around the same time as this that Nel, who was somewhat absorb in comparing herself —to her friend, became conscious of a chill spreading across her back. Nel saw a long dark shadow spreading across the cobbled streets and across the rooftops, like a darkening thundercloud. Kevin’s eyes were wide with panic and Nel’s heart sank and did not need to turn around to know what it was: it was Clare. Nel had, in the midst of her fantasies about growing, become so carried away she had, at least for a moment, forgotten about Clare! Nel did her best to swivel in the gap between the houses to look up at Clare. To her dismay, Nel found herself looking up and up and up at Clare and Nel wondered if the tawny-haired pixie had not, in the time that herself and Kevin had hidden in the house, grown even larger! For Clare still seemed enormous compared to Nel, standing over her like some massive tower. Nel could feel Clare’s breath like a hot, sweet smelling wind flowing over her. Nel wriggled a bit in her predicament, trying to unstick her hips, but swivelled around again to look into Clare’s vast green eyes. “Hmmm” boomed Clare, almost in an air of disappointment, “you aren’t exactly very big, are you Nellie?” At this Nel fumed, although compared to Clare at this point it was undeniable. “I was kind of hoping” continued the titanic Clare as she descended to her knees, making to lie down on her front, heedless of anything beneath her, “that you might be a bit bigger next time I saw you! I need a playmate...” Nel panicked as, for an instant, she thought Clare might carelessly squash her and Kevin underneath her monstrous chest as she lay down. “Everyone’s running away from me, you see”, Clare went on, “apparently I’m too rough!” “But, I’m just”, boomed Clare and she paused as she lay down on her front, upon the gigantic cushion of her bosom, which seemed the throb warmly behind Nel, “ a BIG kid really!” Nel waggled her hips again and shot a look at Kevin who slipped under her leg and began trying to tug her free. “I must say I was hoping you’d be a bit bigger than this though!”, thundered Clare, seemingly unaware of Nel’s efforts, “I was sort of hoping for, I don’t know, a Clarezilla versus Mega Nel! Or maybe Boobzilla versus Assasaurus... a clash of the Tit-ans!” The massive Clare shrieked with laughter, her mammoth chest rapidly swelling and falling from her laughing. In fact, such was the extent of this undulation, that Clare’s chest collided with Nel unwittingly, unsticking her!

While Clare was still distracted by how funny she found herself, Nel, thinking quickly, scooped up Kevin from where he lay a bit dazed and, glancing back beat her wings and took off, Kevin in hand, at an incredible speed, flying low over the buildings, her tits catching at chimney stack as she flew. Clare’s laughter ceased and she wiped a tear from her eye as she sighed:“But don’t worry Nellie, I’m sure I can still have fun with—HEY!” Clare shrieked in frustration, her huge arm slamming in front of her, so long that it crashed down a couple of hundred yards from the airborne Nel and Kevin. But Clare’s size became, or that moment, her disadvantage as she heaved her gigantic body up from the ground with a cataclysmic crunching, taking masonry and buildings with her!
