115212121121211222122122211.content:
As she skimmed over the fields of reeds outlying the pixie village, Nel, Kevin clasped in one hand, cast a quick glance back to see Clare, seeming gigantic compared to the houses they were fast leaving behind, attempting and straining to heft the enormous bulk of herself upright; she was not used to her new body yet and Nel was thankful for it. Nel’s last image of Clare, before she and Kevin reached the woods, was of her friend standing upright, silhouetted against the cloudy sky and bits of the village still falling from about her body. Nel reached the brink of the woods and landed, running swiftly, borne along by the beats of her wings, between the dark trunks...

Nel must have fled for hours through the trees, into the woods which stretched for who knew how far across the mountainsides. Kevin, who was clutched like doll between Nel’s fingers and held to her warm and bobbing chest, in fact, began to feel quite ill from the motion. S it came to pass that Nel, deciding she had lost Clare, sat down on a mossy stone in a glade, Kevin standing on her knee. They must have presented a curious sight to woodlanders: Kevin, a smidgeon over a foot in height, and Nel, more pointedly, who was, let it be not forgotten, while dwarfed by Clare, was considerable in her size now and stood several heads taller than a human now, a stature more commensurate with a woodland bear or mountain troll than a pixie! Yet Nel’s mood was low and she sat upon the rock with her cheeks in her hands. It had begun to rain and the droplets ran down Nel’s nose and quivered on the end like icicles. Kevin, by contrast, was in rather high spirts, still buzzing from their getaway, notwithstanding his momentary lapse into motion sickness. “I was like: “Noooo!” and you were like: Swish and Nyyyyeeerrm” and Clare was like “Raaaarrrrgghh!”” Kevin fluttered from one knee to the other. “And when her arm came down! It was like: “KaBOOM!””, Kevin did a hurling motion with his own arm, “but you were like: “Not today Bitchzilla annnd awaaay we go!”” Nel smiled in spite of her mood, “That’s how it happened did it?” Kevin put his hands on his hips, facing away, towards the trees: “Yup, just like that.” He paused for a moment, apparently thinking. Nel eyes rested on the little man standing on her knee lazily. She sighed. Kevin shook his head and turned around, for a moment forgetting that Nel was not behind him proper and he was instead standing on her, and was a little taken aback at having accidentally gazed into the large chasm of her cleavage. He blushed a touch and looked up at Nel’s rainstreaked face. Her hair was wet from the rain and looked, to him, perched on her knee, like the curtain of a willow tree. Nel blinked slowly, still low, and Kevin swiped a droplet away from her nose. Nel giggled in spite of herself. Kevin then asked “What now then, Miss Nel?” Nel, her face still in her hands, shrugged: “Dunno…you tell me little man”. Kevin walked up and down Nel’s thigh as if it were the deck of a ship. “It goes without saying,” he finally said, “that we can’t just let Clare run amok.” Nel sighed: “I suppose not, no…”, Nel looked away for a moment, “but I don’t see what we can do.” Kevin’s stopped pacing for a bit and then resumed: “Well we have to do something, anything; what’s go into her? She’s out of control! Carrying on the way she is there’s no telling what she’ll do! Who she might hurt. Or—”. Kevin halted a second, “How big she’ll get…” finished Nel. There was a moment wherein they both dwelt on the prospect. Kevin imagined Clare’s mind, after she had ceased to have fun and explore her new size, would turn to taking over the pixie kingdom with her newfound stature, but, before long, would subjugate kingdom after kingdom, she would, most likely, threaten the world of man too, laying waste to their glass cities, until eventually, having grown and grown with each new conquest, enthroning herself on the mountains to the North, her colossal rear comfortably filling the mountainside, the clouds sitting about her head and shoulders like a mantle. Nel, whose imagination tended naturally towards a somewhat larger scale imagined Clare, in the event she was not stopped, growing and growing until she resembled more a continent than a pixie, one which would quake from time to time as it expanded more and more, until Clare could sit upon a continent as Nel sat upon this mossy rock, perhaps until Clare could hold the planet as no more than an apple in her hand. Both of them shuddered a little.

“Well”, said Kevin boldly and matter-of-factly, “you’ll just have to get big too!” Nel did not really react. “Fight fire with fire; It looks like our best option right now”, Kevin went on, ‘Clare won’t be able to push around a pixie just as big as herself!” Nel sighed again and looped a strand of hair behind her ear: “I don’t think I CAN get that big”, she said gloomily, “it doesn’t look like I have the same reaction as Clare to all that alchemy”. Kevin laughed, “You got this big didn’t you?” Nel shrugged moodily, “still wasn’t big enough was it?” Nel looked at herself for a moment before adding: “it might just be easier to try and make her smaller.” “Maybe whatever happened to the pair of you has just affected you differently? The results seem the same to me” said Kevin as he touched Nel’s forearm a moment (he would have shaken her gently in reassurance, but at her Amazonian stature it was out of the question). “Look, I’m sure the Empress and her court will try their own, maybe better, plans to stop Clare, but this is OUR best shot.” Nel laughed a fraction as Kevin strode to the prow of Nel’s knee again. “Besides, whatever it is that makes Clare react this way to magic can’t be the only way of making a lovely young pixie into a towering giant!” Kevin was on something of a roll now and Nel smiled as he became more lively and animated as he spoke, even as the storm intensified above the woodland canopy. “Okay, so Clare just grows and grows, so what? Nel, my girl, and we can’t afford to stand around here and wait for Nature to talk its course and have her way with you, while even as we sit here Clare strides across the landscape getting taller and taller! We have to give you an edge.” Kevin, with a wild and excited look in his eye, slicked back his hair: “I say to hell with Nature then! If she won’t give us a Nel big enough to stop Clare, then we’ll just have to explore other options! We’ll find unnatural means: the world of man and the world magic and the ancient secrets of the world must have something. Let’s create our own options, by any means we can! Let’s make you giant, Nel! No, huge!” Kevin turned and caught her eye, there was a slightly crazed look in his eye: “Let’s make you….a monster!”
As Kevin said this there came, for above, a flash of lightning. As the thunder faded, the two pixies, one large and one small, looked at each other. It was another few moments before both Nel and Kevin erupted in laughter. It was some time before either of them could talk. Nel composed herself and said: “Well, Doctor Kevinstein, if I’m to be your monster…make me big!” Kevin admitted that he had not thought so far ahead as to say how they might actually go about making Nel into a giant: “Good timing with this storm though” he laughed. Nel agreed with a smile. They sat for some time in the rain in silence. “I think we should get out of the rain; I am butt-naked in the woods and this rock is starting to freeze my ass solid” said Nel looking up. Kevin nodded, looking away and rearranging his shorts. “I’ll think of something” Kevin said. Turning he added, “To that end, and the end of finding something to help us, I suggest we head deeper into the woods, maybe there’s a cave or something we can shelter in?” Nel looked at the briars and the darkness of the woods and made a hesitant sound. Kevin laughed: “What’s a big girl like you got to be afraid of?” Nel furrowed her brow: “Well, apart from even bigger girls…all sorts of things…dragons…evil trees…grazing my boobs on spiky branches…” she said hefting her bosom with both hands. Kevin added that those two sounded like the same things. “Well,” said Kevin, “if everything works out, you sure as hell won’t be having to worry about spiky branches!” Nel sighed and stood up, waggling her numb ass-cheeks, Kevin fluttered up as she did so, hovering at her hip height as he looked around. “I guess it doesn’t matter which way we go now, just so long as you don’t—“, Nel playfully grabbed him out of the air and walked into the deep, dark woods to the sound of his protests...

1152121211212112221221222112.content:
Frankly, Nel did not consider herself a lucky person. She always lost at games of chance and Nel’s recent run of luck had been true to form. Perhaps most recent was the travesty that meant although Clare and herself had occupied, for the briefest of times, the same bottle of alchemical mixture it was somehow Clare who had grown the most! Nel had always wished to be bigger, maybe just to have the edge on Clare. But it was only Nel’s luck that would have her grow big (bigger than a lot of pixies and then bigger than a lot of humans) but only at the cost of making Clare many, many times bigger than her!
And Nel’s run of bad luck was continuing now for, some hours later, Nel and Kevin were still attempting to find shelter from the storm. Far from stumbling across any means to grow Nel, they had quickly become hopelessly lost in the tangle of trunks and soon the storm had worsened, so that the wind blew the rain through the canopy of leaves and made their going cold and uncomfortable. Manoeuvring the forest in the dark at Nel’s size was not easy: she found head permanently becoming snagged on branches; sometimes unable to see her feet, she could not always see where she was treading or what she was stepping on; she had stumbled more than few times and knocked over small trees, meaning she had to then lift them from their path and, nightmare of nightmares, she had just been caught on the tit by a flailing briar. It gave Nel little joy, as she stood in that rain-sodden forest, to think that one day she might be able to crush this forest under her foot. Nel’s exposed flesh was by now covered in gooseflesh and she shivered in the icy rain as they cast about for a direction to head. She drew a wet strand of hair from her eye and rubbed her boob as the thunder crashed above again. Kevin returned from thicket and fluttered up to Nel’s ear and had to shout to be heard that there wasn’t anything that way, save a deep ravine. Nel advance in another direction, swiping aside branches as she went. Lightning flashed above their heads again, through the thinned canopy above. They would have, thought Nel, been better off deeper in the woods, not skirting these mountainsides looking for a cave. Nel was tempted to turn back when she saw, by the light of another flash from on high, a break in the trees, a tract of mountainside clear of trees. Nel could see the trees on the other side and the mountain reaching high above them. She sought Kevin in the gloom and gestured to what looked like a cabin or a cottage in the midst of this clearing, surrounded by a little copse of trees. Kevin nodded and fluttered ahead. Nel, unable to fly from exhaustion and cold, peeled a large leaf from her butt-cheek, where it had stuck for a while, and trudged out from the trees, pushing aside a rotten trunk on her way as the lightning glowed again. Nel had never been afraid of lightning really. She used to love sitting at her open window, on nights not unlike this one, and watch, wide-eyed, as the white forks flashed across the sky. Nel thought of that glorious, pensive silence between the lightning and the rumble of the thunder. Nel could see Kevin ahead of her, just about, as she walked across the clearing. Nel felt sure that she could see lights on in the forest cottage, but her rain-soaked her was in her eyes again. She paused to wipe her hair back, standing up tall as she did so. Given the chances of such a thing happening, it must have been a weird sort of luck, or the worst kind of bad luck, that meant Nel, as she stood in the field, herself maybe as tall as a smallish tree, was suddenly struck by a jolt of lightning! Nel was only fleetingly aware of a blinding flash, a horrific crash, and a screaming sound before her world turned black…

The world started to swim back into view for Nel, the woozy colours, greys, whites, inky blues and dim shapes slowly coalescing and began to resolve themselves, as if Nel were passing upwards through the fathoms of grey, marine light, beneath the surface and chopping waves of a storm-wracked sea. At first, it seemed as if she were looking up at a sheet of wet and rock, then at an expanse of marsh, but as Nel’s wits returned to her and her vision grew better, she soon found that she was outstretched, supine on her back with her face to the sky above. Clouds were still mottling the sky, though the worst of the storm seemed to have passed. Spots of rain were still falling from the sky and landing on Nel’s cheeks, and though she blinked, Nel could not bear to move. For not long after she had regained consciousness Nel was soon made conscious of the aching on her body, throbbing across all her limbs, down to the tips of her toes and her fingers. Nel groaned and closed her eyes, gritting her teeth as she suffered another wave of pain.

https://www.femcafe.hu/sites/default/fil...

Nel’s memory was still a little foggy; she remembered standing in the field near the woods, and dimly recalled a sudden flash, but thereafter could remember nothing. It felt like she’d been hit by an automobile, or perhaps a train, but she suspected that she had been struck by lightning. If so, was it any wonder that she was in such pain, indeed, there being no sign of Kevin, as far as she could tell, it was safe to assume that the force of the bolt had flung Nel some distance from the field, where she now lay bruised, singed and aching. Nel opened her eyes again and lay looking at the sky, a veil of misty cloud was passing by wherever she lay and raindrops pearled on her long eyelashes before she blinked them away. Nel used what little will she had to move her fingers, trying to feel about her as a lobster might probe the cavernous darkness of the seabed with long antennae. She could feel the damp grass about her, and feel it beneath her prostrated body Summoning what seemed like all her strength, Nel ran her hands lightly over the grass. As she did so, Nel’s fingers found and felt a smooth lozenge, about the size of a domino. Still lying down, Nel ran her thumb across the flat oblong lozenge she’d unearthed from the grass. Placing it down, Nel almost immediately found another such flat pebble among the grasses; running her hands still further abroad reveals another and another, some upturned and others lying ensconced in the earth. Reaching out and lifting her arm with some effort Nel could feel stiff ferns about her, bristly and wet with the rain.

Gently Nel left her hand fall from the ferns and drew it back to her side, rippling across the smooth pebbles. As feeling returned to her body, Nel was becoming ever more conscious of discomfort around her buttocks, running in a line across her backside and nettling her as she lay there, as if she were lying upon the thorny tresses of some briar. Nel shifted where she lay, waggling her rump, but did not succeed in dislodging whatever she had landed on. Nel could hear something squeaking nearby, like the cry of a bird or mouse. With some difficulty, Nel planted her hands by her sides and, after a couple of abortive attempts, managed to heave herself upright, groaning rheumatically as she did so. Nel’s head swam and, drawing her knees up, she rested her head on them, her vision bursting in patches of oily light as blood rushed to her head. Still feeling the rain falling on her naked shoulders, Nel raised her head and looked blearily about her.

Initially Nel could not quite come to terms with what she saw about her where she had awoken, she fancied for a moment that she had been hurled skywards and landed in a neighbouring pixie settlement, but suddenly the reality broken in upon her like a parting of the clouds. She had landed in a churchyard, lined with trees and an adjoining cemetery of array stones, and a modest-looking church, its tapering steeple crested with a creaking weathervane. But what caught Nel’s attention most, and what made her suddenly clutch her knees with surprise, was that the tombstones arranged in rows across the grass seemed like small, smooth pebbles, the conifers along the graveled paths, through which the misty rain drifted, looked like wet ferns growing alongside a mountain path and the church itself was like a large and well-made doll’s house, with arrowhead windows and a thimble-sized bell hanging in the steeple tower; indeed, what suddenly dawned on Nel was that, though she did not know where she had been hurled by the lightning bolt that had struck her, or where, for that matter, where Kevin was, she had grown!

Indeed, such was the shock of this to her, that Nel suddenly found herself alert and casting about her, having released her legs, in spite of the dull aching throughout her body. Heedless of the rain gradually wetting her hair and skin, Nel gingerly ran her hands across the treetops once more. Before she lost consciousness during the storm, following the spurts she’d undergone back in the pixie village, Nel had been much the same size as a rather tall human, which was certainly large enough for a pixie, and arguably to be considered exceptionally busty and curvy for any creature, but now Nel sat upon her haunches in the churchyard as veritable giantess to humans, her huge green eyes were practically level with the creaking weathervane and a person who might previously have been able to bury their face in her chest might now only be able to content themselves with planting a tentative kiss on Nel’s ankle! Nel continued to look about her, inspecting the wet slates of the church roof, peering in at the windows as best she could to see any signs of life. “Hello? Anyone there?” Nel asked, surprised by the loudness of her voice. All that Nel could discern through the fine drizzle at this moment though was a flock of sheep bleating in a nearby field, adorably small like balls of cotton with which Nel might powder her nose of stuff her ears.

A prickling across her rear reminded Nel of the discomfort she has forgotten upon discovering her new size. Clutching the nearby roof, though conscious that her new strength and weight might break the beams, Nel rose to her feet. Again, not used to her size, and having been recumbent for so long, Nel was overcome by vertigo; for a dreadful moment, as her vision clouded and seemed to be waning, Nel though she might faint or tumble backwards and crush the church roof under what was unquestionably a rather prodigious rump! But momentarily, after her initial wobbliness, Nel composed herself. Having done so, Nel was able to turn her attention to that bothersome stinging. Twisting herself to regard as best she could the bulge of her buttocks, Nel could just about make out something plastered to her huge rear. Perhaps it was only the angle, but Nel felt that her ass was larger than before. Reaching back delicately Nel grasped what felt like a drawing pin pushed into her skin and pulled it from herself with a wince, feeling the other point of discomfort pang for a moment, resisting coming away, before one by one coming free from her giant cheeks one tack after another. Rubbing her smarting ass with one hand, Nel inspected with a mild annoyance the dangling stakes and wires of fencing she she had removed from herself, which must have lined her butt-cheeks like a spiraling staircase lined the trunk of a tree or cobbled tower.

Her rear finally debarbed, Nel breathed out and looked around her, finally able to adjust to, and appreciate, her newfound scale. Indeed, it was marvelous! To see out over the fields as she now could, she felt she could see for miles were it not for the veils of rain passing over the landscape. Nel’s chest practically swelled with the thrill that was gradually overcoming her. That was to talk only of her height, for Nel felt that her chest had ballooned also, a thought she attempted to verify with a quick heft of her breasts, filling her cupped hands as a pumpkin fills a pudding bowl, before letting the slap back wetly. Nel brushed a damp lock of hair from her eyes before placing her hands upon her hips, looking about biting her lip, still at a loss as to what to do. Should she stay put, out of sight, or search the area? People might not welcome a giantess strolling into their midst. Ought she to find Kevin? Would she even be able to see him at this size? Not easily unless he too had grown. Of course, he could not help but see her if he were nearby. But how, for that matter, had she grown as she did? These things didn’t quite happen on their own, even Clare needed her allergic reaction to the mixed potions to make her grow so large. As she mused, there came the light rumble of thunder in the distance. Of course, thought Nel, it must have been the lightning! It could only be that. Apparently my body was able to eat up a big jolt from mother nature herself! I’m not unscathed, thought Nel, looking at the few bruises formed on her creamy skin, but good God have I been juiced up! Nel wonder how she might stack up to Clare now? Probably not favourably, she concluded. It was hard to tell how big Clare had been, or exactly how big Nel herself was now. Big enough to incline herself as she thought and flick, lightly, the thimble-like church bell with her finger. Straightening up, Nel began to leave the churchyard, taking her first steps as a giantess, marvelling at the thunder of her footsteps, and just as much at the weight of herself, even muffled by the damp ground. Within moments, Nel was crossing the fields by the churchyard...
11521212112121122212212221121.title: Bottled Lightning

choices: Upset, Nel wanders aimlessly, looking for a place to rest...
Furious, Nel decides to get bigger and act like a real monster!
Nel encounters something/someone in the darkness...
115212121121211222122122211211.content:
The afternoon was drawing to close in the little town and now the clouds had cleared for the most part and the sky now dripped only occasionally. The tea-time bells were ringing in the clock-tower as the townspeople made their way home along the lanes. As these town-folk walked home under umbrellas and trudged along in their galoshes there could be heard a peal of thunder from the cavernous, purple clouds above. People thought little of this, save perhaps quickening their pace.

thoom...

A young woman was sitting at the window in her attic, where she liked to sit and watch the day draw to a close, enjoying the townsfolk plashing through puddles and watching the rain fall across the fields and the wood, looking out absentmindedly watching the rooftops and the little birds in the gutters as she waited for her husband to return; as she did so though her languorous eyes widened as she saw…

thoom…

The owner of one of the town’s best tailors had just pulled to and locked the green door of his shop and begun the walk home, taking, as he usually did, the cobbled road that followed the town’s walls, when, as he was musing thoughts about his grandkids, the sun suddenly faded and he looked up to see…

thoom…

Another woman, in her back garden in the midst of hanging out her washing on the line, was conscious of a dark shadow spreading across her year, as if a cloud was passing over the sun, and looking around, over her garden wall, she dropped her basket of washing and could not help but scream at the sight of…

Thoom…

A guardsman, standing and leaning against the wall, was vacantly looking out across the fields and in real danger of nodding off when, all of a sudden, there came...

Thoom...

A stray cat, lounging in the sun cast on the town wall, jumped with fright and ran skittering across the battlements…

THOOM!

On the roof of the town hall a young man was at work replacing the slates that had been blown off in the gales of earlier in the month; as he worked to fix the last few slates in place before the day was done, he felt the slates jittering as he held them in place, and saw the spare slates he’d brought with him clacking together; raising his head and shielding her eyes he looked out across the rooftops to see…

THOOM! Crunnnch!

The townsfolk were shocked, some screaming, others fled, to see an enormous, blue-haired young woman approach and effortlessly straddle the walls, her huge leg gliding over and hooking over the town perimeter, a sheepish smile of the giant young lady’s face, as if to apologise to the townsfolk for her awkwardness and the panic caused by her size. Indeed, her case was not helped by the crunching of stone between the young lady’s massive, thick thighs. Awkwardly, this blue-haired giantess hauled her other leg over behind her, apologising as she took some of the masonry with her. The young lady must be, so the panicking people thought, contrary to her placating and booming cries of “STOP!”, “COME BACK!” and “PLEASE...”, some kind of voluptuous monster. This they judged by the great diaphanous wings splayed out from the giant young lady’s massive shoulders, which scintillated brilliantly, in rainbow colours, with the fine rain that pearled across their glassy panes and veins during the afternoon.

The townsfolk scurried away from the young giantess, who awkwardly pursued them in resounding, wet footfalls along the cobbled streets. As the giantess peered down at them while making her way through the streets on legs that seemed to dwarf the streetlights as one would wading through tall rushes, her blue hair, damp from the rain, fell about her face and across her eyes like the leaves of a night-blue willow tree. The town was rural, but of a respectable size; it had formed originally in the middle ages inside the protective star-shaped ring of the the now decaying walls, superfluous in this day and age, especially given the ease with which a giantess might ease herself into the town as if stepping into a hot bath. As a result the houses were of an old-fashioned sort and in places were tightly packed together, interlaced with many lanes and alleys, their steepled roofs almost at times seeming to touch those of the houses running parallel. Through this the intruding giantess tried her best to make her way. Trying to maneuver the huge trunks of her legs through the narrow streets and twisting her lissome yet massive torso so that her bulky thighs or buttocks did not gouge clumps from the masonry or tear off guttering as she went, the blue-haired giantess succeeded only in unbalancing herself and only prevented herself from toppling by clutching at a nearby chimney stack, which crumbled in her hands, and which swung the huge weight of unwieldy bosom into the facade, knocking out the windows.

Apologising profusely, Nel attempted to replace the chimney stack, which slid off almost immediately and smashed in a neighbouring lane. Nel winced; she swept back her hair and held it with her hands as she attempted to see the townsfolk about her feet, it was made difficult not only by her size but by the gleam of the sun on the wet streets. Nel sighed as she looked at the townsfolk rush in ripples through the puddles, and Nel could not help but feel like one of those tall wading birds that young pixies were sometimes warned about at school, standing amongst masses of thick-clumped reeds and looking down at minnows darting across the surface of an amber pond.

Nel could feel her voice, booming though it was, break a little as she pleaded with the townsfolk not to be afraid, that she only wanted to be fitted for some clothes, to have only a little something to eat and a warm, dry place to spend the night and that, though she had no money on her, she could help them about the town by way of payment. Before long, Nel had waded through that particularly narrow street, her huge backside repeatedly becoming wedged and having to be tugged free. Nel stood embarrassed and upset in the town square, rubbing her chafed cheeks.

The streetlights were coming on as night fell and Nel still was casting about for townspeople he
half-heartedly; “PLEASE!” she boomed, then, conscious of her size, she lowered her voice as best she could “I just need a little help…”. Seeing lights coming from a street and the shadows of people stretching tall, but not so tall as her, Nel advanced across the square in expectation. Her face sank however when she made out by the dots of lantern light the local constabulary, whom she more than expected were armed. Putting up her hands, Nel gingerly advanced on the crowd but was met with cries to “halt” and “desist” from the figures. Nel tried to explain herself but was drowned out by the crowd forming behind the guards, yelling things like “Get out of here monster!” Nel could not help but back up as the crowd continued to surge forward, emboldened by the giantess’ shy disposition despite her obvious stature. Nel could hear the sound of objects being hurled and it wasn’t long before she felt on her left thigh the sharp pin-prick of something striking her and bouncing off. “HEY!” Nel yelped, drawing herself up protectively. As the crowd advanced the fusillade continued, cobbles and bottles striking her knees and shins and her hands as she clutched them over her huge, soft breasts. “OWCH! STOP IT!” she wailed as she retreated from the angry mob.

All of a sudden, Nel registered a blinding red flash from the crowd, presumably a flare or a firework, but which was quickly catapulted towards her face! Nel reeled just in time to save the thing hitting her eyes, but dazzling her and sending her stumbling backwards across the square. As she stumbled, Nel blundered into a street light, which burst in a bloom of glass. The sharp jolt from the streetlamp only made Nel, still blinded, lurch backwards (some members of the crowd, which was cheering and rushing forward, would later swear that they saw the giantess leap a foot in height as the shock passed through her.) As she floundered, Nel’s foot caught on a metal bench, knocking her from her feet and send her crashing down, buttocks first, onto the post office. Let us just say that the townsfolk ought to be thankful that seconds later the power grid to the town went out, for as Nel’s rump broke through the network of lighting and power lines in the roofspace of the Post Office, she was momentarily exposed to a huge surge of electricity, which, at the very instant the lights of the town went out, to blew Nel up by almost half her already giant size! The crowd was frozen as the young giantess’ splayed legs suddenly seemed to rocket forth across the square! Others were stunned by the way her huge hips erupted almost instantaneously from the roof space, as if a charge of dynamite had been set off inside, sending splintered wood flying! Others were dumbstruck by the violent way in which the giantess’ torso shot up with a rapid crackling, as if her spine were stretching and popping, and how her huge, pendulous breasts seemed to inflate like weather balloons. The suddenness of the events was enough to induce utter panic amongst the townsfolk, suddenly plunged into darkness. Groggily heaving herself from the Post Office, Nel rose to her new height, still not quite conscious of what had happened, and tottered for a moment wincing with pain. Hearing the screams and confusion around her, Nel let instinct drive her and, spreading her wings, took several booming strides before leaping, using her wings, though she could not manage to fly, to bear her in one graceful jump out of the town walls, where she landed with a resounding boom somewhere in the darkness and fled, in massive, clumsy stomps, into the humid, black-blue darkness...
